story:
Our Story

As part of our mission to foster literacy learning in Lincoln, Nebraska, we’ve started a crowd-sourced fundraising campaign to help us print a book of writing from the children of Writing Lincoln Initiative. Those who follow the work of Writing Lincoln Initiative know that we hold a writing club for students (K-6) in the after-school program at Clyde Malone Community Center.

The kids work hard on writing projects like songs, poems, puppet shows, comic books, letters, and stories, and learn basic literacy skills and writing habits along the way. In order to celebrate their fantastic efforts, we decided to anthologize their writing in a book that each child can have for free and be proud of. This book will be entirely composed using writings from children in the WLI’s Malone Center writing club.

But, we need the community’s support to make this happen.


Our Goal

Our goal is to raise $1000 to fund the publishing of a book of student writing and to purchase school supplies to support our work in the community for the coming summer and school year.  We want each child to get a free copy of the book to share with their families and to remember their experience in the writing club.

Even if we don't reach our entire goal, we'll hope to make a significant dent in the cost of printing books.  We have big dreams if we surpass our goal too -- we'd love to outfit our writing classrooms with a handful of tablets, plenty of pencils, pens, and notebooks, and prizes to share with writers!

For your participation in the campaign, Writing Lincoln will send you a personal message, thanking you for your contribution to the writing club. Additionally, we'll toss a few perks your way for donations of $10 or more!

The Impact of Writing Lincoln

Launched in fall 2012, the Writing Lincoln Initiative is a community outreach program established through the University of Nebraska-Lincoln Writing Center. It is made up of a mix of graduate, undergraduate, and community volunteers that work with writers of all ages and backgrounds one-with-one to provide a friendly and supportive space for writing.

We've grown our tutor and volunteer network considerably in the past year, but we need the community's help to make us a regular fixture around Lincoln. Check out our website at www.writinglincoln.org, follow us on Twitter @writinglincoln, and "Like" us on Facebook!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute money, but that doesn't mean they can’t help:

  • Spread the word about our campaign to your family and friends using the Indiegogo share tools!  
  • Volunteer to spend time reading, writing, talking, and learning alongside community members this year!
  • Send school supplies and prizes to the Writing Lincoln Initiative, c/o UNL Writing Center, 115 Andrews Hall, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE 68588

Thanks again for your support! 

Thich Nhat Hanh says "Alone I am one drop of water that can evaporate easily. With others I am a river that can move mountains."

Let's be the river.

story:
Short Summary

One of our own CORA-raised players, Jenna McBride, will be representing Canada at the Ringette World Championships in North Bay starting on 29 Dec 2013. 

Jenna is involved in almost every part of ringette.  She has played on a variety of Provincial-winning teams, has represented Ontario at National Championships, and Canada at previous World Championships, and has been a member of the CORA NRL team for the past 7 years.  She's a mentor and coach, has been assistant coach and coach on a variety of Tween AA and Junior AA teams, and has coached powerskating.  She's also one of the best referees in Ottawa.

She has given a lot to CORA and to CORA players.  She has trained coaches who coach your daughters today and she has inspired a whole new generation of player coaches including four working this year with U10 Purple and U16B. In fact if you are a coach at CORA chances are you have a Jenna McBride play in your playbook.

This is our opportunity as an organization and as a community to help offset the costs involved in playing for ringette for Canada.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is what we need:

  • It will cost Jenna over $7,000 in travel expenses by the time she has completed all the training required to be a member of Team Canada
  • Any contribution that you make helps to offset this cost.

Here is what your team gets:

  • We have a bunch of cool incentives for teams that raise money. Check them out, get excited and raise some money.

The Impact

Good role models are hard to find and in ringette we work hard to bring players back into the fold as coaches, assistant coaches and volunteers. But coaching requires a combination of skills - leadership, diplomacy, empathy and a strong knowledge of the game.

We understand ringette better at CORA because Jenna has been coaching at the top level for the last six years. Helping her to follow her dreams and compete for gold at the Ringette World Championships is the least that we can do.

 

Our Target

We set a modest target - $1,000 - let's shatter it !

story:
The Earthquake 

On April 25th a massive 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck Nepal 50 miles to the west of the bustling city of Kathmandu where over one million people call home.  So far its estimated that there are over 8,000 deaths and another 14,000 casualties.  With lack of power, many collapsed or unsafe homes, and dwindling resources over half a million people are estimated to have been displaced and are in need of immediate attention.  Western regions have been the hardest hit.  Entire villages have been destroyed and access roads cut off.  The ancient city of Bhaktapur, home to over 80,000 people has had a majority of its buildings collapse.  


Fundrasing

Hi, my name is Kevin Lanuk and I'm the founder of a Himalayan start-up called Mountkarma.  Nepal is a place close to my heart filled with some of the most grounded, kind and generous people I've ever known.  My friends and colleagues live and work in Kathmandu and while our team is safe and sound a great deal of people haven't been as fortunate.

Mountkarma in coordination with our partner organization J.M. Trading are creating a 100% volunteer based relief effort in Nepal to help bring 1st and 2nd level help to villages in need.

At the moment what people need most are tents, rice, salt, oil, pulses and medicine.  Monsoon season is also on its way and more than anything people will need shelter. The entirety of the proceeds will be used for purchasing these goods which will be transported to the assessed villages in need.  Because we're doing this on a volunteer basis we have no administrative costs which will insure all of the donations go to helping the victims.  Please join me in bringing relief to some of the areas and people that need it the most.  


Our Goal

We're seeking to raise as much as we can with the goal of reaching $10,000 USD so we can use the funds to purchase and distribute materials that Nepali people in rural villages will need during the next few months.

All contributions are welcome under the big CONTRIBUTE button and you also have the choice of receiving one of our  Tibetan prayer flag shirt which is handmade by our artisans in Nepal.  

As we collectively strive to reach our donation goal of $10,000, I will be trying to personally raise funds to travel to Nepal and help efforts in person.


Who We Are

While a great deal of charities and organizations are raising funds for providing relief services around Nepal many smaller local NGO’s are not receiving the same amount of attention.  These organizations can make big differences in their communities  given the financial resources.  By working hands-on with smaller local organizations we will have the ability to more easily manage the impact and transparency of our crowdfunding campaign.


Josh Barrow - I am a Business and Management student at Oxford Brookes University. I have a passion for helping others, hence my work in the third-sector. I have worked for charities such as  Fuse School, who provide free, high quality education to everyone.

https://www.youtube.com/user/virtualschooluk

Kevin Lanuk - I'm the founder of a start-up called Mountkarma, a Himalayan clothing brand which supports artisans and communities in Lazimpat, Kathmandu.  www.mountkarma.com

Martins - My name is Martins and I’m the Co Founder and Production Manager  of J.M TRADING Pvt Ltd In Kathmandu, Nepal.  We create workshops in rural developing areas where we train the local people in learning to improve the cultivation of raw materials such as hemp and bamboo. Through our workshops we help to increase the potentiality of women in these remote areas as well as deter child labour.  

J.M. Trading

Its important to note that we are not a registered charitable organization and therfore cannot give tax exemptions for any donations made.  We are a collaborative team of individuals and organizations with members on the ground in Kathmandu, Nepal.  Parties involved are Mountkarma LLC & J.M. Trading pvt ltd.


Tibetan Prayer flag Limited Edition T-Shirts


Donations of $100 or more can choose to receive our limited edition Tibetan Prayer Flag T-shirt. This hand crafted one of a kind garment is made in Nepal by our skilled artisans and is a unique blend of 70/30 Bamboo & Organic cotton. Each shirt is adorned with a one of the 5 elemental prayer flags from Nepal; Sky, Wind, Fire, Water and Earth. Additional detailing on the sleeves showing our iconic logo.

Prayer flags are ancient Tibetan devices used for turning our misfortune into fortune and the spread of positive energy.  When wind passes through the flags there energy is released and carried by the Lung Ta (Wind Horse) into all the surrounding areas.  They’re an age old force for good and change.

Mens Crew neck - Color options: black, white

Womens V neck - Color options: black, white

  • Handmade in Nepal

  • 70/30 Bamboo & Organic Cotton

  • "From Sky to Earth" badge on both sleeves

  • Your choice of Prayer flag element:  Sky (blue), Wind (white), Fire (red), Water (green), Earth (yellow)

  • Unique summit hem


Movement of Funds

Funds > Indiegogo > Mountkarma LLC paypal > purchases of food and aid materials --> delivery and distribution

Mountkarma

J.M. Trading


Transparency

-All the money raised (beside the processing fees of Indigogo or any banking transfer fees) will be used to purchase food and materials which will be donated to  Nepali people in need.

-Updates about the status of the funds and any images or video of our efforts will be presented on our campaign page.

-Transactions will be documented and made available.  

-I will fly to Nepal and handle transactions personally if we reach our goal.


Additional Support

We are also running a Thunderclap campaign which you can sign up to and show your support. It will make our voices louder, and make our cause stronger through everyone sending out our message on the 17th of May using their social media. Sign up here:

https://www.thunderclap.it/projects/26079-mountkarma-s-nepal-aid-project?locale=en

If you would like to help the people of Nepal in other ways here are two great charities to consider:

Redcross Nepal earthquake relief donation page

Oxfam Nepal earthquake donation page

story:
Spark tomorrow's vocal artistry today.

Be part of our 57 year legacy of offering vocal scholarships to gifted singers!

Voices of Canton, Inc, formerly Canton Civic Opera, is a 90 voice community chorus performing its 75th season.

Our mission is to celebrate choral arts through performance, using the power of “many voices” as a catalyst within the community to educate, inspire and unite.

This year VOCI is pleased to present $4,500 in scholarships to six deserving area students studying vocal music. Twenty-eight talented, young singers, representing eleven universities/music schools (Baldwin Wallace, Capital University, Cleveland Institute of Music, College of Wooster, Eastman School of Music, Malone University, Ohio University, University of Akron, University of Dayton, University of Toledo and University of Valley Forge) competed for six scholarships totaling $4,500.

100% of all contributions made are applied to vocal scholarships.

With your generous financial contribution, we can continue our tradition of supporting gifted singers' vocal arts education.

story:
Help keep Jeff, Elikplim, Wisdom, Seyram, Ramatu, Eyi and Etsa in school!

 

Short Summary

Opening Books to Open Doors is the brain child of Oscar Azameti, a recent graduate of the University of Ghana at Legon. Having struggled to afford education as a child, by the time I met Oscar at age 27 and a junior in University, he was already brainstorming ways to provide scholarships to children in his community.

My name is Morgan Bober, and I have been working with Oscar for the last three years to send seven children from Klikor, Ghana to school. These are children who are passionate about education, who want to use an education to help their community, but whose families cannot afford the fees associated with schooling without outside financial assistance.

Oscar and Morgan, in Ghana

 

Having grown up in the United States with access to free education and very few impediments to learning, it is heartbreaking for me to know that these children in Ghana are so motivated by and so dedicated to an education that they cannot afford.

The fees associated with an education in Ghana, from a uniform to exam fees to lunch and transportation, are financial barriers to many children and their families. These barriers are too often correlated with an individual’s ability to obtain a well paying job or to help lift their family out of poverty.

To learn more about our students, check out their profiles on our website at this link.

Your assistance can help right this wrong, and provide the opportunity for these impressive youngsters to obtain an education that they would not otherwise receive.

 

 

Jeff doing work in class to become a doctor

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $1000 to contribute towards the students’ fall term, to be paid at the end of November. The full cost of a term is $1200.

This money covers all seven students and pays for:

  • Tuition--$400 for all 7 students
  • Books and school supplies--$360 for all 7 students
  • Fees for exams, sports, and miscellaneous--$115 for all 7 students
  • Lunch and a snack everyday--$325 for all 7 students

These fees can vary marginally from term to term, and year to year depending on the student’s class year and additional resources needed. There is also variation due to fluctuations in currency exchange, as these numbers are converted from the Ghanaian cedi.

In appreciation of your contribution, we have several perks to send from the students and their community including letters and videos of thanks, as well as art made by artisans throughout Klikor.

Seyram preparing for an exam so that he can grow up to be an engineer 

 

 

The Impact

The students that we are working with are embarking on their third year of school. We are starting to see positive returns from these students; they are learning incredible things and working hard to take advantage of the opportunity that these scholarships provide.

We are beginning to see the impact of education on these children; on education as a tool for empowerment, for community development and for personal self-attainment.

Providing an education to these children gives them the opportunity to lift themselves and their family out of the poverty cycle and enables them to dream
big and make those dreams a reality.

Elikplim, studying in class so that she can become a teacher

 

Other Ways You Can Help

To keep this project going, we are looking not just for financial assistance, but also for people to help us raise awareness. Please share this link on facebook, tweet it and send the project to your friends!

We have only a short time to raise this money to ensure that Jeff, Elikplim, Wisdom, Seyram, Ramatu, Eyi and Etsa stay in school!

For more information, please check out our website at http://openingbooks.bellstrike.com.

Thank you for all of your help! Without people who believe in what we're doing, these wonderful children would not have the chance to be students.

story:
My name is Katie Caldwell and I am in 8th grade. I have been
offered an amazing, life-changing opportunity to learn about foreign cultures
through a program called People to People. The trip includes England, Ireland,
Scotland, and Whales.

This program was established to help individuals like me face challenges and grow personally in ways that can be used in leadership roles. During the 19 day trip, we not only get to visit important landmarks, but also get to experience the culture through activities, interaction with local people, and overnight stays with a host family.

If you donate you will see the pictures and notes I will post on what we
did during the trip. This will show you all the great things you made possible for me by donating to my campaign.

To learn more about the People to People program please visit their site at: http://www.peopletopeople.com/find-a-trip/all-programs/europe/celtic-cultures?Grades=8&ZipCodes=85374

story:
Who we are and what we do:

Research is exciting and us Utrecht University Research Master Neuroscience & Cognition students are all glad to be in the game. We are an interdisciplinary master made up of biologists, psychologists, linguists and computer scientists.

The future of our species depends on our technological progress and as neuroscientists we are studying the most complex engine we know: the human brain. Advances in this field will not only contribute to healthier and more efficient minds but also advance the evolution of intelligence, for example through saner human-computer interaction.

The goals of neuroscience to which you would be contributing include to understand the human mind and brain (the way we perceive and interact with the world) as well as curing debilitating neurological diseases (such as Alzheimer's disease) and psychiatric illness.

To pool our collective knowledge and to kickstart everyone's careers we are organizing a symposium on May 13th & 14th. The topics (among others) will center around optogenetic techniques, cognitive enhancement, artificial intelligence and the reversal of aging in the brain.


Why we need you:

We plan to invite several international researchers to give inspiring lectures on their area of expertise. However, covering their travel costs and lodging is very expensive and makes up the bulk of the event budget.

You can help to make this symposium a glowing, memorable success for the participating 100+ students who will soon be launching themselves into the science world. Your contribution will make a big difference for the sprouting neuroscientists as it will inspire career decisions and allow them to form professional contacts in the neuroscience community beyond geographical borders. It's simple: the more funds we have available the more interesting speakers we can invite.

It takes ~$500 to invite a speaker from Europe and ~$1000 to invite someone from further away. Approximately $280 resp. $780 for travel costs, $120 for lodging and $100 for other expenses such as dinner and thank-you gifts.

If you pledge towards our goal as a sponsor you will, besides our deepest gratitude, receive exposure both towards the attendees of the Symposium as well as to the broader neuroscience community.

Although we strive to use all the funds gathered via this campaign in this year's event, any potential funds not used will be transferred to next year's committee, which will give them a headstart for the Mind the Brain Symposium that will take place in 2015.


Contact us:


Chairman:                  Paul Zerr                      p.zerr@students.uu.nl

Senior supervisor:     Mariken de Krom          m.dekrom-3@umcutrecht.nl


Also check out the website:  http://mindthebrain.nl







                                                                     ~ The enthusiastic 2014 committee

story:
Hello, my name is Morgan Rippke, and I am trying to begin my adventure at Iowa State University to achieve my Master's Degree in Education. I returned to Iowa State University after being away for 6 years and worked hard to achieve a double degree in Psychology and Sociology and to build my GPA back up to graduate with Honors. 

However, that time away has come back now to haunt me, as the loans I consolidated in order to achieve this goal have now come to collect. I've already been accepted at Iowa State University for the Fall of 2013, but my loans are preventing me from making an attempt to earn a Master's Degree even possible. 

So, here is what I need. For a semester at Iowa State University, it will cost me a total of $4440 after fees are added in. In this semester's time, I can work with the loans that are preventing me from granting my financial assistantship to release my financial package and place me back on track to achieving the degree I'm seeking.

Now, you may notice that I'm only asking for part of the amount that I need. The reason for this is that I'm currently seeking other means of helping me get back into school and so I won't need to campaign for the full amount. The funds that are raised through Indiegogo will be put towards my college tuition, with any extra amount being used to help pay off the outstanding loans.

If this campaign doesn't reach its goal, that isn't going to be the end of my own campaign to return to Iowa State, and any money raised will go towards this endeavor.  

This is my first time trying something like this, but if you contribute even a dollar towards this campaign, I will personally send you a thank you note in response to your donation. This project is very personal to me, as it'll be the first step in my eventual goal of earning my Ph.D, and you could have a hand in making this happen. 

And if you can't donate a dollar towards this campaign, please share this with your friends and explain what it's for. I'm not asking for much, but every dollar helps. Please help this campaign be a success.

Thank you.

-Morgan Rippke

story:
The Project:

Hello!  We're Rebecca Jones and Norina Beck, the directors of Rising Song Preschool, For the past five years our little school has provided quality, affordable childcare to families in Portland Oregon.  We believe in the importance of small class size, play based learning, and connecting children to the natural world. Our tuition is sliding scale, and supports families of all income levels.    

Our school is currently located in a rented house.  For the last year we've been looking for a permanent home for our school.  We're excited to be in the process of purchasing a residential house on a 1/2 acre of land, so we can relocate and expand our school.  With your help we plan to turn the land into a beautiful garden, orchard and play area as well put the finishing touches on renovating the existing building.  This move will allow our school double in size, impacting twice as many families and children.  

To find out more about our school, please visit us at:

http://www.risingsongpreschool.org


What We Need & What You Get

We have raised 90% of the downpayment for the property.  Our loan includes a construction budget of $21,785, which will help us get most of the work done but cannot include landscaping work for the school garden  and a few other necessary renovations.

 The $10,000 raised in this campaign will be used to:

1.  Complete the sale: This money will finalize the sale of the property

Total: $3,500 

2.  Transform the vacant lot into a beautiful school garden: 

-Site Clearing and Soil Prep: $1200

-Plant materials: $2000

-Simple wood Tool Shed: $2000

Total: $5200

3.  Renovate the existing house to bring it up to code for educational use. (state certification fees, interior painting, light fixtures, etc): 

Total: $1,300


The Impact

Our mission is to influence and better the lives of the children and families we work with. Contributing to our campaign creates social change in our community and in our world. You can be a part of this change by supporting our life's work to make a loving learning environment for young children.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Purchasing this property is only the first step towards opening a classroom in September.  There are numerous ways you can help us get there!  

Volunteer your time: 

-Help get the word out- post our campaign on facebook and twitter.  Make a buzz for us!

-Get dirty in our garden! We will be hosting several work parties.  Let us know if you can lend a hand. 

-Organize and distribute perks to contributors.

-Pick up items for the new classroom found on craigslist etc.

-Sewing and knitting projects (curtains, wool ropes, simple dolls/animals--patterns available!)

Donate: 

-Natural and/or wooden toys for the classroom (shells, stones, gems, blocks, wooden cars, cloth, silk)

-Art materials

-Plants and/or seeds for our garden 

-House plants to beautify the classroom (cuttings from your already existing plants, or neglected ones that could use a loving home!)

-Use of a truck!

story:
Background

My name is Lex Alexander and I’m an aspiring web developer. I’ve been teaching myself how to code and most recently won fourth place at Hack for LA's hackathon, for my app MapMySnaps.

How will the scholarship work? 10 percent of my income for my first two years as a programmer will fund the scholarship. The recipient(s) of the scholarship will then be asked to do just as I did, donate 10 percent of their income for two years to the next person. Similarly, the next recipient will do this as well, in effect, paying it forward.

After Hack for LA’s hackathon I decided to enroll myself in a coding boot camp, but I realized I was not going to be able to pay the full $11,500 tuition. In response, I’m launching an Indiegogo campaign, in order to raise the full amount I need and to keep my career as a programmer on track. As thanks for those who are currently helping me reach my goals, I’m giving back and creating a scholarship. This scholarship will send women and other minorities to coding bootcamps and help solve the racial and gender disparities in tech, as well as keep their dreams on track.


What I Need & What You Get

I need 9,000 total to pay my remaining tuition, fulfill all Indiegogo obligations, and to launch the Code it Forward Scholarship.

What you get:

$5

Have your name immortalized in the comments of any code that I write and a shoutout on social media.


$20

An email thanking you for your contribution to making the tech world more diverse and a shoutout on social media.

$100

You'll receive a sponsored Code it Forward t-shirt.

$500

Receive an autographed photo of the recipient along with a thank you card.

$1000

You'll receive a personalized video from the recipient telling you their goals and aspirations and thanking you for your contribution.

$2000

You'll get a vote in choosing the recipient plus all of the above.


The Impact

Women represent only 18 percent of all undergraduate degrees in computer and information science, And while the overall percentage of 24-year-olds in the United States with STEM degrees is 6 percent, it's just 2.7 percent among African-Americans and 2.2 percent for Latinos. The Code it Forward scholarship, will not only enable women, blacks, and other ethnicities to learn how to code and take their careers to a new level. But it will also create a bond and network under the umbrella of scholarship and community advancement that is second to none. This scholarship will give currently inaccessible opportunities to the demographics and communities that need it most.

Other Ways You Can Help

Join me now in paying it forward by sharing this campaign with everyone you know using the #codeitforward hashtag so we can build a network of coders who change the world one line of a code at a time.

story:
Short Summary

Hello,

My Name is Charles Miles, and I come from a large family. Two weeks ago, my mom called me and asked me to start contributing to a college education account she set up for my four little brothers.

She contributes a little here and there, but she can't put much away since her full-time $12 an hour job barely covers the bills. She sounded a little sad at how much she's been able to save, and it made me want to be able to do something greater than my own salary allows me to contribute to the account--I want to surprise her and put a big smile on her face by putting a lump sum of $4000 into the college savings account for my little brothers.

A little background, she's a widow of almost 2 years and regularly works 14 hour shifts to provide for my little brothers (we lost my dad to cancer after a long two year battle). She's an amazing person and always thinks of her kids before herself. She's been worrying a lot lately because she doesn't want my brothers to have to go into debt like I did to get a college education. The impact this will have on how she feels about how much is saved for their education and on my little brothers' future education will be huge!

I've set a fundraising $4,000 goal because I think that, given the number of amazing people out there, it is a reachable goal. I also think it would make an amazing late birthday present for her.

If you can't afford a donation, you can still help me by posting it on someone's wall, sharing it on a blog, or blasting it on your status! Indiegogo has all sorts of ways to share the information. Please help me reach my goal, and thanks for supporting my family!

story:
On May 7, 2009 there was a bullying incident at a small school in British Columbia, Canada where a brave student had to go to an enormous amount of trouble just to give the school staff a 'heads up' as to what was going on.   As a result of this incident and the subsequent shock that there was no such bullying reporting system a teacher from that school launched STOP A BULLY four days later.  STOP A BULLY allows ANY student in Canada who is witness to serious bullying at school or online to be able to report it safely to school officials.

Since its launch in 2009 STOP A BULLY has received tremendous attention and support from students, parents, schools, youth organizations and police departments across Canada.  In April 2012 we were invited to Canada's capital to testify to the Senate Committee on Human Rights who are reporting on strategies to combat cyberbullying.

Despite our incredible rate of growth, our program is now entering into the 4th school year without any corporate or government funding.  The founding teacher is still paying the bills...

STOP A BULLY is a national Non-Profit Organization and desperately needs great Canadians to back us so we can keep up with the current rate of growth and demand for our program.

Go to www.StopABully.ca

All Sponsors will be honoured on our TEAM STOP A BULLY page.

*Canadian Non-Profit Organizations are NOT able to issue Tax Receipts.

---------------

Quotes from STOP A BULLY website:

"From destroying my art projects, pushing me in the hallways, name calling, and even stooping so low as to placing feces on my locker; I felt sick to my stomach each and every day I was made to go to school." 

[Parent] "I think every school in Canada should be a part of this program. Children need a safe place to report bullying!"
 
[Parent] "As a mum of two very young girls I am so happy to see a site and program like this....with enough of us writing... the schools, administrators, teachers, politicians will listen."
 
[Other] "I am the RCMP School Liaison for this school and feel this would be a great program for the school"

story:
See our website for updates:

http://cusd.cornell.edu/ssa/

Our Story

In the past academic semester, Cornell students have catalogued existing and potential sustainable practices in South Africa and have created a comprehensive atlas of their research.  This 200-page atlas will inform the design of a 6,000 square foot Early Childhood Development center (known locally as a crèche) and is currently in three of Cornell's libraries and throughout the design studio. Cornell architecture students will complete the design within the next few weeks and the crèche will be constructed by volunteer students during Summer 2011 in Cosmo City, South Africa. 


The Impact

Currently, children in Cosmo City attend school in a 6ft x 6ft room with 79 other students.  This will be the first official crèche in Cosmo City.  With the introduction of Schoolhouse South Africa's crèche, children up to age 7 will be able to attend a school that affords them space to learn and play.  

This project also includes a teacher training center that will allow for other schools to have their teachers trained by Education Africa.  In this way, the benefit of our school is not limited to only the students attending the school.


What We Need & What You Get

The schoolhouse will cost ultimately around $150,000.  We are looking to reach a minimum of $50,000 here on indiegogo.com within the next two months.  This money covers only materials and permits.  The labor to build the crèche is all volunteer (30 eager students and 10 local African laborers), and the travel cost will all be covered by the volunteers as well.  We are very fortunate to also have the support of alumni of the CUSD program, the school, and family and friends.

The book from our extensive research (for use in the design phase, as well as to encourage other people and organizations in similar projects by providing a solid starting point) can be seen here.

CUSD Schoolhouse: South Africa Research Compilation Book


Other Ways You Can Help

We are always looking for contacts to help us make Schoolhouse South Africa a reality.  Any material donors in South Africa, professional companies in building related fields, are welcome to contact us and discuss contributions. We have an extremely active and well developed media campaign, and you will be featured amongst our partners.

story:
Our Story

We are the York University Rover Team (YURT), a group of enthusiastic York students from a wide range of disciplines all working towards a common goal: to build and develop a prototypical rover platform to compete in NASA's Lunabotics Mining Competition, Mars Society's University Rover Challenge (URC), and CSii's Robotics Competition. So what's a rover? Well, it's basically a robot that you send to outer space for exploration purposes. Cool, right?

Founded in 2007, this is our fifth year competing in the University Rover Challenge. We have made our mark at this competition by placing on the podium every year we've competed against other remarkable teams from around the world. At URC, the idea is to build a Mars rover that can one day work alongside human explorers in space. The rover has to complete a series of simulated tasks in the Utah desert such as delivering rescue packages to lost astronauts, fixing a broken equipment panel, finding signs of life and site surveying. On the other hand, this is our very first try at NASA's Lunabotics competition which focuses on building a Lunar rover capable of mining soil on the moon, and our second time at CSii's Robotics Competition which showcases young innovators of today. URC will be held May 31-June 2 at the Mars Desert Research Station, NASA's Lunabotics Competition will be held on May 21-26 at the Kennedy Space Centre, Florida; and CSii's Robotics Competition will be held July 9-10 at the Deerhurst Resort, Ontario.

We are a fully student-ran project and during the school year, our team dedicates countless time, effort, and sweat outside of the classroom into researching, building, and programming our rover in addition to fundraising and public outreach projects. Being part of the team provides us with a very unique hands-on experience unlike any other. It helps us appreciate more of what we learned at the university and even learn skills that are not taught in the classroom. Many of us who went on the trip to Utah last year agreed that it was definitely one of the best experiences of our lifetime and we hope to go again this year for a championship title at all three competitions!

So far, through the generous support of our university and the hard work of our team members, we have been able to build a competitive rover that's versatile enough for the three competitions. However, the biggest problem is: in order to travel from Toronto to Florida, then to Utah and back to Toronto again, it will cost us an estimated $15 000. We are not far from our goal, but we need your help to make this last step! Ideally, we would like to attend the three competitions and take about 15 members but if we cannot raise the sufficient funds, we will have to drop out of one of the competitions or take fewer members. This would be very painful for our team as a lot of time, energy, and money has been invested in this project and all that would be for nothing! :( So please help us in making our dream a reality! :)

Other Ways You Can Help

When we are not busy with the rover, we have been actively participating in public outreach projects such as Robots Rule and Go Eng Girl at the Ontario Science Center, Science Rendezvous at York University, weekly presentations to local high schools, and many more! We want to let the world know what is out there for students interested in science and engineering, to inspire, and to show youth of today what students are capable of with passion and a love for learning.

So besides donating money, you can also help by spreading the word about our team and help us inspire others:) "Like" us on facebook, follow us on twitter, visit our website, or tell a friend or two!

 

Thank you for taking the time to read up about us. We really appreciate your support!

 

-The York University Rover Team-

 

*All perks will be sent out after the two competitions. We'll also slip in a note about how we did;)
story_txt:
Our Story
We are the York University Rover Team (YURT), a group of enthusiastic York students from a wide range of disciplines all working towards a common goal: to build and develop a prototypical rover platform to compete in NASA's Lunabotics Mining Competition, Mars Society's University Rover Challenge (URC), and CSii's Robotics Competition. So what's a rover? Well, it's basically a robot that you send to outer space for exploration purposes. Cool, right?
Founded in 2007, this is our fifth year competing in the University Rover Challenge. We have made our mark at this competition by placing on the podium every year we've competed against other remarkable teams from around the world. At URC, the idea is to build a Mars rover that can one day work alongside human explorers in space. The rover has to complete a series of simulated tasks in the Utah desert such as delivering rescue packages to lost astronauts, fixing a broken equipment panel, finding signs of life and site surveying. On the other hand, this is our very first try at NASA's Lunabotics competition which focuses on building a Lunar rover capable of mining soil on the moon, and our second time at CSii's Robotics Competition which showcases young innovators of today. URC will be held May 31-June 2 at the Mars Desert Research Station, NASA's Lunabotics Competition will be held on May 21-26 at the Kennedy Space Centre, Florida; and CSii's Robotics Competition will be held July 9-10 at the Deerhurst Resort, Ontario.
We are a fully student-ran project and during the school year, our team dedicates countless time, effort, and sweat outside of the classroom into researching, building, and programming our rover in addition to fundraising and public outreach projects. Being part of the team provides us with a very unique hands-on experience unlike any other. It helps us appreciate more of what we learned at the university and even learn skills that are not taught in the classroom. Many of us who went on the trip to Utah last year agreed that it was definitely one of the best experiences of our lifetime and we hope to go again this year for a championship title at all three competitions!
So far, through the generous support of our university and the hard work of our team members, we have been able to build a competitive rover that's versatile enough for the three competitions. However, the biggest problem is: in order to travel from Toronto to Florida, then to Utah and back to Toronto again, it will cost us an estimated $15 000. So besides donating money, you can also help by spreading the word about our team and help us inspire others:) "Like" us on facebook, follow us on twitter, visit our website, or tell a friend or two!
 
Thank you for taking the time to read up about us. We really appreciate your support!
 
-The York University Rover Team-

story:
Summary

Hello everyone my name is Amanda Archibeque and I am a senior at Arizona State University. I will be graduating this coming May. I am Global Health major and I was recently accepted into a volunteer program this summer with HELP International in Thailand. The only problem I have is being able to fund to this once in a life time opportunity. My trip there I will be working in an orphanage, teaching English at a local school, working with sustainable farming projects for the hill tribe communities, and working in public health by raising awareness programs for HIV/AIDS. Throughout this experience I will also be working with other health concerns and with water filtration systems. 

This is important for me because I will be able to gain more experience internationally in my line of work. This will allow me to see another cultures point of view and to see what health disparities they are up against. Through this experience I hope to apply the things I will learn and gain with other locations internationally but also domestically.

Please help me by contributing to this great experience anything will help. Keep in mind this is not only helping me but this will be helping others around me because of my passion in improving ones community and helping others in need. Let me share my passion with others.

Fifteen weeks volunteer program is $3,750 

The program fee includes:

  • Housing
  • Breakfast and dinner during the week (Sunday dinner - Friday breakfast)
  • Health Insurance (comprehensive coverage for evacuaion and medical emergencies)
  • Trainings and handbooks
  • Safety and security in-country
  • Country Director(s)
  • Building partner relations
  • HELP t-shirt and other promotional material

The program fee does not include:

  • Flight
  • Passport
  • Visa
  • Tourist activities and souvenirs
  • Transportation to and from country
  • Immunizations
  • Extra food and eating out
  • THAILAND flights are between $1,600 and $2,200
If you are interested in looking into HELP International or IVHQ volunteer program you can go online to http://help-international.org/ and http://www.volunteerhq.org/

story:
The Open Building Institute (OBI)

Hello Indiegogo, my name is Marcin Jakubowski and I am a farmer and a scientist. Some of you may remember me from my 2011 Ted Talk where I expressed my frustration with my newly earned Ph.D. in fusion physics from Princeton University and its lack of relevance in solving real world issues. I also spoke about how shortly after my Ph.D. epiphany, I started a farm and set out to create a series of open source blueprints to create a civilization from scratch.

For those who don’t know me, I am the founder and director of Open Source Ecology (OSE), a non-profit organization dedicated to creating open source solutions for the advancement of humanity. We are also a creative lab and learning institute. By using open source protocols we have been developing The Global Village Construction Set  or (GVCS). GVCS is an open sourced hardware project that consists of the 50 machines required to build a civilization from the ground up. Machines that are a fraction of the cost of the major brand versions which are built to last for a lifetime of use unlike the models that have planned obsolescence incorporated in their design.   

We have been busy at OSE over the past 5 years since that Ted Talk and have made excellent progress with the GVCS. One of the things we have learned along the way is that we can create the maximum disruption and help the most amount of people if we applied our open source hardware tools and principles to housing. So we did, and we achieved amazing results in the process. So much so, that my wife, Catarina Mota started The Open Building Institute, which is an open source, sustainable and ecological approach towards home construction. 

In the last few years we have developed a high quality, robust, eco-friendly, sustainable, extremely affordable home that can be built just about anywhere in the world using locally sourced materials. Our current prototype is a 700 sq ft starter seed home with greenhouse which is modular by design and could be increased in size as the homeowners need for space or budget grows. 

The base cost of the home including materials and labor is around $35,000 (not including land). To put these figures in perspective, the national average cost for new construction is $125 per sq ft and our average construction cost comes in at well under half that at $50 per sq ft. 

Because our validation process was so successful with open source home construction, we are inviting the world to continue to help us further develop this exciting concept. Our goal is to improve upon our designs through trial and error – organize the information – and then make it available to the world as a free resource for anyone to use. 

Open Source Eco-Toolkit 

Our open source eco-building toolkit  is designed to make the construction of ecological housing easier, cheaper, faster, higher quality—and put it within the reach of everyone. 

The OBI toolkit is entirely open source—free to use and modify—and will enable anyone to:

  • Design a house and/or greenhouse—that respects the planet and can be expanded as your needs and family grow—using a library of modules that fit together like building blocks
  • Learn how to build with instructionals and training programs
  • Organize the rapid-build of a house loaded with ecological features

Through a series of experimental builds over the past few years, we learned that it is possible to construct a modular starter home—with an attached aquaponic greenhouse and loaded with ecological features—for under $25k in materials and in as little as 5 days.

We already have a lot of work in place, but there is much more to do. We are coming to you for help to further refine this toolkit and make it (more) accessible to everyone.

How it Works

The process in a nutshell:

1) We started by creating an open source library of modules—construction parts that can be put together like building blocks—along with guides for design, building and development. You can download a collection of walls, roofs, doors and windows and design a complete, buildable structure. Imagine having all the tools you need to design your own house and/or greenhouse easily and for free! You can also choose from a variety of house models contributed by designers around the world.

Just an example: a simple studio designed with OBI's modules library.

2) The modular system, combined with a formula for rapid builds, makes it possible for a large group of (mostly inexperienced) people to then build this house in as little as 5 days.


3) Builds can be executed by a contracted crew, a group of friends and relatives, or using a social production model. In this social production model, builds are structured as educational experiences and take place in the context of training workshops.

4) The library also includes designs and instructionals for a number of eco-features—from solar power, water catchment and compressed earth blocks to biogas, hydronic heating, and bio-insulation.

Aquaponic Greenhouse at the Factor E Farm in Maysville, Mo

Our attached aquaponic greenhouse provides passive solar heating and year-round food production.  Our greenhouse is quite unique and supports a diverse range of food sources, not just leafy vegetables.  It is also designed to produce super-foods such as spirulina, mushrooms, small fruit, and proteins like fish, chickens and eggs, which all tie into a unique symbiotic ecosystem. We have even integrated an ecological pest management system that serves many other purposes too. To learn more about our aquaponic greenhouse design and features click here.

The quality and durability of our homes is an area of focus as well. By using our compressed earth block construction our homes walls are 1 foot thick solid block which creates a high R value keeping heating and cooling costs down to a minimum. Our compressed earth blocks are also fire proof, insect resistant, mold proof, bullet proof , hurricane & tornado proof, sound resistant, and will stand for 1000 years if left uninterupted.  All the material needed to make the CEB  for construction is already on the property.  For more on the benefits of CEB construction  click here.

Compressed Earth Blocks at the Factor E Farm in Maysville, Mo
5) Given that not everyone wants to build their own house, we’re also developing a training program for builders—who will then be able to kick off their own enterprises providing construction services to those who don’t want to build themselves.

Early test home where Marcin and Catarina now live in Maysville

A Modular Building System

The library is entirely open source, which means that not only you can use it for free, but also that the designs themselves are contributed by volunteer designers. We’re also crowdsourcing building designs so you can have a wide variety of complete structures to choose from if you don’t want to design your own. 

Contributions by designers around the world also mean that the library will be capable of addressing a variety of location-specific requirements (such as climate, availability of materials, and cultural specificities). That’s why we love open source!

Cost

A 700 sq ft starter home costs approximately US$25k in materials. An expandable 225 sq ft home (what we call a seed home), loaded with ecological features, costs approximately $12k in materials, and each 225 square foot addition—with an additional 600 Watt of photovoltaics—costs about $5k in materials. This assumes materials are bought readily from a big box store.

This cost assumes a DIY build, but our build model—for taking this to a much larger audience beyond the 10% of owner builders—involves hiring a trained OBI builder who can organize a build party for a 5 day build of a 700 square foot home. We are expecting to develop and deliver a price structure such that turnkey service will cost the owner $10k on top of the materials cost. The labor is included in the apprentice training of people participating in the build.

Utilities & Appliances

A house is not just made of walls, roof and floor. It also needs power, water, sanitation, etc. That’s why we’re developing a collection of off-grid, sustainable utilities and appliances.

  Features included in the 2016 Starter Home build:

  • 3000W Photovoltaics for off-grid energy
  • Biogas Digester
  • Grid-Tie Inverter
  • Open Source Thermoelectric Generator
  • Super-efficient LED Lights (3W Each)
  • Super-efficient Refrigerator (8W average)
  • Pellet Burner for House and Water Heating
  • In-Floor Hydronic Heating
  • CEB Floor
  • 2 CEB Wall Modules
  • Modular Plumbing Fixtures
  • Modular Electric Panel
  • Passive Solar Design
  • Biofiber Insulation
  • Rainwater Collection
  • Super-efficient Shower Head
  • Water purification: sand, charcoal, ozonator
  • Separating Toilet
  • Greywater Garden

For a more complete description of these features, see Features Narrative.

Rapid Builds, Social Production

Through our building experiences—and based on OSE’s extreme manufacturing methodology—we developed a formula for rapid builds. It’s deceptively simple: a large group of people build a large number of modules, in parallel, and then assembles them rapidly into a building. Using these techniques, we were able to build—from raw materials—an entire 800 sq ft greenhouse in just 5 days.

This process can be replicated by a contracted crew or a group of family and friends. But, to date, our preferred method has been social production. In our particular application, this means that we use builds as training opportunities by treating the builds as immersion workshops. During these workshops, participants become familiar with the building system and acquire hands-on experience—while building a structure.

Revenue from workshop tuition helps offset the cost of building materials for the hosts. In turn, all workshop participants are encouraged to host their own build-workshops. Like the library, all workshop organization materials are open source and freely available—so everyone can replicate this model if they want to.

Who We Are

We are Marcin Jakubowski (founder of Open Source Ecology), Catarina Mota (founder of the Open Building Institute), and an amazing group of advisors and contributors—from world-renowned architects and scientists to business and organizational experts—who are committed to providing expertise on all areas of the project.

Catarina Mota is an open source advocate. She founded the Open Building Institute, co-founded Open Materials (do-it-yourself smart materials) and AltLab (Lisbon's hackerspace). Previously, she co-chaired the Open Hardware Summit 2012, served on the board of directors of the Open Source Hardware Association, taught as an adjunct faculty member at ITP-NYU, and was a fellow of the National Science and Technology Foundation of Portugal. Catarina holds a Ph.D. in communication sciences and her research work focuses on the social impact of open and collaborative practices for the development of technologies. She is a founding member of the Open Source Hardware Association and a TED Fellow.


Marcin Jakubowski is a Polish-American who came to the U.S. from Poland as a child. He graduated with honors from Princeton and earned his Ph.D. in fusion physics from the University of Wisconsin. Frustrated with the lack of relevance to pressing world issues in his education, he founded Open Source Ecology in 2003 in order to make closed-loop manufacturing a reality. He began development of the Global Village Construction Set (GVCS)—an open source tool set of 50 industrial machines necessary to create a small civilization with modern comforts. His work has recently been recognized as a 2012 TED Senior Fellow, in Time Magazine's Best Inventions of 2012, as a 2013 Shuttleworth Foundation Fellow, and a White House Champion of Change in 2013.

Why Housing?

We started Open Building Institute to address the issues surrounding housing for several reasons. Housing is a basic human need and is something that everyone can relate with because we all need a roof over our head. Housing costs also tend to make up a persons largest fiduciary responsibility. We wanted to apply open source methods and protocols to change this dynamic. Housing costs are only one of the issues we are trying to address with our initiative because there are other challenges depending on what part of the world we look at.

For people in less developed countries, there is a lack of access to technology, knowledge and resources required to build an affordable eco-friendly quality home. In addition to that, global population growth is exploding in these same countries causing billions of people to need shelter in the coming years and it's important that we approach this challenge in a smart sustainable way. 

For people in developed countries, owning a home is expensive, and requires most homeowners to encumber a life of debt, debt that is rarely ever paid off while living in home because interest payments are front loaded through the banks amortization schedules. This perpetual debt is like a a ball and chain that follow us through life and only serves to keep homeowners away from their home, (and family) busy at work trying to satisfy one of their largest monthly obligations which is their mortgage. It is our mission to offer high quality alternative solutions to this dilemma.

Why Food?

Another issue we wanted to address with our initiative was self sufficiency. Although we have addressed this in many ways with the homes numerous eco features, we felt that food production was such an important fundamental aspect of self sustainability that we needed to integrate food production into our modules. As with housing, food is a basic human need and makes up a significant portion of our yearly expenditures. Lack of access to healthy and nutritional food affects people in many different ways as well.

People in under-developed countries are frequently confronted with a daily battle of caloric intake, and in many cases, those are the lucky ones. There are over 700 million people in the world that suffer from undernourishment  and over 3 million children die every year due to poor nutrition. 

There are also millions of people in developed countries who have no other option but to eat cheap, processed, low nutrition food because they are  unable to afford quality food sources. This is one of the reasons we conduct our aquaponics workshops and have added this life sustaining component to our library of modules. Our aquaponic system can provide enough vegetables and protein to feed a family of six year round.  

A New Paradigm Is Within Reach

Imagine a life with little to no mortgage payments. utility costs or food bills. The average person spends almost 60% of their income on those three items alone. What if you could cut those numbers in half? What would you do with your time if you didn't have to spend it all working to keep these exorbitant costs satisfied every month? Or what would you do with the savings? This is not some far off pipe dream but a real possibility – right now. More people are coming to the realization that time is their most valuable asset and although we have an abundance of technology, is it really being properly utilized to create a better quality of life for us? One could argue that the introduction of more technology has only complicated our lives. Our housing initiative was created to be directly applied towards creating a better quality of life. We want to offer a way for people to have more time to do what they want to. Simply put, our model is designed to circumvent traditional housings constraining ways and provide a new housing paradigm (and lifestyle) for all who want it.  

How It Began

For several years now, Open Source Ecology (OSE) has been working on the Global Village Construction Set—a set of 50 industrial machines for building civilization from scratch. A lot has happened since OSE's successful Kickstarter in 2011. More recently, OSE established a partnership with a new open source project—the Open Building Institute (OBI)—to apply its GVCS machines to modular housing. The goal of this partnership is to make ecological housing accessible to everyone.

The project began when we—Marcin and Catarina—got married and realized our Missouri farmhouse was too small for two people. We had a very specific idea of what we wanted our home to be: comfortable and affordable, rapidly built from local materials, expandable (so we can add new rooms as the need arises), off-grid, and capable of generating its own energy and food.

We realized that this house didn’t exist yet—so we set out to design and build it ourselves. The process began in late 2013 with a microhouse—a 144 sq ft tiny house. To this we then added a bedroom, a mud room, a porch, a library/work space, an office, another bathroom, a utility room, and an aquaponic greenhouse. Together, these structures form a 2100 sq ft living and working space at Factor e Farm (Missouri, USA).

Throughout this process, and after much trial and error, we arrived at formula that makes building a house easier, faster and cheaper. On our latest build—an aquaponic greenhouse—a team of 35 (mostly inexperienced) participants built an entire 800 sq ft greenhouse from raw materials—in 5 days—for $6,000 in materials. This build included not only the structure itself, but also two 1500 gallons fish ponds, 1 chicken coop, 85 aquaponic towers, 2 compost grow beds, 6 mushroom grow towers, 1 aquatic worm system, 1 BSF breeding system, and 3 hydronic radiators.

We realized that this approach—a combination of modular designs with rapid build techniques, social production, local materials, and open source machines—has the potential to make eco-house building widely accessible. But it was not easy. We have to make it easier. That’s what this campaign is about: turning our experiment into something everyone else can benefit from and participate in.

Training

We recognize that not everybody wants to build their own house. To address that, we’re creating an intensive training program—so you have an option to hire an OBI builder, if you want. 

This program will be a real deep dive into construction: from design and materials production to rapid-build organization and business—including building the construction machines themselves, which we can do in a single day.

Upon completion of the program, these trainees are expected to start their own building enterprises to provide building services to those who don’t want to build themselves.

The goal is to not only help train a growing number of open source, regenerative builders, but also to encourage entrepreneurship and seed the replication of many similar facilities worldwide. Like everything else in this project, all training materials are open source. Everyone is free—in fact, encouraged—to use those materials to launch their own training program and enterprise.

The initial training program is set to launch in 2017 with 2 to 4 trainees. And then double this number annually until we reach an enrollment of 24 students—from which point we intend to scale operations to other locations.

We need your help to spread our initiative to the broader world. We are seeking builders for collaboration and participation in our initiative. 

Materials Production

And it gets even better. Imagine being able to source most of your building materials from 50 miles around your build site. This is exactly what we’re aiming for with a solar-powered Materials Production Facility capable of producing compressed earth blocks, lumber, insulation, paint, glazing, and lime concrete—from local soil, limestone, hay and trees—using open source machines.

This facility will be open to the public, so that anyone who is interested in using local building materials has an option to produce their own materials. In our usual fashion of re-skilling and educating, we will provide people with both theoretical training and practice. This allows people to provide sweat equity in producing their own building materials, while gaining an appreciation of nature through the stewardship of natural resources. We will also provide turnkey materials for those who do not have the time or interest in sweat equity.

The Materials Facility highlights include:

  • 20kW of solar electricity powers the brick press, sawmill, mixers, lime burner, hammermill, 3D printer, and pelletizer.
  • Stabilized CEB block production—which has about 8x less embodied energy than fired brick.
  • Lumber production, with byproducts of sawdust and wood pellets.
  • Production of pelletized biochar from pellets to produce soil amendment and machine fuel (with gasifier engines), while co-generating burned lime in the process.
  • Large format 3D printer for producing multi-wall polycarbonate greenhouse glazing from scrap plastic.
  • Burning of lime to make carbon-neutral concrete from local limestone.
  • Production of bio-fiber insulation from recycled newspaper and biomass feedstocks.
  • Production of heating and feed pellets from biomass feedstocks.

Our unique approach is that of ecology—combining as many features into a whole as possible—to arrive at harmonious existence of humans and nature.

The initial operation of this facility is scheduled for late 2017 with further expansion planned for 2018. The goal is to provide detailed open source documentation for all aspects of this facility (all the machines, building, layout and processes) so it can be replicated and adapted all over the world—make local building materials available everywhere.

Challenges + Collaborative Development

By now, you’re probably thinking “These people are crazy! How are they going to do all this?” Well, we have a secret sauce: it’s called open source. It simply wouldn't be possible for our little core team to undertake this project without any additional help. But we’re not alone. Just like Linux is developed by thousands of programmers around the world, we believe we can all get together to fix housing.

All the work we did in the past years—both on machinery and housing—has relied heavily on hundreds of contributions from advisors and volunteers who believe, like we do, that we should join efforts to make things better for everyone. And now we’re taking this collaborative approach to the next level. One of the core goals of this Kickstarter is to develop a common platform for submitting new designs and improvements to the system. We will host Design Challenges as well.

That’s why we’re inviting everyone to join this common platform by submitting new designs and improvements to the system. In addition to a standing-invitation to contribute to the library, we’re also hosting design contests—starting with a callout to design the 700 sq ft expandable home that we’ll build at our headquarters this November.

Given the scope of the project, we’re also gathering an amazing group of advisors—from world-renowned architects and high-tech engineers to business and organizational experts—who have committed to providing expertise on all areas of the project. Check out our Advisory Team.

Building Codes and Regulations 

Compliance with regulations is one of the requirements of the project, just as it is for any standard house. That’s why we’re working with experienced architects to: 1) ensure that all our modules comply with the International Building Code; and 2) produce sufficient documentation (calculations, plans, construction details drawings, design rationale, etc.) to enable builders to apply for the necessary permits in their area of residence. We also intend to have each module design stamped by a licensed engineer, as well as provide several complete house models with all regulatory aspects worked out in detail. To get there, we are recruiting an army of advisors on all the technical details—one of them being compliance, and other being real estate law - to help people navigate legal hurdles surrounding land acquisition and tenure. 

Further, since code compliance is a complicated and scary issue for most people, we are preparing a special webinar on Code Compliance. The key to successful code negotiation starts with a first-principles literacy of general concepts, and then moves to specific quantitative requirements. Codes are our friends if we understand them—and as such, our goal for this Webinar is to foster basic Building Code Literacy—so that seemingly inane regulations are converted into a human understandable form. 

Given that regulations and procedures vary from region to region, we will also crowd-source a database of regulation-related documents that can support the construction of select OBI house models in many different areas around the world. 

The autonomous and modular nature of the system also allows for a large level of flexibility towards meeting codes: 

  • Because our system is modular, it is highly flexible in the implementation that it can take. For example: “So, the separating toilet with biodigester doesn’t meet code?” The solution is simple: we swap out the toilet module, which is designed as a swappable platform, and replace it with a regular one. Or, the flattish roof does not meet snow load requirements in Northern Canada? Ok, we add another roof module (which is stackable like a sandwich), and we have now doubled snow load capacity. And so on. 
  • This modularity applies to parts of modules as well: if some part is inadequate—such as a structural member not being strong enough—we can replace it with one that is. The system allows this in general. 
  • Modularity applies clearly to wall sections, which are typically 4x8 panels. These may be CEB and weigh over one ton, or standard stick framing and weigh 100 lb. You can stack these in multiples—or you can modify the materials used to scale their thickness. You can make larger wall cavities for insulation to meet the requirements of northern climates. You can substitute the materials and, for example, build panels out of bamboo, strawboard, or hempcrete. 
  • The modularity of the OBI system also allows for full control over room and house dimensions—to meet size, ceiling height, or any other constraints related to geometry. House too small to meet zoning minimums? Add a module and the house now meets this part of the regulations. House too large to meet code? Downsize by removing a number of modules. 
  • Off-grid design provides great flexibility. As long as you are not connected to water, electricity, or gas—essentially by living in an autonomous house—many options open up as far as where you can build or stay. In some places, code jurisdiction works on the basis of, for example, “Sewer system requirements” or “electrical hookup requirements.” If you are not hooked up to a sewer or electricity, the rules may not apply to you. 
  • For multiple house developments, special use cases may be obtained as Planned Unit Developments. Variances to ordinances may also be sought. 
  • You don’t like regulations at all? You can build a structure that is small enough to escape code jurisdiction all together. Or, in later phases of the project (2018 and later), when we design mobile structures, put the house on wheels and you are no longer under housing code jurisdiction, but vehicle code jurisdiction. 
  • Can’t afford the size required to meet zoning regulations? Build a shell structure, like Alejandro Aravena’s incremental housing and add to it as resources allow. Really, really hate dealing with regulatory institutions? You may be glad to know that there are no building regulations—not even a building department—in parts of Missouri (US) and Chad, etc. 

Simply put: the system modularity allows immediate substitution of different parts to address compliance, making the regulations issue no different than for any other type of more standard house. And, due to the flexibility of modular construction, you as the builder have a great amount of code negotiating power. 

Land Access 

We have learned that while codes may be negotiated, there’s only a finite supply of land. In the USA, the situation is good as land is widely available —with farmland going for $2-8k per acre, and building lots as low as $10k in many cities. In Europe and elsewhere, farmland is $2-25k per acre. In India, prices are exploding. The question of land tenure, and the unequal access to land and resources is beyond the scope of this project. However, our work aims to increase individuals’ ability to convert abundant natural resources into lifestuff that frees people from material constraints—our fundamental formula for freedom. We believe that only by balancing human activity with regenerative resource use can prosperity happen for all—hence our quest for regenerative housing integrated with natural life support systems. 

Current State, Funding, and Roadmap 

  • The current state of the project is:
    We have built a number of modular home prototypes and additions between 2013-2015 - as well as the 800 square foot aquaponic greenhouse. We are testing these now. 
  • In 2016, we will build building an expandable, replicable Starter Home with an aquaponic greenhouse addition - based on learnings from the 2013-2015 builds. This design is not done. 
  • House and other building designs will be crowdsourced via Design Challenges - to be launched after this Kickstarter campaign achieves its funding goal. The design work involves: (1) working out some module interface details, (2) designing new utility/appliance modules, and (3) designing the overall composition of the house. 

This Indiegogo campaign will fund the necessary steps to make our building system widely replicable: 

  • Further development of all the system components, so that each is a fully engineered and documented module - usable in any model of a Starter Home. The goal by July 2018 is to develop all the modules necessary to build a Living Building Challenge compliant home, at a reasonable cost. 
  • Next iteration build and testing of the Starter Home with aquaponic greenhouse. Our next build is November, 2016. 
  • Creation of an immersion training program for builders. 
  • Development of open source enterprise curriculum for designing and building modular housing as a service, including how to produce local materials using open source machines. 
  • Development of a robust crowd design platform for submitting new designs and developments to the building system. 
  • Build of the solar powered materials production facility—so that most of the house building materials can be sourced from within 50 miles of the build site. This facility will be open to the public for production and training. 

Note that these funds do not cover the various supporting machines for construction and materials production - nor does it cover numerous other structure builds that are in our timeline below but not in the funding scope above. These will be funded by proceeds from our immersion workshops - a funding model that we have used to fund various machine builds for the last 2 years.

Risks and challenges

While the development is high risk in general because of the level of innovation, the rewards have been selected first and foremost based on things that we can deliver.

Making things is hard. We realize that.

We've spent the past years developing the technology and process for building things rapidly and efficiently. We have established a network of advisors - where we have learned that subject matter experts are the strongest point of an open development process. Such expertise allows us to download information in hours - which would otherwise take months or years to develop. So while we have ambitious goals on the product level - none of the technology we are putting into practice is new. The challenge revolves around the rapid learning and integration that is required - which is a question of operations and management.

We understand the huge difference between vision and execution. We have world class business advisors on our team - as we know that the difference between an idea and global impact is that of enterprise development. All of our work relies on business innovation using inovative social production processes - so naturally, there is a tremendous amount of risk involved

At the same time, we have been building heavy machines on a day timescale, and building structures on 5 day time scales. We are well versed in Extreme Manufacturing - and the next challenge is whether we can teach others how to do the same. We know that we can build crazy things on rapid timescales - but the question of impact means (1) how effectively we can teach; and (2) how quickly we attain and exceed industry standard metrics of quality.

Our training program will be a crash course indeed. Curriculum development and a pilot training program are a way to learn what parts of our training program work. We will accept 2-4 students in 2017, and we aim to double our enrollment yearly until we reach 24 students. This means that access to a turnkey OBI building service - relies on the success of our teaching program - as otherwise the barriers to entry appear too high.

We have work to do on the quality aspect - which is the core of the technical development that we are seeking to fund. We have already shown that average people can participate in complex builds - without needing trade skills. We have also been developing quality control protocols - starting with design-for-manufacturing - and standards quality control checklists throughout the build process.

Because this work is an integration of features not found in any other single project - we live at the bleeding edge of integration - which has inherent risks. While it is commonly understood that you can have only two of the three product features: quality, cost, and speed - we are challenging this assumption. We are breaking through the quality barrier by tapping top subject matter expertise, incentivized as a contribution to the common good.

Modular Design: The challenge of any modular system is interface design - and we respect this point. We have had several years of experience in building modular machines, and are now applying the same principles to modular housing. The interface details in the current system need work, as they are difficult: we are breaking large builds into small parts - thereby introducing a number of interfaces that need to be sealed. Our insight on this point is careful navigation of Depth of Modularity. This means that if a certain interface does not work, we make specialized parts - or move the modularity either up or down in the design hierarchy. We have learned to be flexible with interfaces - or if an interface does not work well - we are comfortable getting rid of that interface or otherwise changing. Our result is a hybrid and flexible system - where we are not afraid to eliminate modularity when it simply does not work. At the same time, we have build modular electrical and plumbing sections - and we think that we have only scratched the surface of what is possible.

Development Time and Scope: We have promised ambitious products over an ambitious 2 year time scale, and a major risk is the mere scope of the technologies. While all of the technologies are proven, our innovation is the opensourcing or publishing of the technologies to make them accessible at cost - sidestepping the cost of expensive expertise. The Starter Home that we will build in November, 2016 - contains a large number of proven technological features - which we are promising at breakthrough cost - by publishing the technical expertise required to accomplish the build of - availing otherwise expensive expertise for free to the world. So far we have been quite successful in attracting the necessary subject matter experts to provide the supporting technical information. The key to success is finding several more experts who are willing to share cutting edge know-how. The time of 4 months from the start of the campaign to the first build - is short, though we have a large base of prior modular build experience that we are building upon. And 15 months to the more ambitious Living Building Challenge build - and the 1 year time scale to the Materials Production Facility -means that we are compressing the documentation of just about all human knowledge related to construction - into making it fully accessible in 2 years. That is extremely ambitious - but the idea is that a proper world-class expert can bring us up to speed to the most cutting edge practice in a matter of months.
