story:
OSEP at a glance

OSEP (Open Source Education Project) is a project created and maintained by thedigitalcraft.com.

The Digital Craft:

The Digital Craft (TDC) is an organization that produces free computer and web technology learning series.

OSEP:

OSEP was created to allow individuals to not only educate themselves by watching video series hosted on (TDC/YouTube) but learn how to build a professional level product by the end of each OSEP series.

Because our viewers (many of which call themselves our students) are building these projects along with us, from the ground up - they will have the knowledge it takes to enhance, and modify the product once they complete the series. 

The Goal:

The overall goal of each OSEP project is to grow a community of web programmers and designers who can feel like they had a part in creating something "real" (because they did!). 

Some Strategy Never Hurts:

Our strategy comes from watching how other organizations build, host, and maintain their open source products. Many of the other open source orgs out there have to build a product and then promote it in order to attempt to gain a community that will receive the product, need it, and have the willingness to take the time to learn how the product was built and how it works. Only then can the orgs development community grow.

Our attempt is to eliminate the waiting and hoping period from the equation. We already have the (ever growing) community that wants to learn a new skill (or hone an old one). So we launch the product with a support base of all the viewers who have followed along with the series in which we build the product from the ground up.

Now, we cannot be pompous enough to think that we can pick any type of product, create a video series and build a loyal community to help support it. Nor do we want to. To the contrary, we have chosen this first OSEP product from the overwhelming request we have had from viewers (publically and privately) to teach them how to build a CMS. In fact, this is where the idea for OSEP was born.

 

As with this first product, the future products will be chosen based off input from our viewers.

Why do you need funding and who all is involved in this org?

The Digital Craft, OSEP, and the ideas have all been the original work of myself, Alan Quandt. I have been a graphic designer, web designer, web developer (lead), and even had a stint directing a network late night comedy show. I have been doing all this (and more) for almost 17 years (12 professionally). 

Why give up the big bucks in order to become a fulltime educator?

I have always wanted to be an educator. However. I paid (or am still paying) enough for my current education that I wont be signing up for a teaching degree anytime soon! So during a lull in freelance work, I started videos for what would soon become The Digital Craft. TDC has a history all its own (can be read on our website). However the videos fit right in on the website and I kept on producing video after video until the "lull" ended. I then continued to make videos whenever I had free time.

Fast forward to now. I have a ton of loyal subscribers/viewers and more than a ton of views. In fact, at the moment of writing this we have close to 3500 subscribers and over 716,000 views.

I am at a turning point in my career. I have seen the popularity of TDC and overall acclaim from our viewers grow beyond my expectations over the last several months. I have a choice to

  1. Continue freelance work and do TDC videos on the side
  2. Stop freelance work and join another development firm
  3. Take this once in a lifetime opportunity to do something awesome and follow my actual dream... aka: Manage the TDC and OSEP fulltime

I have chosen option 3. 

However I am a husband and father to 3 young girls in elementary school. I still have a responsibility to put a roof over their heads and food on our table. I have been generating some income from advertising via Google ads on the YouTube videos and thedigitalcraft.com. At this point however, that is only generating enough to pick up a month's worth of groceries.

So we need funding until I have enough content and viewers in order to build income through advertising, affiliate programs, and other opportunities that will allow me to keep the videos and project free. At which time I will hault the fundraising until its needed again.

The video above is explaining the first project that we are attempting with OSEP. The funding amount is enough to keep me working on the site for several months and keep current with my own research and tools needed to produce the videos. 

I will admit, this is the first (well unofficially the 2nd) of many future fund raising attempts. We will need to keep funding the project until other means make up for the loss of income I will incur. We will also need to bring on more industry professionals who are willing to devote their efforts fulltime to continue to expand our reach and topics.

Every donation counts! $5- $500 it is about the numbers of people who support the cause.

Thank you, sincerely,

Alan Quandt

Project Founder and Instructor
story_txt:
OSEP at a glance
OSEP (Open Source Education Project) is a project created and maintained by thedigitalcraft.com.
The Digital Craft:
The Digital Craft (TDC) is an organization that produces free computer and web technology learning series.
OSEP:
OSEP was created to allow individuals to not only educate themselves by watching video series hosted on (TDC/YouTube) but learn how to build a professional level product by the end of each OSEP series.
Because our viewers (many of which call themselves our students) are building these projects along with us, from the ground up - they will have the knowledge it takes to enhance, and modify the product once they complete the series. 
The Goal:
The overall goal of each OSEP project is to grow a community of web programmers and designers who can feel like they had a part in creating something "real" (because they did!). 
Some Strategy Never Hurts:
Our strategy comes from watching how other organizations build, host, and maintain their open source products. Many of the other open source orgs out there have to build a product and then promote it in order to attempt to gain a community that will receive the product, need it, and have the willingness to take the time to learn how the product was built and how it works. Only then can the orgs development community grow.
Our attempt is to eliminate the waiting and hoping period from the equation. We already have the (ever growing) community that wants to learn a new skill (or hone an old one). So we launch the product with a support base of all the viewers who have followed along with the series in which we build the product from the ground up.
Now, we cannot be pompous enough to think that we can pick any type of product, create a video series and build a loyal community to help support it. Nor do we want to. To the contrary, we have chosen this first OSEP product from the overwhelming request we have had from viewers (publically and privately) to teach them how to build a CMS. In fact, this is where the idea for OSEP was born.
 
As with this first product, the future products will be chosen based off input from our viewers.
Why do you need funding and who all is involved in this org?
The Digital Craft, OSEP, and the ideas have all been the original work of myself, Alan Quandt. I have been a graphic designer, web designer, web developer (lead), and even had a stint directing a network late night comedy show. I have been doing all this (and more) for almost 17 years (12 professionally). 
Why give up the big bucks in order to become a fulltime educator?
I have always wanted to be an educator. However. I paid (or am still paying) enough for my current education that I wont be signing up for a teaching degree anytime soon! So during a lull in freelance work, I started videos for what would soon become The Digital Craft. TDC has a history all its own (can be read on our website). However the videos fit right in on the website and I kept on producing video after video until the "lull" ended. I then continued to make videos whenever I had free time.
Fast forward to now. I have a ton of loyal subscribers/viewers and more than a ton of views. In fact, at the moment of writing this we have close to 3500 subscribers and over 716,000 views.
I am at a turning point in my career. I have seen the popularity of TDC and overall acclaim from our viewers grow beyond my expectations over the last several months. I have a choice to

Continue freelance work and do TDC videos on the side
Stop freelance work and join another development firm
Take this once in a lifetime opportunity to do something awesome and follow my actual dream... aka: Manage the TDC and OSEP fulltime

I have chosen option 3. 
However I am a husband and father to 3 young girls in elementary school. I still have a responsibility to put a roof over their heads and food on our table. I have been generating some income from advertising via Google ads on the YouTube videos and thedigitalcraft.com. At this point however, that is only generating enough to pick up a month's worth of groceries.
So we need funding until I have enough content and viewers in order to build income through advertising, affiliate programs, and other opportunities that will allow me to keep the videos and project free. At which time I will hault the fundraising until its needed again.
The video above is explaining the first project that we are attempting with OSEP. The funding amount is enough to keep me working on the site for several months and keep current with my own research and tools needed to produce the videos. 
I will admit, this is the first (well unofficially the 2nd) of many future fund raising attempts. We will need to keep funding the project until other means make up for the loss of income I will incur. We will also need to bring on more industry professionals who are willing to devote their efforts fulltime to continue to expand our reach and topics.
Every donation counts! $5- $500 it is about the numbers of people who support the cause.
Thank you, sincerely,
Alan Quandt
Project Founder and Instructor

story:
Social change must be sustainable. It must create its own momentum to continue indefinitely once it is put into motion. The end goal should be to empower individuals to educate themselves.

By building upon the unique skills of the individual members of the community, the community is shaped and fortified, thereby generating further aptitudes and resources.

Thousands of Nicaraguans have thus been mentored through the establishment of the Learning Centers. With each center being coordinated by local women, they are able to cater to the individual needs of each learning center's community.


"Lifting up through Learning"

A goal of the Learning Centers is to help people help themselves. Nicaraguan people receive training to provide direct support to themselves, their families, and their communities. Community education is more than the act of teaching people practice skills. It is a process of bringing citizens together to solve local problems. No development project can be successful without active involvement of citizens shaping their future.

At Wisconsin/Nicaragua Partners of the Americas (WNP), volunteers have developed and coordinated a network of thriving at the Learning Centers. There are currently over 100 established Learning Centers throughout Nicaragua. Each Learning center is autonomous with organization and management by the people and their communities. Current Learning Center activities include sewing, handcrafts, jewelry, baking, gardening, lending libraries, and much more.

Although these Centers are established, students need supplies and teachers need to be paid. With each year, more Centers are established and more students want to learn. Supplies are in great need. All proceeds generated in this campaign will go towards running and funding the Learning Centers.

Perks

$5 - Thanks

Any contribution will help support a Learning Center in Nicaragua.

All donations are welcome and any way of spreading awareness will greatly help.

Wisconsin/Nicaragua Partners of the Americas is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization. Cash and in-kind donations are fully tax-deductible to the extend allowed by the law.

$10 - Jewelry

Unique hand-crafted jewelry made by Nicaraguans

Women and families who visit a Learning Center learn many different skills, such as jewelry-making. By teaching people these skills, they can make a living by selling their crafts. Each piece is differnt and varies in shapes, colors, and sizes.

$25 - Coffee

Colectivo Coffee, Nicaraguan fair-trade coffee

Starting your day with a delicious cup of Nicaraguan coffee not only makes your day, but helps out the farmers who work hard making a dignified living selling their coffee. In Esteli, coffee is grown by 2,300 small farmers with 30% of them women.

If you don't drink coffee, Nicaraguan fair-trade coffee is a great gift for coffee-drinking friends!

To find out more about Colectivo Coffee, visit their website at http://colectivocoffee.com/

$100 - Baskets

Pine needle baskets created by Nicaraguan women

These baskets are created from the hands of indigenous Nicaraguan women in the northern region of Nicaragua, Cusmapa. Cusmapa's landscape is filled with pine trees. A traditional art from in the northern Atlantic Coast of the country has always been basket weaving using the long pine needles gathered from the forest floor.

This craft allows these women to reduce the poverty in their municipality through sustainable employment.

$200 - Wooden Bowl

Hand-crafted wooden bowls created by Nicaraguans

$300 - Black Ceramics

Black ceramics hand-crafted by Nicaraguans

Students in the Learning Centers are learning how to work with clay by hand, making every single piece without a spinning pottery and manual tools. The most challenging part of creating black ceramics is during the firing process to turn the clay black. The pieces that survive are beautiful works of art.

$500 - All of the above

With a donation of $500, you'll receive each gift as a thanks for your generous donation.

Other Ways You can Help

Spread Awareness

Tell your friends of our fundraiser! The campaign will end on April 2, 2014.

Link with us through social media! Like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter.

Visit our website to learn about more programs Wisconsin/Nicaragua Partners have to offer. http://www.wisnic.org/

Click here for the direct link on the Learning Centers!

Material Donations

If you have any material donations you would like to send to Nicaragua, shipments go out often! Click here for details.

Wisconsin/Nicaragua Partners of the Americas is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization. Cash and in-kind donations are fully tax-deductible to the extend allowed by the law.

story:
Currently there is NO effective way to get live streaming scores for High School sporting events. The only way it's done today is via someone at the game calling, texting, Tweeting or updating Facebook.  Obviously, those are terribly inefficient methods and don't always provide the most accurate results.  Its kind of like watching the big game on TV and every 15 seconds your feed cuts out for 5 or even 10 minutes at a time. As you can imagine that can be very frustrating if you are a fan, but even moreso if you are a parent and who couldn't make it to the game.  

That's where ScoreBird "swoops" in to save the day!  This is the first live feed technology that delivers a streaming scoreboard to fans.  You might be wondering how can we do this.  Well, we literally took the score from the most obvious place…the Scoreboard! Our proprietary method provides the ability to take live feeds directly from the scoreboard for any game…for any sport…at any time. This feed travels directly to our free mobile application (iPhone or Android) with all the scores from participating schools. This allows fans and family to see scores from anywhere at any time.

                                          

                                        

                                         


So we fixed the "streaming" issue, what else can we do to advance high school athletics?  Did you know that there is a rapidly growing problem affecting high school sports programs.   According to up2us.org, $3.5 billion has been cut from public school athletic budgets over the past few years all across the country.  “Pay-to-play” as a practice is surging in recent years and as of 2010, most schools charge fees to play their respective sport. Forbes.com states that there has been speculation that by the end of this decade nearly 1 in 3 public high schools will have no interscholastic sports programs to speak of. These teams have to rely on the parents, players and boosters to raise the money needed for critical things such as uniforms, equipment, field maintenance and even travel costs. The players and boosters are out knocking on doors selling everything from candy bars to pizza kits. Even, with these efforts, it barely makes a dent. 

We can’t idly sit back and watch this happen. Sports programs help to develop a healthy competitive spirit in our future leaders and keep many kids off the streets and involved in something productive. Because of the tight budget constraints, ScoreBird is going to provide this technology to the schools, absolutely free, no fees, no cost at all.  On top of that, we are going to help the athletic departments at these schools by empowering them to generate an additional form of revenue.  Revenue from advertising!  As part of our agreements we’ll transition these booster selling candy bars and pizza kits door to door, which might make them a few hundred dollars, to selling internet ad space to their local businesses and make thousands!  Half of that revenue will go towards funding their high school sports program. Also, ScoreBird plans to donate 1/3 of any national advertising, which we sell, back to the participating schools. 

       

                                      




We plan to change everything for High School Sports!  Our goals are to increase exposure and fan engagement via the app and grow these programs via the booster revenue stream.  Be in the Game with ScoreBird!

story:
A note from Ron Seivertson.


" Human sincerity is impossible to disguise" (c) Ron Seivertson 2014

I would like to sincerely thank everyone who has participated in this campaign, especially the funders.  You have stated to the world that you believe in this vision we have for Horizon and that you are firm believers and supporters in our ability to create the school, no matter what it takes.

The team that came together of their own accord and circumstance are indeed some of the most giving and loving persons I have met in my entire life. 

This was not my idea nor did i have the capacity to conceive that a crowd fund was even possible for us.  Mr Lars Flikkeid. Is the architect of not only this campaign, but also our new website and the website of Tiari's Treasures.

Without Lars very simply this campaign would not exist.  I asked no one to join the team yet they arrived one by one expressing interest and asking how they could help.   


During this discovery, this learning experience  about community funding, we have all learned a great deal more about each other and the world at large.  Everyone has been  so gracious with their time, sincerity and energy and I am forever grateful.

Thank You,

Ron Seivertson  Aug. 8th 2014 7:43 PM


Counting Down with 50% Discounted Perks!

Only a few days left and believe it or not, your contributions do make a difference even if we don't reach our goal. We'll continue to raise money for the school even after the campaign is over so keep your contributions coming. We've decided to offer 50% off on all our perks too, so just contribute with no perk selected, then write a comment and let us know what perk you want.

We'll take care of the rest! Thanks again for your support!


Introduction

This crowd funding campaign is about updating tools, equipment, and facilities so that students can learn the art of Glassblowing in Bali, Indonesia with International World-Renowned Master Glass Artists.


Milestones

All funds if we don’t reach our goal will go towards tools and equipment necessary for teaching the art of hot glass in a more limited capacity. 

We need many things, big and small, to help make the Horizon facility functional for our students. 

We appreciate your generosity and the goal does not have to be fully met for your money to be effective.  Here are our milestones of where your money goes:

$5,000 - Finish our shop floor and finish 1 bathroom for our students.

$10,000 – Build 1 glory Hole. Our aim is to buy recuperating glory holes for maximum life and fuel efficiency. These are very expensive and must be imported. But we can build our own standard glory holes for less. 

$20,000 – Build 2 glory holes, two benches and buy new pipes and hand tools.

$50,000 – Build a new furnace.

$75,000 – Build a new annealer and convert our others to electricity. 

$100,000 – Will give us enough to buy a larger electric furnace and convert the whole shop to electricity which will be more energy efficient. Right now we operate on bottled gas. 

$125,000 - We can buy a backup generator and build our cold working shop. 

$150,000 – We can fully fit out the hot shop, build our metal working shop, finish our shop office, second bathroom and buy enough tools to serve 12 students. 


Campaign Summary

At Horizon Glassworks we are developing an International Glass Art School that has the ability to dramatically affect the lives of artistic individuals both locally and worldwide. Southeast Asia, and more specifically, Ubud Bali, is the perfect place for Horizon’s learning facility. Horizon Glassworks is now becoming a community of creative energy for glass artists.  

This campaign is about developing part of Horizon Glassworks into a teaching facility that is dedicated to teaching students from all walks of life, ages, and life styles the world over who seek new and exciting ways to express their creative and artistic passion and talents. The skills, lessons, and sense of community learned here will carry on for generations to come.

We have instructors from all over the world that are waiting to come teach, and we’ve got students wanting to learn.

Located in Bali, on the 'Island of the Gods,' we are developing this glass art community in preparation for a glass art movement to be born in Indonesia and throughout South East Asia. 


What We Need

Ron and his wife Indah have spent just about every penny they have securing the property and building the facility where Horizon Glassworks currently resides. It’s a huge operation with over a dozen full time staff, 4,000 square meters of property, and 4 buildings - all in pursuit of the dream to build this into a World Class International Glass Art School. 

Ron and Indah will continue to operate the facility with or without the school. However, they simply can’t afford to complete the necessary upgrades and improvements to the facility in the capacity required for teaching without your help. Please support us, contribute to our campaign, and help turn this dream into reality...  

 



Overfunding

If we are overfunded, we will create a scholarship fund for underprivileged persons to attend. We will also continue to upgrade our facilities to high efficiency recuperating systems and equipment to reduce overall operating costs.  

We will also add a program to teach others how to build and operate a fully functional studio of their own to work with hot glass and other glass art forms. This will help promote glass art and begin to stimulate a glass art society and collector's movement throughout Southeast Asia. 

It is a devotion of ours to develop this program to help less fortunate creative and artistic individuals become self sufficient by opening their own hot glass art studio. With your help, we can make a huge difference in the lives of countless people, and continue the modern age of glass art. 


What You Get In Return

Besides helping to make a huge difference for thousands of people, we have implemented an exciting and generous lottery program for those who donate $50 or more to our campaign. We have hand selected 50 pieces of beautiful pieces of various styles from figurines to vases, bowls, platters, paperweights and the like. If we reach our goal, 50 recipients will be drawn at random to receive one of these collectable pieces in appreciation of your support.

We also have perks that include your name engraved in stone in our courtyard, and even a perk where one of the studios is dedicated to you with your name proudly displayed at the entrance along with the name of the studio - i.e. The John Q. Smith HOT SHOP. Teachers, students, and visitors will all recognize your support for years to come. 

Alternatively, Ron will be creating beautiful custom one-off pieces of art for those individuals who donate at the $1,000 level. These will be highly collectable pieces and are available on a very limited basis. 

Here are some of our Other Perk Highlights:

Pendant Necklace: $50 Level


Name Engraved in Stone: $100 Level

This is very special to us as we want our entire courtyard filled with the names of our valuable supporters and where they are from -  a constant reminder of who made this International Glass Art School happen - YOU! The Horizon Glass Property is surrounded by Balinese Stone Carvers making this perk an incredible value. Please come join us, our community, and other supporters...

 


The Impact You Can Help Make

We foresee the style and message of the local’s work reflecting their rich history and tradition with beautiful glass art pieces. 

As we develop international visitors and local individuals in the art of hot glass, we are creating a cross cultural and cross generational exchange. Your contribution can make a huge difference not only in their lives, but the lives of future generations - elder artisans here traditionally pass art skills to their children. We truly have the ability to bring a new form of expressive creativity to people here and around the globe who would otherwise never have the opportunity to experience the wonders of glass art. The result is beautiful pieces of glass art that give people the purpose and resources to support themselves and future generations. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Are you fascinated by glass art? If you can’t contribute, please pass this on to someone who can by posting us up on your social media network or simply telling friends and family who might want to help about this campaign. You can use the Indiegogo share tools for your convenience. We appreciate every contribution, large or small.

If you are planning a trip to Bali, please stop in and enjoy our facility. Take a course, volunteer as an intern, become an Artist in Residence, or even join us as a Teacher's Aid (TA). In any way you can, we invite you to join us on this fantastic journey. We are open from 9-5pm Monday through Saturday and welcome visitors who can sit and watch the art of making hot glass in action. Come see for yourself why Horizon truly is the place where “Glass Comes Alive.”


Founder's Bio  

Ron Seivertson (1961, United States), Horizon Glassworks
  Ron Seivertson is a hot glass artist who lives on the edge with an intense devotion to his craft. Ron works from Horizon Glassworks Studio in Ubud, with his team of personally trained assistants. He is known all over the world for producing one of a kind glass pieces that are bold and unique in their style.    

He re-awoke the artist inside himself with painting and sculpturing in his late 30's before finding ‘off hand’ hot glass as his ultimate medium. Ron studied intensely in Seattle, Washington, the Pilchuck Glass School in Washington, and also in Melbourne, Australia.  

From an early age it was quite obvious to Ron that he was an artist - of some sort. His curiously intuitive mind and great imagination give him the ability to model complex forms in space and manifest the extraordinary with incredible tenacity and self expression. Moreover, he has a passion and fervor that gives him endless drive to express, create, expand and achieve… thus he works in the most challenging of mediums - Molten Hot Glass.

$10,000 – Build 1 glory Hole. Our aim is to buy recuperating glory holes for maximum life and fuel efficiency. These are very expensive and must be imported. But we can build our own standard glory holes for less. 
$20,000 – Build 2 glory holes, two benches and buy new pipes and hand tools.
$50,000 – Build a new furnace.
$75,000 – Build a new annealer and convert our others to electricity. 
$100,000 – Will give us enough to buy a larger electric furnace and convert the whole shop to electricity which will be more energy efficient. Right now we operate on bottled gas. 
$125,000 - We can buy a backup generator and build our cold working shop. 
$150,000 – We can fully fit out the hot shop, build our metal working shop, finish our shop office, second bathroom and buy enough tools to serve 12 students. 




Campaign Summary
At Horizon Glassworks we are developing an International Glass Art School that has the ability to dramatically affect the lives of artistic individuals both locally and worldwide. Southeast Asia, and more specifically, Ubud Bali, is the perfect place for Horizon’s learning facility. Horizon Glassworks is now becoming a community of creative energy for glass artists.  
This campaign is about developing part of Horizon Glassworks into a teaching facility that is dedicated to teaching students from all walks of life, ages, and life styles the world over who seek new and exciting ways to express their creative and artistic passion and talents. The skills, lessons, and sense of community learned here will carry on for generations to come.
We have instructors from all over the world that are waiting to come teach, and we’ve got students wanting to learn.
Located in Bali, on the 'Island of the Gods,' we are developing this glass art community in preparation for a glass art movement to be born in Indonesia and throughout South East Asia. 

What We Need
Ron and his wife Indah have spent just about every penny they have securing the property and building the facility where Horizon Glassworks currently resides. It’s a huge operation with over a dozen full time staff, 4,000 square meters of property, and 4 buildings - all in pursuit of the dream to build this into a World Class International Glass Art School. 
Ron and Indah will continue to operate the facility with or without the school. However, they simply can’t afford to complete the necessary upgrades and improvements to the facility in the capacity required for teaching without your help. Please support us, contribute to our campaign, and help turn this dream into reality...  

 



OverfundingIf we are overfunded, we will create a scholarship fund for underprivileged persons to attend. We will also continue to upgrade our facilities to high efficiency recuperating systems and equipment to reduce overall operating costs.  We will also add a program to teach others how to build and operate a fully functional studio of their own to work with hot glass and other glass art forms. This will help promote glass art and begin to stimulate a glass art society and collector's movement throughout Southeast Asia. It is a devotion of ours to develop this program to help less fortunate creative and artistic individuals become self sufficient by opening their own hot glass art studio. With your help, we can make a huge difference in the lives of countless people, and continue the modern age of glass art. What You Get In ReturnBesides helping to make a huge difference for thousands of people, we have implemented an exciting and generous lottery program for those who donate $50 or more to our campaign. We have hand selected 50 pieces of beautiful pieces of various styles from figurines to vases, bowls, platters, paperweights and the like. If we reach our goal, 50 recipients will be drawn at random to receive one of these collectable pieces in appreciation of your support.We also have perks that include your name engraved in stone in our courtyard, and even a perk where one of the studios is dedicated to you with your name proudly displayed at the entrance along with the name of the studio - i.e. The John Q. Smith HOT SHOP. Teachers, students, and visitors will all recognize your support for years to come. Alternatively, Ron will be creating beautiful custom one-off pieces of art for those individuals who donate at the $1,000 level. These will be highly collectable pieces and are available on a very limited basis. Here are some of our Other Perk Highlights:Pendant Necklace: $50 LevelName Engraved in Stone: $100 LevelThis is very special to us as we want our entire courtyard filled with the names of our valuable supporters and where they are from -  a constant reminder of who made this International Glass Art School happen - YOU! The Horizon Glass Property is surrounded by Balinese Stone Carvers making this perk an incredible value. Please come join us, our community, and other supporters... The Impact You Can Help MakeWe foresee the style and message of the local’s work reflecting their rich history and tradition with beautiful glass art pieces. As we develop international visitors and local individuals in the art of hot glass, we are creating a cross cultural and cross generational exchange. Your contribution can make a huge difference not only in their lives, but the lives of future generations - elder artisans here traditionally pass art skills to their children. We truly have the ability to bring a new form of expressive creativity to people here and around the globe who would otherwise never have the opportunity to experience the wonders of glass art. The result is beautiful pieces of glass art that give people the purpose and resources to support themselves and future generations. Other Ways You Can HelpAre you fascinated by glass art? If you can’t contribute, please pass this on to someone who can by posting us up on your social media network or simply telling friends and family who might want to help about this campaign. You can use the Indiegogo share tools for your convenience. We appreciate every contribution, large or small.If you are planning a trip to Bali, please stop in and enjoy our facility. Take a course, volunteer as an intern, become an Artist in Residence, or even join us as a Teacher's Aid (TA). In any way you can, we invite you to join us on this fantastic journey. We are open from 9-5pm Monday through Saturday and welcome visitors who can sit and watch the art of making hot glass in action. Come see for yourself why Horizon truly is the place where “Glass Comes Alive.”Founder's Bio  Ron Seivertson (1961, United States), Horizon Glassworks  Ron Seivertson is a hot glass artist who lives on the edge with an intense devotion to his craft. Ron works from Horizon Glassworks Studio in Ubud, with his team of personally trained assistants. He is known all over the world for producing one of a kind glass pieces that are bold and unique in their style.    He re-awoke the artist inside himself with painting and sculpturing in his late 30's before finding ‘off hand’ hot glass as his ultimate medium. Ron studied intensely in Seattle, Washington, the Pilchuck Glass School in Washington, and also in Melbourne, Australia.  From an early age it was quite obvious to Ron that he was an artist - of some sort. His curiously intuitive mind and great imagination give him the ability to model complex forms in space and manifest the extraordinary with incredible tenacity and self expression. Moreover, he has a passion and fervor that gives him endless drive to express, create, expand and achieve… thus he works in the most challenging of mediums - Molten Hot Glass.

story:
Children of Colombia

Making Ripples

I am Robbie J. Frye (LinkedIn,Facebook,About.me), the founder of ripplepi. I’ve created a nonprofit donation platform based on the idea that bringing like-minded benefactors together can truly change our world. This “tribe” seeks out causes and opportunities of high probable impact and via our collective charitable donations, we create ripples in communities across the globe.

Ripplepi, in alliance with the Civil Air Patrol of Colombia, wants you to be part of an amazing opportunity to buy a portable anesthesia machine for children. These children have no access to modern healthcare and desperately need our help. At this moment, the Civil Air Patrol of Colombia doesn’t have an anesthesia device that will allow them to operate on children who need invasive surgery. The DRE Integra Portable Anesthesia Machine will allow the compassionate doctors of the Civil Air Patrol to operate on children in the most remote areas of Colombia, where access by airplane is the only option.

I know that with your help, we can create the largest tribe of donators this world has ever seen. We can establish an impactful force for good on this blue earth, helping those who need it most. With our collective power, we can change the future of our planet and society for all generations to come.


What you receive for being part of this awesome campaign and helping the Children of Colombia.

The cost of this machine is only $10,000, which is exactly what we need in this fundraising campaign. 100% of every single donation earned will go directly towards the purchase of this portable anesthesia machine.

After we reach our $10,000 goal, every dollar earned afterwards will be used to purchase medical equipment requested by the PAC, which is also in needed. Everything we receive will go towards helping this benevolent group as they continue saving lives and impacting communities.


With you on our team, we can purchase this life-saving device and travel to the most remote areas in Colombia so we can assist these children in the most desperate situations. We will use the anesthesia machine for the first voyage of the PAC in January of 2015, using this precious gift to help hundreds of children, thousands of people, and communities that were impossible to reach before.

The ripplepi campaign has some amazing “thank you gifts” to thank you for your valuable participation and to part of this opportunity. In addition to the formal perks, we will document the entire journey and gift a special video back to the community that supports us.

Gracious Perks and Gifts

-Special handcrafted and designed T-Shirts

-Digital and hardcopy books of the adventure

-Unique apparel and gifts signed by the children

-Three seats on PAC airplanes making this adventure in January of 2015

If we are unable to reach our goal, we will send out an email to every person who has donated and provide them with alternative machine options from the Civil Air Patrol. The item with the most votes and community support will then decide where we use the money. No matter what happens we, will provide 100% transparency with all of your money.


The Greatest Impact

This single machine will start far-reaching ripples of positive influence on children in poor and hard to reach communities all over Colombia, allowing the Civil Air Patrol to have a much wider impact on the communities they serve.

Ripplepi has witnessed and participated in several Civil Air Patrol campaigns and has seen the ripples they create in the communities they assist. One simple surgery can allow a person to work, see their family again, and to once again be part of their communities. The volunteer doctors, nurses, and pilots are so pivotal to the state of these remote communities. The ripples they create are far-reaching and make a drastic difference in many lives that need it so badly.

The Civil Air Patrol is one of the most wonderful groups of people we have had the pleasure to work with. We are sure of the great impact they will make with this portable anesthesia machine for the children of Colombia.

If any of you have questions about this campaign please email us, call us, or leave your messages here on our campaign page.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please take the time to share this amazing ripplepi campaign with your social networks and spread the word with family and friends. You can like us on facebook, follow us on pinterest and twitter, or reach out to us with your own idea. We are always looking for enthusiastic ripplers!

We thank you, the PAC thanks you, and the children of Colombia will thank you as they are able to grow up and contribute to this global society we call humanity.

story:
Let's keep music in LA’s inner-city schools.

In five Los Angeles schools, with students who otherwise would have no access to music education, the Young Musicians Foundation (YMF) Music Mentors Program fills a critical need by providing free music classes to underserved elementary and middle school students.  Now in its third year, our program has doubled for 2013-2014, with 22 Mentors teaching 300 students in their own schools.  And more students want to sign up every week!

We know that students learn best in a caring, mutually beneficial environment that strengthens individual resiliency and the capacity for lifelong learning.  Our extraordinary Mentors are current members and alumni of YMF’s Debut Orchestra, one of the top pre-professional training orchestras in the nation.  Mentors participate in training sessions throughout the year with Lisa Schaeffer, Director of Pedagogy, to develop the skills to engage and inspire their students’ curiosity about music and the world.

In the 2013-2014 school year, the Music Mentors Program is at five school sites:

  • Lennox Middle School (Lennox, CA)
  • Hobart Boulevard Elementary School (Koreatown, Los Angeles, CA)
  • Para Los Niños Eisner Foundation Child Development Center (Skid Row, Los Angeles, CA)
  • Para Los Niños Charter Elementary (Skid Row, Los Angeles, CA)
  • Para Los Niños Charter Middle School (Skid Row, Los Angeles, CA)

As we enter the spring 2014 semester with our strongest impact ever, we’re asking for your help.

It all starts with just $30 per student.

$9,000 will fund an entire semester of

  • New instrument purchases ($3,500).  We just had 21 new students at Lennox Middle School sign up to learn double bass and cello, which means we need to purchase instruments and music stands for two new classes.
  • Instrument maintenance and repairs ($2,500), including necessary supplies such as reeds, strings, etc.;
  • Sheet music and materials ($2,000) for our classrooms, including music notebooks, worksheets, and display boards;
  • Performance costs ($1,000) of the culminating end-of-year concerts for the parents and families of the students (up to 600 per concert).

With 300 students, that comes out to just $30 each for an entire semester of music instruction.  Any money raised beyond the $9,000 goal will go to support audio and visual recording of the final concerts, year-end evaluations, and indirect costs.

And it makes a lasting impact.

The Music Mentors Program isn’t just about teaching fundamentals or regurgitating information.  It’s about engaging the students’ prior knowledge, their passions and curiosities, and working with the unique interests and abilities of each individual child.


We’ve seen a lot of students who would otherwise have been lost in the system or fallen through the cracks.  Many of them are second language learners, so they struggle academically.  But they absolutely thrive with this type of expression, and now students and families are seeing a path to a brighter future.


We know that giving comes in many forms.

Even if you can’t donate today, spread the word to your friends, take advantage of Indiegogo’s sharing tools, and give the gift of music this holiday season!

Who we are:

Founded in 1955, Young Musicians Foundation (YMF) promotes the classical music tradition of Southern California by nurturing the personal, academic, and artistic development of youth ages 4-25 through performance opportunities, financial assistance, and community outreach.

story:
Mi nombre es Tamara López Cruz, madre de una niña con condiciones especiales. En Puerto Rico sobre la situación de nuestros niños y niñas especiales existe una infinidad de artículos en la prensa, discursos de políticos y jefes de agencia, decisiones de tribunales, páginas y páginas de leyes aprobadas en papel y muertas en la realidad.  Pero, ¿dónde quedan las experiencias de miles de madres y padres?  ¿Cómo dejamos plasmadas para la posteridad nuestras vivencias y opiniones?  Dicen que las palabras se las lleva el viento, entonces nada mejor que escribir.  Esa precisamente es la tarea que asumo como madre de una niña especial, contar nuestra historia, desde el punto de vista de quienes día tras día viven en carne propia la falsedad del sistema.  Para lograr ese propósito nada mejor que un libro.

Esta obra no es solo una manera de contar mi historia, además, es una excelente herramienta para crear conciencia entre madres y padres de niños especiales y más allá de ellos, en toda persona que aspire a que Puerto Rico sea un mejor país, un país inclusivo y comprometido con una educación de excelencia.  Más allá de mis experiencias personales, incluyo una serie de entrevistas que ayudan a entender otros casos y a hacer más claro el panorama al que se enfrentan miles de madres, padres y estudiantes.

Es sumamente importante lograr que esta información vea la luz y pueda estar en manos del pueblo. Todo tipo de ayuda para alcanzar este último objetivo, lograr la publicación de este trabajo, es bienvenida y de crucial importancia.

El total aproximado para la publicación e impresión del libro es $5,000. 

La contribución de cada uno de ustedes hará que este libro pueda ver la luz y permitirá a mayor cantidad de madres y padres que se preparen mejor para defender los derechos de sus hijos.

Espero poder contar con todos ustedes y de no ser posible su aportación económica por favor difundan la campaña y compartan esta historia. 

Cuento contigo :-)

story:
The Journey...

In 2000 I took my first yoga class at Velocity dance studio out of curiosity to explore a new movement form. I immediately loved the practice.

For years I dabbled in classes here and there, and even did some home practice to balance out hours of dancing and working in landscaping. It wasn’t until 2006, when I was recovering from a torn ligament in my foot, that I took to the yoga mat in a dedicated fashion—going to class 3 to 4 times a week. It was the best physical therapy I could have given myself, to regain strength and trust in my foot again in my own timing.

Coming from a structured dance background where I was challenged to push my body, I felt comforted in the space where I was encouraged to listen to what my body wanted and needed. I loved how relaxed I felt after every class, and I began to notice how the days were better when I did yoga versus when I didn’t. I loved how focusing on my breath and my body calmed my busy mind and slowly but surely, my body became stronger and more flexible. My ability to deal with stress improved as well and I started to listen more and more to the quiet voice within.

Since then, I have explored many yoga styles— Vinyasa flow, Bikram, Iyengar, Ashtanga, YogaWorks, Baptiste….

Now, arriving at Forrest Yoga, I feel that this is the practice I have been seeking. The practice has everything I need—the relaxation, the strength-building, and the experience of coming home to myself. The Forrest yoga practice encourages me to be authentic with myself, tune into and stay connected to feeling, honor what is and breathe into what I feel.

I want to help pass on this healing work of Forrest Yoga. To hold space and encourage others to stay connected to and listen to themselves, to the feelings that arise and honestly give their body what it needs. I want to teach.

The Details...

I have applied and have been accepted to the Foundation Forrest Yoga Teacher Training taking place in Houston this October. I need your help to make this next step of my journey a reality.

This training is 28-full days and non-residential, so in addition to the tuition, I need to cover expenses for the flight, food, and rent (both in Houston and my home back in Seattle). I hope to stay within walking distance to the training site and plan to cook when I can to save costs.

What the Indiegogo Campaign funds support and make possible:

  • $4,375--Tuition for the Forrest Yoga Foundational Teacher Training
  • $400--Airfare from Seattle to Houston
  • $600--Rent for home in Seattle
  • $600--Room I will rent in Houston
  • $400--Food (Groceries, Restaurants) while in the training

  $6,375--TOTAL

  • $255--4% overhead for indiegogo.com

  $6,630--GRAND TOTAL

The Journey Continues...

Funding my training will help support me in my vision to help others achieve healthy body awareness, to heal traumas and emotional blocks, become more strong, more vital, more relaxed, more balanced...In other words, supporting my training is one way of paying it forward for a healthier planet!

I’ve spent a long time pushing down the voices inside that tell me I want to teach yoga and I want to help people heal. I’ve reached a point where I can’t keep those voices quiet anymore. It’s time for me to live my dream and live my truth.

Your Support Helps My Dreams Come True!

If your heart swells at the thought of donating, please do so. I am humbly, eternally, grateful.

I have created some fun perks as gifts for donating. I hope you will enjoy them.

If you can’t contribute financially, I welcome your support in any form. Please share my dream with people you think would be inspired by it too.

If you would like to read more about Forrest Yoga or the Foundational Teacher Training, check out the website:

http://forrestyoga.com/training/foundation/

Your support and encouragement means the world to me!

     Teacher Training
$400--Airfare from Seattle to Houston
$600--Rent for home in Seattle
$600--Room I will rent in Houston
$400--Food (Groceries, Restaurants) while in the
     training 
 
$6,375--TOTAL
$255--4% overhead for indiegogo.com
 
$6,630--GRAND TOTAL
The Journey
Continues...
Funding my training will help support me in my vision to help others achieve
healthy body awareness, to heal traumas and emotional blocks, become more
strong, more vital, more relaxed, more balanced...In other words, supporting my
training is one way of paying it forward for a healthier planet!
I’ve spent a long time pushing down the voices inside that tell me I want to
teach yoga and I want to help people heal. I’ve reached a point where I can’t
keep those voices quiet anymore. It’s time for me to live my dream and live my
truth. 
Your Support Helps My Dreams Come True!
If your heart swells at the thought of donating, please do so. I am humbly,
eternally, grateful.
I have created some fun perks as gifts for donating. I hope you will enjoy
them.
If you can’t contribute financially, I welcome your support in any form.
Please share my dream with people you think would be inspired
by it too. 
If you would like to read more about Forrest Yoga or the
Foundational Teacher Training, check out the website: http://forrestyoga.com/training/foundation/
Your support and encouragement means the world to me!

story:
SUMMARY

Friday morning 12-20-2013 started out great I got into work at 7am to help one of my students prepare class stocking stuffers she made. Shortly after 8am, the rest of the class joined bringing baked goods and finger foods for our Christmas party. First class went well everyone ate treats while watching Elf, this was the last day of class for the students until Jan 6th, 2014. Second class of the day started pretty much the same way watching yet another Christmas movie and taking a group Christmas photo together. After class, I stayed back a few minutes to talk to coworkers and wish everyone a happy and safe weekend. Thereafter, I left to head home on the I -10 freeway, the trip was cut short when a speeding car rear-ended me and sent my car spinning into the diamond lane wall at speeds of about 65mph. The airbags deployed and I was lucky enough not to sustain very serious external injuries. Sadly, my car was totaled. I started getting lightheaded and dizzy quickly, and was immediately rushed to the hospital where they performed a CT scan; during this scan they concluded that I had sustained a concussion, had frontal lobe brain swelling, and had sprained my neck (cervical sprain). The CT scan also found I have degenerative disk disease in my neck, which appeared to be a pre-existing condition. This condition was aggravated from this accident and I will require physical therapy to work on reducing the effects of this injury.

My name is Brandon, I am a 27 year old Business Administration and Computer Information Systems professor for a junior college. I have lived in California all of my life. This campaign is extremely important for my recovery and to allow me to purchase a new car and cover the cost of medical bills from the accident.

Achieving my goal will provide me with the support needed to keep teaching at the college, something I greatly enjoy. In addition to getting assistance with my medical expenses and financing a new vehicle, this whole situation has added a lot of stress to an already busy a holiday season.

 

The insurance company is not going to provide a solution at this time as there may have been a third party involved in the accident. This could mean a hit and run. An investigation is currently underway as to who was at fault, the 3rd party involved or the person behind me. I have zero fault in the accident. As a liability insurance holder, there is a chance I may not be reimbursed for any injuries or damages at all.

What's needed and how you can help

What's needed is support of any size. Anything and everything helps get this situation resolved and me to stay in the classroom educating minds and improving the futures of all my students. I will send emails, hand written cards, as well as a photo of my classes.  Also, I will be making personal phone calls to all those who donate to my recovery.

Thank you. God bless.

story:
We have the BEST holiday deal for you!

GIVE THE GIFT OF EDUCATION and donate to Pathways in someone’s name. That person will receive the perk and a personalized thank you note from Erica Hamilton, Pathways Executive Director. Your name will be included on the card, in appreciation of your donation.

Happy Holidays!

About us

Pathways Community School started as a program in a traditional high school in South Los Angeles.  We built a college-going culture and a pride in our community that many of our graduates still have today.  But since as teachers we had no control over the budget, schedule, staffing or even what classes we taught – we were powerless to take Pathways to the next level to provide the supports our struggling students needed.

For the past 3 years Dr. Erica Hamilton, the founding lead teacher of the Pathways program and the founding Executive Director of Pathways Community School has been working with researchers, teachers, Pathways graduates and their families to design a school specifically for the students of South Los Angeles.

The result is the Pathways PATH Plan, a unique combination of specialized inputs designed to prepare the Pathways graduate for college, career, and life.

What we need

We are at the ground floor of starting something amazing and we need you to be a part of it!  The first $6000 raised for the Pathways Community School will provide the foundations that we need to build a school that the students in South LA need.

When we speak with parents and middle school students about Pathways, they have so many questions and as we answer them you can see the excitement building within them… about this new and unique opportunity that will be in their community.  But the challenge we face is in creating those opportunities to speak directly with parents and students.  In Los Angeles, charter schools are not allowed to “recruit” new students on traditional school campuses.  This means that in order to reach out to our future Pathways students, we are making tons of copies of our informational flyers and distributing them in stores, parking lots, in neighborhood walks, and in front of middle schools at release time.  We are throwing small house parties at the homes of our Pathways graduates and holding community and parent meetings at the local park.  As the word spreads, more and more parents and students are joining our events, but we need to continue them through the new year in order to continue the face to face engagement that is at the heart of our work.

Contribution Levels

Thanks to all the hard work, Pathways is slated to open in the coming school year and we need your help to keep going strong!

In addition to the satisfaction of knowing that you are contributing to the education of students in South Los Angeles, you will receive a gift from the school to show our appreciation for your contribution!

At Pathways, our belief is that students will be successful if we hold high expectations, communicate and support students to meet those expectations, and celebrate when those expectations are met.  The categories of perks match the awards that we celebrate at the end of each grading period (at which time we also have a parent night). 

Acknowledgements - $5.00 - Personalized Thank You Note

You will receive a personalized thank you card and a thank you on the Pathways Community School Facebook page.

Accolades - $10.00 - Pathways sticker

You will receive a glossy laminate sticker with the Pathways logo designed by Pathways graduate Eduardo Arambula.  You will also receive a thank you on the Pathways Community School Facebook page.

Honor Roll - $25.00 - Pathways swag bag

You will receive a Pathways swag bag with a glossy Pathways sticker, a Pathways pen, and a Pathways notepad.  You will also receive a thank you on the Pathways Community School Facebook page.

High Honors - $50.00 - Pathways T-shirt

You will receive a quality black T-shirt with the Pathways logo designed by Pathways graduate Eduardo Arambula.  You will also receive a thank you on the Pathways Community School Facebook page.

Director’s Honors - $100.00 - The whole shebang!

You will receive a Pathways T-shirt, swag bag, and an invitation to Pathways Top Donors Celebration with the Pathways Board, Executive Director and Pathways graduates.  You will also receive a thank you on the Pathways Community School Facebook page.

Stretch Goals

$6000 - $8,000 – Pathways Chill Zone

The Pathways Chill Zone is the idea of Rosalinda, currently an 8th grader and a future Pathways student.  It is a space for students to relax, read magazines and books, play games, talk to each other, or meet with an advisor or counselor to discuss a challenge or a problem they are experiencing.  Donations from $6000 - $10,000 will allow us to purchase a large area rug, multiple sturdy bean bag chairs, small tables, shelving for books, and displays for magazines.


Drawing by Rosalinda

$8,000 + Pathways High-Interest Library

Every penny beyond $8,000 will go towards purchasing high-interest books, magazines and e-book readers/books for the Pathways Chill Zone and classroom libraries.  Research and experience have demonstrated that exposing students to high-interest reading material and increasing recreational reading “profoundly” increases reading ability and literacy development in general (Krashen, 2001).  Our vision is that every location in Pathways (classrooms, welcome center, chill zone, and offices) will be filled with numerous fiction and non-fiction books, graphic novels, magazines, and comic books.  Through our “Drop everything and Read” time each day, students will have the time to indulge in the enjoyment of reading.  And within our Welcome Center, family members will be encouraged to enjoy educational books in English and Spanish as well as read picture books with their younger children or grandchildren.

The Impact

In South Los Angeles, nearly 40% of incoming 9th grade students will not graduate with their class four years later (CDE, 2012).

As a program in a large traditional high school, Pathways consistently outperformed the rest of the school in graduation rates and standardized test scores, but the margins were typically in the single digits or low teens and that was not good enough for us.  We knew that with the right supports all of our students could graduate high school on time and be prepared for what’s next – and that’s what the Pathways Community School is all about!

By contributing to Pathways today you are providing the foundational support we need to make our vision become a reality. 

And specifically, the contributions towards our outreach plans will allow us to reach the involved parents who are actively searching for educational opportunities for their children and also make personal connections with the families or guardians of struggling students, students with special learning needs, undocumented students, English language learners, and students in foster care or group homes – because we want our school to be representative of the community and to reflect back to that community what is possible.

Other ways to help

Share the link to our fundraising page with your community and anyone else who may be interested in donating.

Use the Indigogo share tools to spread the word on your Facebook and Twitter feeds.


Citations:

Krashen, S. (2001b). Current research: The positive impact of libraries. California School Library Journal 25/1, 21-24.

California Department of Education (2012). Data Quest: School-Based Four Year Graduation Rates. Downloaded at: http://data1.cde.ca.gov/dataquest/

story:
PLEASE SUPPORT US

Facts About Mary’s Meals

  • Total number of children receiving a daily meal in school = 755,777

  • Cost of Mary’s Meals per child, per year in Malawi = $11

  • Cost per meal in Malawi = 6 cents

  • Number of chronically hungry children in the world = 300 million. Around 61 million of these children are out of school.

  • Mary’s Meals is in = 16 countries

We are the Teens for Mary's Meals (Angela Penza, Bella Darke, Kalina Burns, Franziska Barthel, and Brianna Doyle), and our mission is to help spread awareness of the children who die due to starvation in third-world countries. Teens for Mary's Meals is made up of five determined high school girls who plan to raise $11,500 to build a school kitchen for children in Malawi, Africa through a nonprofit called Mary's Meals. We were inspired to start this project after we saw the film Child 31 by grassroots films. We live in Santa Barbara, California and go to Dos Pueblos High School. This is where you can help us reach our goal.

What We Need & Its Impact

  • Every penny of this $2000 will help us get to our goal and go straight to Mary's Meals headquarters.
  • When you donate only 6 cents, you know that you have saved a life in Malawi
  • when you donate $10, you are providing 166 meals in Malawi
  • Mary's Meals buys local food and schools with Mary's Meals have much higher attendance rates
  • Mary's Meals keeps children out of labor and begging by giving them a lasting education which they will most likely continue
 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • post on instagram, facebook, or twitter with #teens4marysmeals
  • blog about us!
  • email us at teens4marysmeals@gmail.com
  • check out our blog at teensformarysmeals.blogspot.com

story:
What if Denton had a FREE splash park, similar to the ones we've seen in Frisco, Lewisville, and elsewhere across DFW?

 

Denton has a lot of great amenities, including a great water park and a beautiful community pool. But nothing FREE for the kids to run and play in during the summertime.  With August temps currently in the 100+ range, it's hard to find activities for our children that allow them to move their bodies and use their "outside voices."

 

There are many families in Denton who can't afford to pay admission to the Natatorium or Civic Center Pool.  There are kids who want to play outside in the summer. There are parents who are tired of reminding their stir-crazy kids to stop jumping on the furniture. And there is plenty of park space in our little town to build something like this.

 

If we can raise $100,000 by the funds allocation meeting on September 17, we will have a powerful voice at the city council meeting regarding the 2013-14 budget.  If we have this money in hand, this could be a game changer, and we could help shape the budget for next year, virtually guaranteeing that the City could bring sufficient funds to the table as well.  We absolutely could get this spray park built in the next year with the money we raise.  With your help we can do it!

 

If we don't make this goal, all funds we collect will be handed over to the Parks Department and applied towards this project in a later budget year - hopefully 2014-15.

story:
We are all here on earth to change the world. Each one of us has a life purpose. In addition, each of us carries a different role in regards to changing or making an impact in this world.  Consciously, my partner Anthony Hebert and I (Imoni Harris) are starting a nonprofit organization for at risk LGBT homeless youth in the greater Los Angeles and South bay area. This population is huge and rapidly growing each day. Statistics show that of the homeless population in L.A. 40 % are LGBT boys and girls. My partner and I have created the organization NULife Project so that we can offer much more than life-sustaining support like food, clothing, medical care and a warm bed; we desire and will offer young people the help they need to get off the streets and make it on their own, including counseling, GED preparation, job placementassistance and mentoring. Eventually we would like to partner with the Los Angeles Gay & Lesbian Center and turn this epidemic into a happy ending/new beginning for our youth. If you simply agree with our cause please feel free to donate any amount you desire. We truly appreciate your love and support for our youth.

“It’s time to change the world & create a NULife”…

With lots of love and patience,

Imoni Harris & Anthony Hebert

NULife Project Founders

story:
The Short Version:

Mi Casita Montessori is a project at its inception. We need to raise $4,000 in 40 days to buy Montessori materials to prepare Xela's first authentic Montessori classroom environment. Any amount you can contribute can help so please donate today.


The Longer Version:

Located in Quetzaltenango ("Xela"), the second largest city in Guatemala, the Mi Casita Montessori (MCM) will offer an exemplary, authentic Montessori education for children between the ages of three and six. Montessori is a method of education designed to meet each child's developmental needs, to follow each child's unique interests and support each child in developing their human potential. You can read more about what AMI Montessori is here.


MCM is directed by Shirley Yancor, an AMI trained Montessori teacher living and working in Xela. In January 2011, after completing her AMI training in Argentina and her practicum in Mexico, Shirley returned to Xela to establish the city's first authentic Montessori program. Committed to AMI Montessori methods, Shirley offers a program supporting the physical, psychological and social development of the whole child. If you're curious about her story, you can find out more about how Shirley became a Montessori teacher here.


You can also follow our blog at http://micasitamontessori.wordpress.com


The Impact

Mi Casita Montessori is located on the boundary between a low-income rural community and a middle-class urban community. MCM is dedicated to bringing children from diverse backgrounds together to foster collaboration and address the educational disparities evidenced in these communities. Guided by Dr. Montessori’s methods, Mi Casita Montessori will be an environment that follows student’s interests and guides each individual towards developing a deep and lasting love for learning, and respect for himself and his peers.


In Xela, where access to quality early childhood education is limited, the need for this program is great. By building a collaborative and respectful community for young learners, united in a caring and nurturing
Montessori learning environment, Mi Casita Montessori endeavors to meet this need.


Montessori materials are precise, scientifically-based and beautiful. A properly prepared Montessori environment engages the child's hand and mind to help them develop their full human potential. By supporting our campaign, you can help us jumpstart a Montessori classroom, providing the children of Xela with the materials needed to become independent, motivated, curious, purposeful, concentrated and peaceful learners.

What We Need & What You Get

We are currently working to fund the purchase of a set of Montessori classroom materials. Montessori materials are precise, carefully crafted and unique to the Montessori method. They support children in developing independence, cultivating their mathematical minds, inspiring curiosity, and emboldening their artistic natures. Moreover, they help young children learn to read, write, count, and more while feeling really good about themselves.


$4,000 will allow us to purchase and ship a classroom's worth of Montessori primary materials critical to the opening of an AMI Montessori classroom. We are using the U.S. distributor, Montessori Outlet as they provide quality, low cost Montessori materials based on the Nienhaus blueprint.


When you donate you can receive some great goodies, and moreover, you can feel good knowing that these kickbacks will help support other amazing non-profits in Xela too!

***Update on kickbacks: We're excited to get these out to you. We anticipate shipping them in August.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about our school! We need all the buzz we can get, so if you're unable to donate at this time, please take the time to forward this to 5, 10, 50, or 1,000 of your friends. The more exposure we get, the more likely it is we will be funded.


Help us become a non-profit organization! Buying materials is just the beginning of starting a school. As the school becomes more established it will need support to fund its potential growth. Current fundraising efforts are being led by a U.S. team of Montessori teachers and assistants. If you can offer your services as a lawyer or are familiar with getting non-profits off the ground, please feel free to get in touch with us.


Pay attention to the next campaign round. Next up, funding the building of a roof!
story_txt:
The Short Version:
Mi Casita Montessori is a project at its inception. We need to raise $4,000 in 40 days to buy Montessori materials to prepare Xela's first authentic Montessori classroom environment. Any amount you can contribute can help so please donate today.

The Longer Version:

Located in Quetzaltenango ("Xela"), the second largest city in Guatemala, the Mi Casita Montessori (MCM) will offer an exemplary, authentic Montessori education for children between the ages of three and six. Montessori is a method of education designed to meet each child's developmental needs, to follow each child's unique interests and support each child in developing their human potential. You can read more about what AMI Montessori is here.

MCM is directed by Shirley Yancor, an AMI trained Montessori teacher living and working in Xela. In January 2011, after completing her AMI training in Argentina and her practicum in Mexico, Shirley returned to Xela to establish the city's first authentic Montessori program. Committed to AMI Montessori methods, Shirley offers a program supporting the physical, psychological and social development of the whole child. If you're curious about her story, you can find out more about how Shirley became a Montessori teacher here. 

You can also follow our blog at http://micasitamontessori.wordpress.com


The Impact

Mi Casita Montessori is located on the boundary between a low-income 
rural community and a middle-class urban community. MCM is dedicated to 
bringing children from diverse backgrounds together to foster 
collaboration and address the educational disparities evidenced in these
 communities. Guided by Dr. Montessori’s methods, Mi Casita Montessori 
will be an environment that follows student’s interests and guides each 
individual towards developing a deep and lasting love for learning, and 
respect for himself and his peers.
In Xela, where 
access to quality early childhood education is limited, the need for 
this program is great. By building a collaborative and respectful 
community for young learners, united in a caring and nurturingMontessori learning environment, Mi Casita Montessori endeavors to meet this need.Montessori materials are precise, scientifically-based and beautiful. story:
PLUM VILLAGE MONKS AND NUNS VISIT JAPAN

May 9-22, 2012

to share the practice of mindfulness in Fukushima and other parts of Japan, to help heal the wounds from last year’s tsunami and nuclear disaster.

http://pv-shouhei.opensense.jp/index.html

WHAT IS MINDFULNESS?

Mindfulness is a simple, scientifically-proven way to bring our mind back to our body, become aware of what is happening in our present experience and connect with happiness, joy and freedom.

You can build a new house in very little time, but healing the emotional wounds from a devastation of such magnitude takes a lot more.

The two-week series of events will include visits to the disaster areas around Fukushima and Miyagi, to offer healing energy through chanting and personal deep listening sessions, a weekend mindfulness practice retreat in Shizuoka, and a day of mindfulness and other events to share the practice with people of all ages in and around Tokyo.

CURRENT SITUATION IN JAPAN

It's been a little bit more than a year since the tsunami hit the northeastern coast of Japan. More than 15,000 people have died, and thousands are still missing. The nuclear leakage from the Fukushima power plant has forced thousands of people, many of them farmers, to abandon their homes and fields. One year later, still too contaminated with radiation for reentry, the area is a no-man's land. Across the country, no one knows for certain how safe their water and food are. It is a tremendous source of anxiety, especially for mothers of small children. Powerful aftershocks continue to shake the entire country, further aggravating people’s fear and stress. The media, moreover, compound those fears by announcing with certainty that another large earthquake and tsunami is due at any moment.

http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2113345...

http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/135617/20110418...

There are many inspiring news reports of friends in Japan who are moving on, helping each other and re-building the country. We don't hear so much about the darkness that continues to prey on this country that already for many years has had the highest rates of suicide in the world. That rate has greatly increased since the disaster. Many are elderly people left with no place to live and no one taking care of them. Having lived all their life in a remote area of Japan, it is unthinkable for many of them to suddenly start up a new life in a strange new place. People who lost their businesses or even their entire families feel hopeless. It has become almost the norm to experience depression, despair, and anxiety, and there is not enough spiritual and moral support to help those who suffer from post-traumatic stress. The victims are truly grateful for the material assistance they’ve received from all over the world. Today, what they are really in need of is spiritual sustenance.

BRINGING MINDFULNESS PRACTICE TO JAPAN

Although Japan is nominally a Buddhist country, most Japanese will tell you they only go to temples for funeral ceremonies. Mindfulness is a form of mind training taught by the Buddha in which the practitioner comes back to abide peacefully in the present moment and embrace all aspects of the present-moment experience. When we are mindful our minds are clear and at peace, we’re able to handle our own and others’ pain, and our hearts are open and light.

In May 2012, Buddhist monks and nuns from the Plum Village Meditation Center in France will be visiting to offer introductory workshops on mindfulness. They are students of Zen Master Thich Nhat Hanh, one of the most renowned Buddhist teachers in the world and a pioneer of teaching mindfulness in the West. They will offer practical exercises in mindfulness of breath, body and mind, and share ways to cope with stress, release tension, and handle strong emotions including anger, loneliness and despair. They will share their experiences of using simple practices to awaken to joy and happiness in daily life and nourish a heart of compassion.

http://www.indiegogo.com/mindfulnessinjapan?c=g...

HOW YOU CAN HELP

We need your help! All funds raised via IndieGoGo will go toward:

- making the 3-day retreat of mindfulness free and accessible for the direct victims of the tsunami
- retreat scholarships for those who are fully committed to helping in the disaster areas
- simple, inexpensive travel and accommodation for the visiting monks and nuns
- producing retreat booklets, and CDs of chanting to be given out to the people in the disaster areas
- IndieGoGo / PayPal / Credit Card processing fees

Your donation, no matter how small, can help open the door of mindfulness practice to a person living in Japan who is alienated, depressed, or even suicidal, showing them a path to healing and transformation.


With everything else happening in the world, there’s now very little media coverage on the grimmer realities of life in post-tsunami Japan. By making a donation, you can let our friends in Japan know they are still cared for and have the support of friends from all over the world.

Any funds raised in excess of our goal for the April visit will be applied toward the next visit of Plum Village monastics to Japan in October 2012.

You can also help by directing people to this page and sharing the project on your Facebook and Twitter pages.â€¨

Thank you for your compassionate support!

ABOUT PLUM VILLAGE

The Plum Village monastery and meditation practice center was founded in 1982 by Vietnamese Zen-Master Thich Nhat Hanh. Every year, Plum Village welcomes thousands of friends from all around the world. There are also Plum Village practice centers in The United States, Germany, Thailand, Hong Kong, and Australia.

www.plumvillage.org

ABOUT PLUM VILLAGE
