story:
Our Goal Is To Improve School Security Nationwide

Our children are the most vulnerable part of our population and in many cases they are not well protected in school (where they spend the majority of their day).

Over the past 20 years, safety and security have been a priority at colleges and universities because of national laws like the Clery Act.

Unfortunately, these laws do not apply to K-12, and 90% of our states do not enforce minimum security standards.

As a result, over 1.8 million criminal incidents occur every year at our children's schools.

As parents, our feeling is that this subject has been downplayed and has taken a back seat far too long. It needs action.

In response to current events, legislators are attempting to place higher requirements and recommendations for anonymous reporting systems, school security planning and emergency notification systems. If you analyze the 470 new Bills introduced since Newtown, you can only conclude that our legislators are guessing at what to do.

Awareness and Accountability Through a Simple App

The idea behind our project is simple:
Enable everyone with a smartphone to report when they see something wrong.

For example, security issues (open door, broken fence,etc), bullying, loitering, drugs, stranger danger...
Once a month, we deliver all reported incidents to state officials so they will know how big a problem this really is.

As part of a school's security plan, school officials will be able to access the incidents for their school from the School Dangers website.

Reports on documented incidents make actionable and targeted plans to improve your school and student safety.

This simple program can point out the safety and security shortcomings that are not being addressed in our nation’s schools and drive positive change for a safer and more secure school environment.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

*Update*

(06/07/2013)

Based on your feedback and available funding, the following ideas may be something that we can impliment into the future:

  • "On My Way" Student Monitoring Function - School Security starts before your child gets to school. The concept behind this is to insure your child arrives safely to school whether they are walking or riding the bus. The way this would work is to check that your child arrives on time at certain landmarks/checkpoints. If they are riding the bus, this app could monitor the bus speed or if it gets stopped somewhere (hijacking or breakdown)

What's it going to take to make School Dangers a reality?

Your contributions will help build the initial Android and Apple IOS mobile applications and related website. We will get the developers started as soon as funding starts to flow in.

We know from our developers that it will cost about $16,000 to build the mobile applications and supporting website.

The other $9,000 is to cover the costs for running the website and delivering the reports. (That's just $750 a month)

FAQ

Is there a revenue model to this?
We do have a long term plan. The mobile apps and website statistics will be free. Revenue to cover hard costs (about $9K a year) will come from advertisers and subscriptions. A $1 app will be available with no ads. Paid subscriptions will allow parents & officials to access more detailed information and additional features we have already mapped out.

Who has access to detailed information?
We do not want to tell a would-be criminal that the side door is unlocked. The average person will only be able to see that a type of incident was reported. School and state officials will need to be confirmed to access the most detailed online information. A reasonable "you-are-who-you-say-you-are" confirmation fee will cover hard costs related to the confirmation process and a small subscription fee to allow us to add services.

Other Ways You Can Help

    • If you already donated or you can’t help monetarily right now... help “Spread the Word” to family and friends, via Facebook, email any way you can think of to raise awareness (remember that’s what this is all about).
    • Get other people you know to donate and make this application and website a reality. All it takes is a donation of your friends and family and their friends and family for as little as $1. All of those $1 donations add up quickly to make a lasting difference in our children’s schools.

    • “I do want School Dangers to be built, but I cannot donate that much. Can I have an Indiegogo perk?”

      Sure you can! Bring friends to donate a total of $100 or more and we will award you the matching perk as if you donated it yourself. Here's how to do it:

      1 - Log into IndieGoGo. If you don't have an account, you can use the "Connect using your Facebook account" feature.

      2 - Browse to our campaign at www.indiegogo.com/projects/school-dangers-mobile-app. You'll see that in the Share section under our pitch video the url will display a number at its end. That url is YOUR personal url.



      3 - Use the embedded share buttons to share our campaign with your firends! Whenever someone clicks on it and donates to SchoolDangers, we'll know that YOU sent him to our campaign page!

Thank you for your help making School Dangers a reality. We are very passionate about improving the Safety and Security of our nation’s schools and creating further awareness of the problems that exist with this issue.

story:
It started with a challenge.

Anytime Fitness challenged 10 bloggers to eat healthy for a week on just $35 and called it #SurviveOn35.

Now, we're upping the ante.

We're asking you to help us give the gift of healthy cooking to those who need it most.

Your donation will go to Cooking Matters, an organization that teaches low income families how to prepare healthy, affordable meals.

Any amount gets us closer to our $10K goal, so please chip in $5, $10, $25 or more today.

Please contribute now!

story:
CBF will build a computer system with custom installed education tools based on needs, location, local requirements, etc.  We will start with different education tracks that they can choose from, both online and locally installed, starting with ESL (English as a Second Language), math, science, and computer programming as possible options for them to use.  We will then look at what local needs they may have, and work with them on more custom options.

These systems will be installed in impoverished locations around the world, with an emphasis on helping children supplement their current education.  Each location will be given e-mail access, a portal to check for education updates, and access to talk to other network members to ask questions or pass ideas along to.

This system is a combination of technology and education specifically designed for each location it is installed.  It will consist of at least 1 Windows Multi-Point Server, a computer system that allows you to install 1 computer box, and multiple monitors/keyboards/mice.  The OS is designed to work in a teacher/student environment.  Out initial systems will have 1 teacher station and 6-8 student stations.

My Goal is to raise enough money to travel with Connecting Borders Foundation to set up a computer system with free educational software we will be giving suplemental education to girls ages twelve to fifteen, in remote parts of the Andes Mountains, specifically to the Sacred Valley Project.

By providing these free tools, we are giving the girls the opportunity to recieve education far beyond the education they would receive in their local village.

Please make sure to share this with your network and get the word out. If I am able to raise more than the required amount I will donate the rest of the money to the organization, which we will bring directly to Sacred Valley Project in Peru.

story:
Short Summary

On Decemeber 14, 2012 the lives of the students of Sandy Hook Elementary were changed forever. 

There's been a lot of coverage of the shooter but not enough of the children. 

These kids are going to be scared to go back to school, and a child should NEVER be afraid of the place where they are supposed to be the safest. It's up to us as a community to reach out. It could have been OUR children, brothers, sisters, grandchildren, nephews, or nieces.

When it comes down to it, money isn't going to help these kids. It's HEALING that will. So let's drum a little something up to help the school begin that process.

Let's start a fund for an after school art program that is going to help these kids express the emotions they are feeling and really begin the recovery process. It's not going to happen overnight, but we can absolutely make a difference.

My Heart goes out to the families. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

The goal is $2,700. That's a $100 for every victim in the shooting.

Donate whatever you can, every little bit matters. These kids are worth it.

****UPDATE**** 

We've reached our goal! But the more we raise the longer we can keep this running! So let's keep it going!

The Impact

Art is one of the most valuable outlets for emotion, relief, and healing.

Unfourtunately, it's also the first program that being cut in most elementary schools. Let's reverse that for these kids, they really need it. We don't want these children feeling like they are alone... and if they can't find the words to tell us how they feel, let them show us. 

 

A child's artwork can be incredibly telling and I foresee this doing 3 things.

1. Giving kids an outlet to show us how they feel.

2. Allowing the kids to take their mind off it for a bit.

3. Alerting the right people which kids are having a more difficult time dealing with it, so they can get the help they need.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

There's always a million ways to help and show you care. Let's flood the school with support. Send letters, drawings, photos... anything you can to help them feel our support as a community. 

https://plus.google.com/104985939909456844973/about?gl=us&hl=en

 

 

 

*MAKE SURE YOU ARE CHECKING THE UPDATES SECTION* I will post it there as I have more information.
story_txt:
Short Summary
On Decemeber 14, 2012 the lives of the students of Sandy Hook Elementary were changed forever. 
There's been a lot of coverage of the shooter but not enough of the children. 
These kids are going to be scared to go back to school, and a child should NEVER be afraid of the place where they are supposed to be the safest. It's up to us as a community to reach out. It could have been OUR children, brothers, sisters, grandchildren, nephews, or nieces.
When it comes down to it, money isn't going to help these kids. It's HEALING that will. So let's drum a little something up to help the school begin that process.
Let's start a fund for an after school art program that is going to help these kids express the emotions they are feeling and really begin the recovery process. It's not going to happen overnight, but we can absolutely make a difference.
My Heart goes out to the families. 
 


What We Need & What You Get
The goal is $2,700. That's a $100 for every victim in the shooting.
Donate whatever you can, every little bit matters. These kids are worth it.
****UPDATE**** 
We've reached our goal! But the more we raise the longer we can keep this running! So let's keep it going!
The Impact


Art is one of the most valuable outlets for emotion, relief, and healing.
Unfourtunately, it's also the first program that being cut in most elementary schools. Let's reverse that for these kids, they really need it. We don't want these children feeling like they are alone... and if they can't find the words to tell us how they feel, let them show us. 
 
A child's artwork can be incredibly telling and I foresee this doing 3 things.
1. Giving kids an outlet to show us how they feel.
2. Allowing the kids to take their mind off it for a bit.
3. Alerting the right people which kids are having a more difficult time dealing with it, so they can get the help they need.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
There's always a million ways to help and show you care. Let's flood the school with support. Send letters, drawings, photos... anything you can to help them feel our support as a community. 
https://plus.google.com/104985939909456844973/about?gl=us&hl=en
 
 
 
*MAKE SURE YOU ARE CHECKING THE UPDATES SECTION* I will post it there as I have more information.

story:
Help make the 2013 Saberseminar a Reality! 

Sabermetrics, Scouting and the Science of Baseball, a weekend seminar for the benefit of the Jimmy Fund, puts you up close with some of baseball’s top coaches, statisticians, scouts, doctors, and scientists.

Following the success of our first event in 2011, the 2012 conference featured:

  • A Sell-out Crowd!
  • Stories and insights from the manager of the Boston Red Sox
  • Original Sabermetric research
  • Attendance from many major league teams
  • Presentations from Scouts and MLB Insiders

The Saberseminar can be a great place to network with industry insiders and meet new friends that love the game of baseball.

During this event, you will grasp how science is blended with advanced baseball statistics and traditional scouting assessments to produce outstanding results for teams. Don’t miss this special opportunity to learn about the deeper game of baseball from insiders and pros, meet people who love the game, and help the Jimmy Fund.

Every penny earned during this baseball weekend will go directly to the Jimmy Fund.

The Saberseminar will be held August 17-18, 2013, at Boston University.


Your donation can help us host a great event to support cancer research.

 


Previews of Poster Perk Rewards can be found at our Merch page:

http://saberseminar.com/merch/

story:
Moira Johnston is an advocate for a woman's right to go topless in public.

 

Moira Johnston graduated with a BA in Sociology from Temple University. She now teaches yoga and participates in independent topless activism in public and private spheres.

 

Topless activism promotes breast health, positive self body image, and equality between the sexes. Going topless can increase a person's feeling of comfort, and increases Vitamin D absorption through exposure to the sun. The activism encourages freedom of expression and empowers women to define for themselves when and for what reasons to bare their breasts.


Topless activism supports the case for breastfeeding and helps people to overcome prejudice and cultivate tolerance for cultural diversity.

 

Contributing funds increases the availability of time Moira Johnston will be able to invest in the activism, rather than spending time generating income through work. Funds will be placed towards various travel costs around areas of demonstration and throughout the country and will help to cover cost of supplies, such as pasties, yoga mats, sunscreen, and any other necessary materials for Moira and others.

 

Yoga mats will be provided for participants in outdoor yoga classes for topless women and their advocates, which Moira will instruct and implement free of charge to participants.

 

Please feel free to contribute in proportion to your preference or level of support to the cause. Your contribution will be greatly appreciated, and used with care. This opportunity was made available due to several inquiries from people interested in making a contribution to this cause. Thank you!

story:
"...but wait! I don't know who Nikola Tesla is." Unfortunately that's something that we geeks of the world hear all of the time. If you seriously do not know who Nikola Tesla was, then Matthew Inman will so elegantly explain. Now that you recognize that our entire modern life is based on Tesla's work, it is time to give back in honor of the man who spent his entire life making yours better. Let's Build a Goddamn Tesla Museum is/was amazing, but we think Nikola deserves something much bigger.

But an Institute? Isn't that a huge task?

Yes, yes it is; but do you think that re-engineering an entire societal structure was a simple task? It is time to give credit where credit is due.

Ok, tell me more.

Excellent! We are pleased that you are interested in the Dana Tesla Institute!(DTI)

At DTI, we are Dedicated to Serving and Educating those the American College System has left behind: The Individual.

The Institute will be divided into three colleges within itself: the College of Sciences, the College of Arts & Humanities, and the College of Business.

DTI was started by four college kids ranging in age from 20 to 24.

Our goal is to create an institute in honor of Nikola Tesla where students are free to be who they are and study what they want. There are several different ways that we plan to do this, so check out our website!

The Dana Tesla Institute is registered as a business in the state of South Dakota, though an exact location is still pending. DTI has also applied for tax-exempt status from the IRS, but like all Government things, it is taking quite a while.

How can I help?

Right now, we are seeking to raise approximately $500,000 for fundraising and staffing purposes, as well as a down-payment on land. The actual cost of land, construction, faculty, accreditation, recruiting, and at least 4 operating years is going to be close to $300 Million. We will continue fundraising until this goal is met before opening to guarantee that our students will graduate.

The Dana Tesla Institute is more than just a great idea, it is a labor of love. In July of 2013, a wonderful woman who supported the Institute from the beginning, took her own life. The DTI team have sworn never to stop until they can dedicate a part of the Institute in her memory.

If you would like to help, but don't have the financial resources, we need help in getting the word out, contacting corporations for donations, and website development and maintenance. If you want in any way, please contact us at: danateslainstitute@gmail.com

Check out our website for more information!

*All photos are the property of their respective owners.

story:
Hi everyone! Many of you will remember the campaign we had last year to raise funds for photobooks for local Camp Kesem campers. The kids lit up when they were presented with the gifts (they were a HUGE success) and I would love to do something similiar again this year. We are getting a really late start (life has gotten in the way), so the surprise will be a bit dependent on the funds we are able to raise. I would ideally like to present each kid with a digital album (there are reasonably priced portable ones that the kids would love). I plan to spend every healthly moment I have on-site again to capture photos and video.


Here is a link to a video I created last year: https://www.dropbox.com/s/kfs8xrehs9baj2x/Camp%20Kesem.mov

We are hoping to raise funds beyond the goal you see listed, but I am keeping it conservative because last year we didn't quite make goal and were hit with significant fees. We have 125 campers this year, so we ideally need to raise $5,000 to pull this off ($40 per camper - after all the fees, we receive closer to $30). I know times are still really hard for many...but each and every dollar counts...so even if you have just $1 to donate, please consider doing so. If each person I knew on Facebook alone donated just $1, we would be 1/3 of our way to our true goal.


Namaste

story:
Short Summary

Hello! Thank you so much for checking out my campaign! I'm very excited to be sharing my vision with you and am so humbled by your attention. 

I have a vision of helping young people grow into thriving, self-aware, generous adults and I need your help to make it happen! There are many roads to wholeness, although not one of them is easy, and the 5Rhythms, a transformational dance practice, is one of the paths I am inspired to help people traverse. Looking out at the world, I see a lot of muck - sadness, greed, arrested development, apathy, and meanness - but I also see a whole ton of potential for infinite freedom, goodness, and peace. It is this potential that gets activated on the dance floor, this potential that I want to spread like wildfire, and this potential that makes me get up each day and face the insanity of our crazed world. 

What We Need & What You Get

I have been dancing the 5Rhythms for four years, attending workshops and trainings all over the country in order to prepare myself for this year of training. The teacher training costs $7,900, not including travel and lodging while on site. I am estimating $2,000 to cover the latter. 

Along with being passionate about dance, healing, and embodiment, I am also a trained leadership coach & facilitator. I have organized numerous workshops, lectures, and symposiums aimed at inspiring young people. I believe that a combination of self-awareness, knowledge about global issues, and strong leadership can inspire even the most disillusioned young person into a powerful comprehension of their purpose in the world - and we certainly need more purposeful people in the world! 

In addition, I will be beginning my PhD next year to become a psychologist. As a therapist, I will continue doing deep work with young people even off the dance floor. As a psychologist, I am also a trained researcher and I will be incorporating the most cutting edge research from the fields of neuroscience and mindfulness (my favorite scientific fields!) into my work. I am also passionate about archetypes, mythology, and ritual - all fields that enhance, inform, and deepen the way I approach the 5Rhythms, therapy, and healing. 

The Impact

Your contribution will enable me to afford the training I need to bring this unique and powerful practice to the world. An investment in me is an investment in a vision for a thriving, grounded, self-aware generation of young people - the very young people poised to take over leading & evolving our planet! It's easy to see our systems are on life-support, and some would argue that if we don't transform our lifestyle in this lifetime, the human species will perish. Young people hold the key to this transformation - but we cannot do it without wisdom, leadership, self-love, and DANCE! By investing in me, you will bring us just a little bit closer. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Not able to contribute financially? No problem! Just help me spread the word! And when the time comes, send me your friends, children, relatives, and students to DANCE DANCE DANCE. 

In love & gratitude.

story:
What is the Animation is Art experience?

What we want to do is bring the community aspects of a convention to a retail experience! This means that we are raising money to improve our equipment and to add stability to the store for events! These are the kinds of events we want to be able to run at the store.

  • Educational Panels and showings. We will also video tape some of these events and make them available online or even stream them online! We have the space for up to 30+ people in the store at once.
  • We have the space, the connections, and the equipment to do events like Guest Autograph Sessions, cultural parties, fun panels, an artist's alley weekend, charity events, meet ups, Streetpass Aurora events, Disney Pin Swaps, and so forth.
  • Coloradoanime.info is a resource we also hope to launch. The idea behind Coloradoanime.info is to collect all the information for the dozens of anime conventions, meet up groups, high school groups, college groups, and events into one all encompassing "wiki" of the amazing Anime Community, here in Colorado. We will also have pages in it with profiles for local artists, cosplayers, and so forth.
  • This will also benefit and help launch the Suki Nihon Society for cultural appreciation. This will be a group that meets twice a month to discuss -via a round table- the anime community at large and the issues that affect it. These events will be taped in both audio and video. We are hoping to get some of the most prominent and opinionated people for each round table. We may even be able to Skype in industry professionals!
  • We will also be able to hold art shows and have interesting memorabilia. When we started, we wanted to make sure we had something amazing at the store, every month. This fell a bit to the way side because of the issues and problems we have had to face.
  • The Animation community in Colorado is amazing and also a bit "fractured." We hope to make our store, and the experience of our store, a neutral force that brings people together.

We are building a community center out of a retail store and we need your help!

What will we be spending this money on?

Let me break down a bit of what we need and why we need it:

  • When we started up, we were not able to secure enough funding from the banking system. We wanted $50,000 or -at least- $30,000. We got $15,000 and they (Chase) changed the nature of the loan from an SBA to an ABA loan during that process. The same banking system that got over $7,000,000,000,000 from our government. So, we ended up with an extremely slim chance at life. It's a miracle we lived a year and we have everyone in the community to thank for that. Which is why it's time for us to start becoming more stable and start giving back even more to the community! This money will go toward stability, and more equipment for events. Some of the events will involve funds of their own; but those will be to get certain guests like voice actors, animators, or musicians into the store for events! Not everyone can afford to go to the amazing conventions we have in the Denver/Aurora area. Sometimes those sell out to capacity as well and people miss out. That is sad and part of the reason we want to get healthy and stable enough to bring those kinds of amazing events to our community. We also want to work with many of the other groups in the area for events. In order to do that, we need to be stable.
  • We hope to meet or even exceed our funding goal. But if we do not meet that goal, everything that is sent to us will still go toward stability. We are working on as much as we can to build up a foundation and fix our current situation..

What will my donation mean?

The first and foremost reason for Animation is Art to exist is to give back to the community that we love by providing product and events that we hope the community will love:

  • Our stability as a community center means that we will be here for the students of the high schools in our neighborhood. We are a safe, non-judgmental store where we treat animation as a brilliant medium. Our name is not the name of a store; but a statement of truth. Our purpose is to spread that message. Animation IS art and is a significant part of our culture, history, and lives. Sometimes, people visit us just to talk and hang out while discussing the shows, manga, and other products they like. We are not a huge, corporate store like Toys R Us or Barnes & Noble, where the experience is a lot less personal. We want to share the joy and pride that animation brings to us in a personal way. In a way that respects the art and welcomes new appreciation for the greatest of crafts.
  • Animation is Art will work with DMG Ice, Area DMG, and Radio DMG when it comes to the release of original content on the internet. We will tape many of the events and be able to make that experience available for everyone on the internet. You will be able to join us at Animation is Art at any time and from any where!
  • Through our Green Cross Commission Program, we are able to highlight and celebrate the local artists of our area of Colorado. Colorado is an amazing place and the community here will be highlighted and shared with the rest of the world.

What other ways can I help?

Sigh. Times are tough. However, there are many ways to help us out:

  • Share this campaign and make some noise! Post it on Reddit, on Facebook, on whatever social networks you use. Let people know about us!
  • If you live in the area and you have never been by the store, stop on by and say hello! Even if you never buy anything or put a penny toward us, just being there and talking with us is reward enough. Come on in and argue over which Studio Ghibli film is the best. Discuss that cray-cray episode of Gravity Falls. Why not come in and tell me all about your Bubbleine fan fiction. A community needs everyone and accepts everyone. Join our Facebook and talk with us. Just make some noise!

Come on in and argue over which Studio Ghibli film is the best. Discuss that cray-cray episode of Gravity Falls. Why not come in and tell me all about your Bubbleine fan fiction. A community needs everyone and accepts everyone. Join our Facebook and talk with us. Just make some noise!

story:
Hello My name is Corrie Ayers. I would like to invite you into my world and share about some amazing kids that I have met!

Over the past 5 years I have been privileged to work with children and youth that live all over the world. These kids are referred to as Third Culture Kids. As a result of working with these kids, I have created a non-profit education business called Club 4th. The goal of Club 4th is to provide these kids a safe place to meet, make friends and go deep in their walk with the Lord.

Club 4th has been created to come alongside them and their parents, helping them to understand more about who they are, embrace where God has them and to go deep in their relationship with God.  We do that by using the club model - drawing people with similar interests and background together to help learn from each other, share stories and life together. We use the platform of spiritual life conferences to do this. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Club 4th is at a crossroads. The teams that have been sent out through  Club 4th have done their jobs well and as a result, I have more requests for teams than I can fill.  The organization of Club 4th provides the needed infrastructure to share the vision, but what is lacking is resources - to use with the kids as well as to train the teams well before they leave. 

The money will go towards the following projects:

Curriculum Development:

Because I am a teacher, I love to bring resources to the kids that engages them, that helps them to learn in a fun way and that includes physical activities to illustrate the point of the lesson. Since I am the only business that will provide programming for children birth -18, I also look for ways to teach across the spectrum of ages. Sadly there is not much written in the western world that will work with these kids. They don’t have the same background. They don’t share the same humor and don’t have the same points of reference. I have some teachers and trainers who are ready to go to work on writing curriculum to use at the camps that will be specifically targeted to TCK”s  - their needs and their experiences. 

Website development:

The also need a safe place to share pictures and stay connected with their mentors.  I have a team of people ready to go who can build a web site just for them - where they can share pictures and their lives with their mentors from the camp. It will also serve to educate others about TCK’s, who they are and how Club 4th meets their needs.

Other projects/needs:

There are also other projects that need funding as well - Any money that comes in over and above the $3,500, will be applied to purchasing other resources needed for the program. Items like toys for the preschool age children, books for giving out to the children and pea pods (little tents) to use to nap the babies in. 

Because this is an Olympic year, I am looking for poeple to come alongside and join the support team. There are various rewards for joining the team - Consider joining the Club 4th "Olympic" team by supporting Club 4th financially! 

The Impact

As I have worked with these kids, they are so excited that I keep coming back and am working on designing curricululm and programs just for them - to meet their needs. The kids love that someone out there sees their needs and is willing to travel half way around the world to meet their needs. The impact will have lasting and eternal impact on their lives. Here are some of the comments from those who have attended a Club 4th Camp:

"Thank you for loving our children by taking the time to learn about them and to help them understand who they are. It means so much to us." - Parent of 3 teenagers

"Thak you for leading this program for us. It has been an amazing week and I really benefitted from this week and have grown spiritually." - 18 year old Male

"You have the perfect balance between everything while you are teaching. I was never bored and enjoyed the lessons a lot. I learned a lot - more here than at any other camp I have been at. Thank you so much for coming and encouraging me so much. " - 16 year old female

These programs mean a great deal to the kids and their parents. The impact will be felt for generations to come! 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help Club 4th by becoming a faithful prayer warrior or by joining a team and going on a trip. I would love to see you on a trip! You will be changed forever and will recieve more than you give!

story:
Hello everyone my name is Selina and I live in Howard County Md. I am doing a cut a thon to support the Howard County Autism Society. 

Your donation will support families in Howard County who are living with a loved one with autism.  There is no known cause of autism, and no cure.  Autism affects individuals without regard to race, ethnicity, social boundaries, family income, lifestyle, or educational level.  Autism affects each individual differently.  Some individuals are deeply affected and require constant supervision, some are non-verbal and extremely anti-social, and others may have limited understanding of what is being said. Still others, characterized as high functioning, have excellent verbal and communication skills and may have an extremely high intellect.  

Notably, the prevalence of autism eclipses every other childhood disease. In 2012, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) adjusted the prevalance of autism from 1 in 110, to 1 in 88.  Howard County itself has become a destination for families of children with autism spectrum disorders.  Consequently the county has the highest incidence of autism in the state at 1 in 73 (vs. 1 in 88 nationally).  

 I am a mom of a three year old daughter and we live in Howard County. The Howard County Autism Society has helped us so much and I would like to help them raise more funds so that they can help others as much as they have helped us.

The Hair Salon event will take place on October 13th at Absolute Hair Design located at 2470 Longstone Lane, Suite D, Marriottsville, MD.  I have recruited 13 stylists who will, FOR FREE, cut the hair of children with autism, from 10:00 am to 12:00pm.  Then at noon it’s time to turn the salon over to the adults for two hours.  Adults may elect to procure a number of services at a reduced rate, including: Cuts with blow dry, Shampoo & blow dry, Seated 30 minute massage, Manicures, Eyebrow wax, and Cuts for Men and children.

Your support for this fundraising effort is greatly appreciated.  Thank you for your interest in helping individuals living with autism,

story:
Summary of La Catalina Foundation, A.C.

  • We are a Mexican non-profit established in 2004.  In just under a decade, with our invisible wand and the heart and hands of many people, La Catalina has performed educational miracles that have changed the lives of young and old alike in La Manzanilla, Jalisco---a village nestled on the beautiful Pacific Coast.
  • We provide a wide range of free educational opportunities for our underprivileged residents, in a town where only 1/3 of the teens finishing middle school went on to high school and only 1 in 25 youth went to university.  Now those stats are changing quickly, with the development of our Educational Center and over 30 youth a year that receive scholarships from our foundation!
  • With the Educational Center we built in 2006, where classes and training are totally free of charge, residents now have a place they can go and improve their skills in a wide range of areas, including learning English, developing artistic skills, receiving tutoring and more!   
  • The latest project at our Center is setting up a computer literacy lab and that’s where WE NEED YOUR HELP to make this dream come to its fruition!!!  With a generous donation of $10,000 that the Foundation already received in April of 2013, we are currently reconditioning a classroom to set it up as a computer lab and will be able to buy an estimated first 5 computers for the lab.  But this is not enough computers to serve our community. We still need an additional 10 computers, software and other equipment for the lab to make it fully functional. 
  • Your donation will help our disadvantaged Mexican youth be able to enter the wider universe of technology and adults that are just as eager to learn, too!

What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to raise $5500US in just 30-days to be able to finish setting up the computer literacy lab.  This $5500US will pay for:

  • 10 desktop computers @ $450US each=$4500US
  • $1000US software and computer set up costs

You can be a part of this project, by making a donation to our Foundation! 

Even if we don’t make $5500 in 30-days, every dollar you donate will go towards buying as many computers as we can!  This is a sure-fire project, as the lab is scheduled to open in mid June of 2013, but in order to serve the community and be able to start classes and training there, we NEED to complete the project by raising the funds for the additional computers.

The Impact

La Catalina Foundation currently has 32 students who receive a scholarship to attend high school and college and many of these kids would have already dropped out of school without this critical support.  Scholarships to high school are needed, as there is currently no high school in our town, so it is costly and difficult for teens to go to one of the neighboring high schools, 30 minutes away. 

These students are now required to do their school work on computers, but most don’t have access to computers and can’t afford to be paying an hourly rental fee to use them. Many get discouraged, as you will see in our video, and even drop out because they feel they can’t keep up with their homework without a computer.

So you can change lives and keep the youth in school by helping complete our computer literacy lab.  The lab will also give adults who have minimal education a chance to chance to develop computer literacy skills and opening their world to wider horizons and more employment opportunities.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • You can use Indiegogo share tools!

story:
George V. Plymyer, age 60, passed away on October 18, 2012 surrounded by his family.   George was born on August 27, 1952 in Unionville, PA to Marian [Smedley] Baker and George V. Plymyer. He graduated from Unionville High School in 1972 where he met the love his life, his“sweatheart” Roo [Leslie Wilford] Plymyer. George and Roo were married in 1974.

 

George and Roo moved to Arden and raised their family. An outdoorsman and renaissance man, he enjoyed fishing and hunting with his sons and sharing the skills his father had taught him. George and Roo later moved to Claymont, Delaware, but often talked about moving back to the Arden woods where 2 of their sons reside with their families.

 

    George was consummate collector and trader, rarely seen without his trademarked red crusher hat. He loved to explore flea markets, thrift stores and antique shops for tackle, knives and camping tools. With a fine eye for quality and detail, George was always able to see the treasures among the trash.

 

    George was a kind and gentle man who went out of his way to help others, most importantly his family. He would often tell stories of his adventures helping someone after only just meeting them. George was also involved in the Arden community and served on the board of directors for the Arden Swim Club.

 

    George is preceded by his father, George V. Plymyer. He is survived by his devoted wife of 38 years Roo; his children, Seth and his wife Michelle, George V. III “Co-D” and his wife Heather, Perry and his wife Jennifer, and Quinn; grandchildren, Madison and Tyler Matera, and Mikala and Ami Plymyer; and his mother, Marian [Smedley] Baker. He is also survived by his honorary children Scott Brumbaugh and Julia Kline Fagnilli and nieces, nephews, cousins and many friends.

 

    Relatives and friends are invited to a send-off gathering in honor of George at the Buzz Ware Village Center on November 17, 2012 from 12pm to 3pm. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to a trust for George’s youngest son Quinn, age 16. For details, please go to INDIEGOGO.COM and search for the Plymyer campaign.

 

    Recently described by his son Co-D as my “Man with The Yellow Hat, but Pop wore a red hat” (a reference to "Curious George"), George was most loved by his family for being a leader and one who would always help them through challenging times.

 

     The loss of a great man has left us with heavy hearts. The world has lost an amazing person who cared more for others than himself. He leaves us with a desire to be more like him, to somehow be better because ofhim and fortunate for having shared a moment with this gentle soul. Thankful for the lessons he taught us and sad for the future without him in it. Ours is a promise to never forget, to honor and continue to love in its purist form. You will forever be in our hearts for you have left footprints on our souls...peaceful rest is yours now Pappa Daddy. ♥

story:
Contrary to popular belief, economics is surprisingly easy to grasp as it is simply the study of everyday life. I wrote EconRhymes to make economics accessible to all by removing the formulas, calculations and jargon and presenting it in a format that, literally, a child can understand.

The economy plays a tremendous role in our lives and is the subject of heated conversations among pundits and politicians. But most people, thinking that economics is too complex, do not even attempt to understand it.

Unfortunately, this lack of understanding leads voters to support policies and make daily decisions that run against their financial well being. People know this and desperately want to educate themselves.
 
Taking a note from the great ancient Greek and Chinese teachers, the book explains all that there is to know about economics using the most effective method, poetry.

An e-book has already been published on amazon (click for a free copy to see how it's fun, easy to read and informative) and received glowing praise, including a public endorsement by head of Harvard Economics, Greg Mankiw. However, to make EconRhymes fully accessible, I am asking for your help to publish a completely illustrated physical book. EconRhymes was written to cater to teenagers, to their school libraries and to their parents. Illustrations will therefore go a long way towards grabbing their interest.
 
A poetry book on economics is a novel idea that will surely generate media buzz. The world is demanding EconRhymes, lets work together towards supplying it!
 
 
 
 

The goal is to make economics accessible. This will be reflected in the content and physical attributes of EconRhymes.

Poetry: Issues are presented through poems. Since antiquity poems have been the most effective way to teach memorable lessons.

Illustrations: World renowed children's book illustrator Matthew Foltz-Gray has agreed to fully illustrate the book. His extreme attention to detail and lively images will attract both yound and old.

Dimensions: Size and feel (square) of a small coffee table book (30 pages) to encourage owners to show off the book to friends and family.

 

EconRhymes' target audience are teenagers.

We expect school and municipal libraries to be big buyers since they have tons of illustrative educational books on science and history, but none on economics and personal finance (since none have been published until now).

We expect parents to buy EconRhymes to their children to not only teach them about economics but also personal finance.

However, the reception of the eBook clearly shows that adults appreciate EconRhymes as well. Head of Harvard Economics, Greg Mankiw, recommended it to hard core economists on his blog and many other people mentionned how fun and easy to understand it is. I sincerly believe that many journalists will write and talk about EconRhymes, with a bit of promotion, as it is so innovative.

 

- Every poem has been written (free copy, click link).

- World renowed children illustrator Matthew Foltz-Gray has agreed to work on the book.

 

- Pay the illustrator

- Pay an editor to insure that adheres to all applicable commercial standards.

- Pay for publishing and distribution.

- Promote the book.

 

- Publish an illustrated interactive e-book.

- Print more copies.

 

 

This book, the first of its kind, will help many people, especially young people, to navigate through these rough economic times.

Please talk to friends, co-worker and family about the crowdsourcing campaign, and promote the book abong your social circle once it gets published. Mention us on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Google+ or any other social media platform.

And please please do not hesitate to contact me for more information,

Thank you very much,

Kasole Nyembo

story:
Short Summary:

“Say YES to CHES” is a campaign spear-headed by Upakriti (www.upakriti.org) to raise funds that would bring new school bags to 93 orphaned-children in India, affected by AIDS. These children belong at CHES (www.cheschennai.org), a non-profit shelter-home in Chennai, India.

About us:

Upakriti is a U.S. based nonpolitical, nonreligious, charitable nonprofit organization. We are organized and operated exclusively for charitable purposes under the U.S. Internal Revenue Code, Section 501(c) (3).

Our mission is to ensure education continuity for underprivileged children in India. We believe in education as a cause, because it is the greatest gift you could give to a child and to build a better tomorrow for the country & the world. Every child on the planet deserves an education and no dearth of health or wealth should stand in the way.

 Upakriti makes all grants on a non-discriminatory basis using an objective set of selection criteria. We have been supporting CHES and other similar organizations & their causes for the past nine years. Some of the past projects we have successfully been able to champion can be found at http://upakriti.org/projects/past-projects/. All US based donations to Upakriti are tax-deductible in the U.S. (Tax Id: 75-3141599)

 

What We Need & What You Get:

Our goal is to raise a total of $600 to purchase 93 school bags by July 31, 2013.“Say YES to CHES” is a cause that, we believe deeply in. This cause aligns with Upakriti’s mission. We are inspired by the passion & integrity in CHES and its founder Dr. P. Manorama. She and her team have been working relentlessly over the past several years to make a huge difference in the lives of children affected by AIDS.

You would have the simple, yet beautiful pleasure of having impacted a child’s life when they start school in summer.

We have chosen a flexible funding channel on indiegogo.com which means that if we don't reach our $ goal within the stipulated time and date, 9% of the whatever was collected up until the point, would be paid as a hosting-fee and only the remaining would go to CHES. As a result, some of these children may not get their new bags. But we hope that our campaign is successful in raising this amount, so the funds reach the most deserving recipients.

 
The Impact:

If we make this deadline, CHES will be able to purchase these school-bags for all the children in time. They wait in anticipation as the clock ticks down. This campaign would add meaning to their everyday lives and make them happier and cheerful so they forget their real battles everyday, against AIDS, discrimination and poverty for a little while. These smiles are priceless. Isn't it every child's dream? to have a new school bag when they go to school after the holidays? :)

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Some of you may not be able to donate at the moment, but we know that, that doesn’t mean you don't want to help. Below are a few other ways you could help.

  • Help this campaign by getting the word out, share the link with your friends and ask them to share with their friends for maximum outreach.
  • If you wish to help CHES in other ways, do reach out to us and we will guide you. Every bit counts, every ounce of love has a deserving recipient.
  • If you wish to support any of Upakriti’s other initiatives, write to us at Upakriti@upakriti.org and we will involve you in such opportunities.
  • We encourage you to use the Indiegogo share tools to share our campaign.

story:
Short Summary

Mercury Astronaut Scott Carpenter imagined living under the sea long before Spongebob Squarepants.  So he did (but never in a pineapple.)  Instead, his first time under the sea (in Sealab) was in 1965, where he proved he had the right stuff (again) and broke the record of human underwater habitation for an entire 30 days.  (There's a funny tale about the President of the United States calling him thereafter and Carpenter sounding like Donald Duck from the decompression chamber he was hanging out in at the time, but that's another story.  Google it.)

Flash forward a few years, and imagine an important space-related artifact named after Carpenter languishing in a warehouse.  That's what we discovered a few months ago when we found the Scott Carpenter Station.  "You want it, you can have it" said NASA to us (we're the Space Foundation, an international non-profit headquartered in Colorado Springs.)

  • We've been around since 1983. 
  • Our Space Foundation Discovery Center just opened in October 2012 and is already out of room!
  • We're in the process of doubling our physical footprint so we can show even more space artifacts and educational exhibits.
  • Support this and you'll be part of something big, actually preserving history for kids to see and learn from. 

What We Need

The Station is in pretty rough shape right now.  The two floation/viewing tubes are a mess -- one was hacksawed off of the Station, the other is partially broken.

Good news!  The interior is in pretty darned good shape and won't need a lot of work.

The exterior needs to be repaired where it's rusted, and the whole thing needs a good professional paint job to restore it to how it looked back in the day.

We also need to have an exhibit fabricated where the Station will be displayed.

What You Get!

Research says that giving stimulates the brain's production of oxytocin, a feel-good hormone.  So first of all, you'll feel great!

Seriously, though, check out the perks (below) and know that EVERBODY who participates in this effort will be listed in our annual report and on-line (unless you tell us otherwise.)  And because the Space Foundation is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, your donation is tax deductable to the extent allowed by law.

Impact

Our goal is to inspire kids -- especially girls and underserved kids -- to pursue careers in STEM (science, technology, engineering, mathematics) -- this is where innovation STEMs from.  It's good for the economy, it's good for our country, and it's just plain good. 
 
Since the Discovery Center opened in October 2012, we've had nearly 10,000 visitors (and we've only been open two days a week.)  This summer, we'll be open five days a week (Tuesdays through Saturdays). Once Phase II is completed (late this year) we anticipate even more visitors.  
 
And, the Carpenter exhibit will also be used to teach kids underwater robotics as it will be surrounded by a pool of water (the Station won't be in the water itself).

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't give, we understand...you can still help! 

Share our campaign with your social networks., your friends and families.

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

THANKS!

story:
Hello,

My name is Benjamin Dralle and I am the President of GLBT Books, an Oregon-registered nonprofit organization which is acting as the funding arm for Stonewall University.

...and what is Stonewall University?

Stonewall University is the nation's first institution of higher learning for oppressed sexual minorities and their allies. Conceptualized 15 years ago by internationally recognized researcher Robin Mathy, Stonewall was established as a domestic nonprofit corporation in the State of Oregon last year.

We need your help to build its campus.

Here's why:

Did you know 20% of homeless youth are gay, lesbian, bisexual, or transgender? According to the National Coalition for the Homeless, lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender homeless youth complete suicide at a significantly higher rate (62%) than non-LGBT homeless youth (29%). The (nonpartisan) National Alliance to End Homelessness reported, "The major reasons homeless youth cite for remaining homeless include lack of affordable housing options, incomplete education, inaccessible job market, and on-going drug use". All of these problems can be addressed with a GLBTQ university modeled after historically black colleges and historically women's colleges.

Here's how you can help.

Please make all your online purchases through glbtbookstore.com by clicking on our Amazon link. Here's how it works:
GLBT Books has become an independent affiliate of Amazon.com. As an affiliate of Amazon.com, every purchase made through this website earns up to an 8.5% commission. One hundred percent (100%) of all commissions go directly to Stonewall University. GLBT Books's operating costs are acquired through donations and fundraising events, with all proceeds above operating costs going to Stonewall University.

One of the great economic transitions in our era is the increasing number of consumers making online purchases, quite possibly including you. "Internet Retailer" cited eMarketer in reporting that the number of consumers making online purchases is expected to increase to over 200 million by 2015. If just one million people make online purchases of $100 per year, Stonewall University will earn the millions needed to buy land and begin building the brick-and-mortar structures that will BUILD OUR FUTURE.

A single purchase may not seem like much, just as a drop of water may appear rather inconsequential on its own. However, collectively each sale is another drop that swells with others to become a powerful sea of change that will save lives and build our future.

 

Right now, we are in the process of obtaining 501(c)3 status.  In order to accomplish this feat, we need $850 and your voices to spread the word about what we are doing to build Stonewall University.  Your financial support doesn't have to be any more than $5, so please help if you can.

Have questions about Stonewall University or would like to make a donation? Contact us:

ben.dralle@glbtbookstore.com, www.stonewalluniversity.org, or send us a letter addressed to:

GLBT Books
1900 NE 3rd St., Ste. 106-18
Bend, Oregon 97701
(our registry number is 860555-98)

story:
My name is Bill Westerman, I have been friends with Abhishek Yonghang Subba's family since they were resettled in this country from Nepalese refugee camps where they had lived for 18 years.  They were originally from Bhutan but were expelled along with over 100,000 other ethnic Nepalis in 1990-1992.  I met Abhi when he was still in 8th grade, writing a research paper about genocide!


Both Abhishek and his friend Bhola Koirala arrived in this country a few years ago after being born and raised in the camps in eastern Nepal, camps which I have visited and which had no electricity and only basic K-12 education.  When they came they didn't speak any English, but both have excelled in the sciences and engineering. 


As part of a class project they have designed and constructed a robotic arm.  Bhola just graduated from Patterson High School in Baltimore, and Abhishek will be a senior in the fall.  They qualified statewide in Maryland for the national Skills USA Robotics and Automation Technology Contest, to be held this year in Kansas City, but the Baltimore school district has no money to send them there.


Their teacher, Mr. Nick Yates, has offered to drive them from Baltimore to Kansas City for the competition.  He also obtained a travel scholarship for them but they will still need about $750 to stay in the official hotel with the other competitors for the week of the competition, pay for food and other travel expenses.


As someone who teaches in summer programs for exceptional high school students, I know how valuable these competitions can be for outstanding students, not only for what they learn from fellow students and teachers at the competition, but quite simply as a credential they can put on their college applications.  It's a tragedy that school districts like Baltimore no longer have the funds to help their most outstanding students have the opportunities that affluent suburban high school students can take for granted.  So I've launched this campaign to invest in the future of these two promising and creative young minds.

story:
Hi,

 

My name is Crystal, I am 33 years old and I am looking for funding to help me work with ME sufferers, a subject that is very close to my heart.

 

ME, also known as Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, is an illness that I suffered from for 6 years from the age of 19 to 25. Those of you who know of the illness will understand how debilitating this illness is, those of you who don’t…well this is my story.

 

I was a bright, energetic, happy and passionate young woman full of dreams and goals for my future as a budding singer and dancer that had even had interest from Polydor record label. Sadly at the age of 19 I was struck down by a very sudden and extreme illness…ME. At first I didn’t understand what was happening to me and with little help from the doctors, who prescribed anti-depressants, I gradually deteriorated. It started with panic attacks, light sensitivity, body aches and coldness and numbness of the limbs to the extent of even tripping over my own feet. This then lead to extreme and relentless exhaustion that couldn’t be relieved by sleep, I would wake up in the morning and at best would walk down the stairs to lie on the sofa all day before returning to my bed again that night. At this stage I would refer to myself as the living dead, alive, but unable to take part in any kind of life, this was the worst stage it got to for me, but some sufferers end up in wheelchairs.

 

In 1999, when I fell ill, ME was little known and often scoffed at and referred to as Yuppie Flu (an ignorant term originating in the US Media). I remember people asking what was wrong with me, was I depressed and perhaps I needed more sleep. At this stage I decided to withdraw myself from the life I had known and go into hiding so that I didn’t have to constantly try and explain something I didn’t really understand myself.

 

Through living a gentle and healthy life and being cared for by my mum and boyfriend I managed to make a very slow recovery and by the age of 25 I found myself able to be back in full time employment and living in London with the idea of resuming my dream of following my passion for singing. This was short lived and I found myself 3 years down the line at 28 years old with full blown ME again. I couldn’t believe it, my whole life was being ripped away again, I was back living with my mum and unable to work. I felt that I couldn’t do this again and if I had to I would rather be dead. Thankfully My mum came across a flyer advertising something called the ‘Lightning Process’ it claimed that by using this process you could become ME free in as little as 3 days. This sounded very radical to me, but there was a testimonial by Esther Ranson (a British talk show host), that this process had helped her daughter recover, so I thought, hey I’ve got nothing to lose, and gave them a call. After having completed the process I was back in London within 1 month, working full time and living the life I loved again. I couldn’t believe my luck!

 

Through discovering this process and having this life tool available to me I have reclaimed my life and I want other sufferers to be able to do the same. I would like to study this programme to become a Practitioner of this process, so that I can dedicate my life to helping sufferers regain theirs

 

ME strikes people of all ages (including very young children and very old people) from all social classes. There seems to be more women than men with ME and the reasons for this are not known. One thing is true of the vast majority of people with ME - they want to get better. The idea that people with this illness somehow ‘want to be ill’ or that they are ‘malingering’ is absolute nonsense. Most of them had an active enjoyable lifestyle before becoming ill and would like nothing more than to return to it.

 

ME patients suffer in silence and withdrawing from society, never living a full and happy life. It isn’t uncommon for people to suffer this debilitating illness for 10 years or more, some never recover at all, this truly is a wasted life. After having lived through this myself and knowing how to recover quickly, I feel I have to share this knowledge and want so much to be part of spreading the word of this amazing training that is being offered. My life’s mission now is to help others recover as I have done and regain the life they loved and lost.

 

My goal is to study a diploma in NLP and Hypnotherapy, complete a master Practitioner certificate in NLP and then go on to train in the ‘Lightning Process’ (aptly named due to the speed of recovery) at the Phil Parker Training Institute. This process will take a year and will cost me £5,000. On completion of the course, I plan to set myself up as a practitioner and help spread the word of this amazing life tool, by helping ME sufferers to recover.

 

Please help me fund this course, it is an extremely worthy cause and will help so many people reclaim the lives they lost…I know at least 7 sufferers, how many do you know?


Here is an interesting article printed in the Guardian, it just shows how unsupported ME sufferers really are http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/a...

story:
What is Youth Lemonade Day?

The National CEO Leadership Institute, Inc. ("NCLI") provides education and training to youth and adult entrepreneurs.  This year, in collaboration with the Franklin County Economic Development and Planning Agency, NCLI is sponsoring  and coordinating Youth Lemonade Day on July 19, 2014. 

Youth Lemonade Day is about providing kids of all ages the opportunity to both learn about and experience entrepreneurship by planning, starting, owning, funding, and operating their own business:  a lemonade stand.

NCLI is raising funds that will be given to the participating children as seed capital to start their lemonade stands.  As we all know, it takes money to make money.  The youth will need to obtain materials to build their lemonade stands and signs, as well as supplies to make and serve the lemonade. 

Youth Lemonade Day is important because it gives the participating youth access to a fun and educational summer activity that can teach them life-long lessons about entrepreneurship.  

The Youth Lemonade Day Seed Capital Campaign is important because many of the youth in Franklin County are in low to moderate income households and may not have access to the modest amount of funds needed to start a lemonade stand.  It is important that we reach and provide this valuable educational experience to as many children as we can.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is what we need and what you get:

  • We need $5,000 that will be divided among the participating youth. We expect at approximately 250 youth to participate in the seed capital program by submitting a short video explaining their lemonade stand idea and what they will do with the seed capital. 
  • Your support is very important to us and the children.
  • The rewards ranging from a "Lemonade Shout Out" to "Youth Lemonade Day T-Shirts" to "Customized Sponsorship Packages" that you will receive for your contributions.  So, in addition to some good lemonade, our goal is to make this a sweet deal for everyone!   
  • The funds we raise fund the seed capital pool and gets distributed to the children.  If we do not reach our goal, the funds are still distributed to the children, however, the amount available to each child will be reduced.
     

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute to the seed capital campaign right now, you can still help us out:

  • You can get the word out and make some noise about Youth Lemonade Day and the Youth Lemonade Day Seed Capital Campaign.
  • Share it with your family and friends via email, on Facebook, Twitter, Google+, and other social media. 
  • You can also tell people about it and ask them to look us up on Indiegogo.com. 

We thank you for all that you do to support Youth Lemonade Day Seed Capital Campaign.

education and training to youth and adult entrepreneurs.  This year, in

story:
The Just Let Me Learn Foundation

My mom and I started the Just Let Me Learn Foundation in 2007 after she joined me on a business trip to India. We saw firsthand that there were kids who didn't have the opportunity to go to school. We could see that the lack of this basic right perpetuated the vicious cycle of poverty.

Over the last seven years we have been organizing and raising funds to help. Our foundation has purchased two School Buses in Patna, built a  Tutoring Center in Chanduali, completed our first full school in Saiphai, and broke ground on our second school in Sesawng. The Sesawng School was our first Indiegogo campaign! 244 awesome people donated over $65,000 allowing us to break ground on phase, April 21 2014.

Our two village schools are located in the state of Mizoram in the Northeastern mountains of India. This Girls Dorm campaign is to address an important need for girls in Saiphai.

Saiphai School

On April 21, 2014 we were thrilled to be in Saiphai to celebrate the opening of our first school!  576 children from pre-kindergarden to 10th grade started school on that day. It was one of the most rewarding experiences of our lives. This gorgeous orange school with a bright blue roof, located on the top of the mountain, had become the beacon of hope for this village. Over 1,200 people attended the opening, including the head of Education for the state of Mizoram, 14 head masters from other village schools located all over the country, as well as family and friends of the students from Sesawng and surrounding village. It was truly amazing!

Saiphai Girls Dorm

This campaign is to raise funds to build a girls dorm in Saiphia to house 60 girls who live too far away to attend school. Our goal is to raise $30,000 for the first building to house the first 30 girls. Our stretch goal is raise $30,000 more for the second building for the next 30. Below is the latest design for the first dorm building.

In this part of India, most of the parents have limited or no schooling. They live hand to mouth. Many of the homes are huts made of bamboo and they make their living with manual labor and agricultural work such as sugar cane harvesting and other things that they can gather and sell in the markets. The children in the family are a big part of surviving. Many of the kids become the heads of the house when the parents must go into the fields, sometimes for days or weeks at a time. The kids cook, clean and protect. Some as young as 5. We found this boy cooking breakfast in their hut for his two brothers. Their parents were not there.

If the kids have a chance to go to school, the parents usually need to make a choice between boys and girls. They usually pick the boys because the girls are considered property. Meaning that they are eventually going to be married off to another family, and become their property. Their rational is they should invest in the boys education because they will be around longer to help the family survive.

Another shocking trend that is happening in northeastern India is the targeting of village girls for human trafficking, i.e., sex trade. Since most of these parents are illiterate, traffickers will entice the girls with the allure of non-village life, and convince the families that their daughters will have more opportunities if they move to the city and get jobs as housemaids and nannies. They offer more money than the can make in the villages and promise that they will send money back to help the parents. The reality is that many of these girls are delivered into the hands of pimps in these cities and forced into the sex trade. This is something we have to stop.

Below is a picture with Dean, the headmaster and the 10th grade class at the Saiphai School. The Saiphia Girls Dorm will enable girls in remote villages to live at the Saiphai school and be a part of this incredible community. They will be away from the pressure put on them at home. This means they will be allowed to focus on studies, surrounded by other girls who also want to learn. Teachers, dorm parents and other adults will be there to help them learn. This will also keep them out of reach of these traffickers. They will have time to be kids.


A Brick In The Wall

With this $100 perk, a personalized brick with two lines of 14 characters each will be included in the Girls Dorm Building. This $100 actually funds 20 real bricks used in the construction, along with the cement, sand, plaster and all other materials and labor that go into making the dormitory. We will send you a picture of the dorm and your brick after the opening in 2015!

Just Let Me Learn Jacket

As you can see from our two very hip models, this perk gives you a stylish jacket just in time for the fall. Wear you jacket with pride knowing that your contribution helped change the lives of children in Saiphai and surrounding villages. 


Fund A School Desk, Change A Life

One of the most inspiring perks in this campaign is the My Just Let Me Learn Desk. You can fund a desk and change a life. Our goal is to personalize all 750 desks for the Saiphai Children attending the school every year. Each Just Let Me Learn desk will be personalized with the donors name (if desired) and a 140 character personal "tweet". Imagine that every day a child ail sit at that desk and read your message. Every year, a new child will sit in that desk and be touched by the same thing.

Can you remember someone that significantly changed your life with a few simple words? If you could go back and tell your 10 year old self something, what would it be? That's the power of these 140 characters. 

Commemorative Coin

We have created a number of unique perks for this campaign, but one of our favorites is the coin. This is a high quality silver dollar size coin that says "I Helped Build The Saiphai School". You can see the final one that we created for our first Sesawng Campaign below.



We Need Your Help

Just because you may not be able to contribute cash, doesn't mean that you can't help. We would ask for you to use the Indiegogo share tools located below the video to propagate the campaign. Every tweet, +1, Facebook Like, and email sent via the .  The more eyes on the project, the  more opportunity for us to reach the "GoGo Factor". If Indiegogo sees that you have reached the GoGo factor, you will be added to their marking campaign.  The GoGo factor is  a sum total of how engaged people are with your campaign. All social media and related page view boost our Gogo Factor score. So please, share it everywhere, but make sure you are using your Indiegogo tools after you login so we can attribute referrals and donations from the seeds you planted.

story:
My Name is Afrikanus Kofi Akosah, I'm the President of Africa Youth Peace Call, a pro-liberty organisation dedicated to the study and advancement of classical liberalism (libertarianism) and lassaiz-faire capitalism (free enterprise) in Africa. We try to change peoples’ ideas, opinions, and mode of thinking by research, seminars and publications. AYPC wants to become the leading organisation in the freedom education of young people in Africa.

  With the generous support of adherents of Liberty like you, we have been organizing the Liberty & Entrepreneurship Camps for college students & anyone who cares to discover new ideas since 2008. The Week long seminars expose students to the Philosophy of Liberty & Entrepreneurship Skills as the means to wealth creation. Our focus is to prepare participants to start businesses & institutions for policy reforms.

This Winter we’re collaborating with the Liberty Brigade a Pro-Liberty group founded by some Alumni of the Liberty & Entrepreneurship Camp to move the camp to Eastern Ghana.

The Goal Post is Shifting! Gradually Africans are beginning to understand the role of individual Freedom & Liberty in ensuring prosperity. Donating towards the Winter Session which is scheduled from 4-9 January, 2015 in the Eastern City of Koforidua will strengthen the drive to free Africa.

We need $12,000 to provide accommodation, Food, Transport & Learning materials at the Lakeside for 40 students throughout the week. Students are contributing half of the cost with half coming from your kind donations.  Help us Demystify Poverty & Tyranny in Africa. 

Line-up teachers include Prof. Steve Horwitz, Dr. Tom G. Palmer,  Dr. Lawrence Reed, Prof. Ken Schoolland, Kwadwo Afari, Jacob Hornberger, Rui Nobre Pinheiro, Afrikanus Kofi Akosah, Dan Mclaughlin, Olumayowa Okediran, Akwasi Adusei, Lode Cossaer, Chris Lingle, Gregory V. Diehl, Noel Berge, Max Borders, Jeffrey Tucker etc.. Some of them will be at the location whilst others will teach via video conference.

600 friends of Liberty donating $10 each will see us through. Don't forget, if you can't donate you can spread the word. Thank you good people!
