story:
With your contribution 

I will complete the OneTaste Coaching and Orgasmic Meditation (OM) Trainer program. This will allow me to supporting my clients to:

• Experience more intimacy and aliveness in sex

• Feel viscerally connected to others

• Understand and express their desire

• Identify and integrate their shadow 

• Engage and move through confronting situations

• Approach relationships with greater curiosity, creativity, and depth

• Communicate powerfully in and outside of the bedroom

• Cultivate energy and responsiveness that inspires every area of their lives

• Move through the fear, shame and taboo that arise with sex

• Learn the OM practice step-by-step

• Understand sexual anatomy and clitoral mapping

• Troubleshoot OM problem areas, including posture, stroking and finding the spot

• Develop an OM practice routine that works

• Understand and integrate key OM exercises

• Communicate effectively during the practice

• Expand their capacity to feel and pay attention in OM and life

What Turns Me On?

I dream of a world filled with more intimacy & personal connection. A time where everyone is comfortable living from a place of desire...

I teach a coupled sensuality practice called Orgasmic Meditation (OM). It is a daily sexual meditation where two people intensely put their attention on each other for 15 minutes in a very specific way. This practice teaches women to come more into their sexuality and men to begin to identify and name their visceral sensations. By balancing these polls men and women can move forward together, more powerfully.

I found Orgasmic Meditation about a year ago and before I even experienced my first OM I signed up to take the training course! After reading just the basic information about this practice I quickly understood how it could transform my life, to fill the void that I had been longing to fill with a lover. I also immediately knew I wanted to share this with the world because there's not one person I know that doesn't want more intimacy and connection!

After taking the OM Training course I began teaching the practice. It was around the holidays last year that I began training sessions with friends to fulfill my hours for certification - and what a blast I was having! I got to witness people turn on to the possibilities of Orgasmic Meditation. As I explained the philosophy and tenets of OM and brought them through the steps of OM, I could see them begin to apply a regular practice to their lives (in their minds) and light up with delight. After just an hour of training, my clients were already turned on!

But that's just not enough!

I quickly realized that teaching the Orgasmic Meditation Practice is not enough for me to truly hold space, a large enough container, for my clients. My clients want more from me and I really want to deliver! This is why I'm heading back down to OneTaste in San Francisco to take the Coaching Program. It is a 10 month program that will give me the tools to guide my clients through the unique maze of sexuality, intimacy, connection, and living from a completely turned on place of existence!

 

What has Orgasmic Meditation opened up for me?

I used to think I was a turned on woman, completely powerful in my sexuality. I stood, unwavering, if anyone wanted to speak about sex. I was righteous in my beliefs about what good sex and sexual relations were. I gave very sage advise to anyone (and there were many) who would ask me sexual questions. I innately knew what great sex/relation was supposed to look like, I just wasn't experiencing it! I was in a place of lack & frustration, but hopeful...

After just 9 months of consistent OMing

I was finally able to stop blaming others for my lack of satisfaction, lack of communication skills that I needed to express my desires, and my lack of intimacy. I've taken responsibility of my ability to receive pleasure. I stopped looking for love in all the wrong places and began filling myself up by OMing. Now that I'm filled up to running over, I can say that I am truly a Turned On woman! My ability to experience pleasure has increased and continues to do so. The expansive orgasm that is created within the OM feeds and energizes me throughout the day. I live my life using my desire as a compass.

I solve problems in a new and exciting way... one can apply anything that they would like to work on or practice or get better at to an OM. OM is an opportunity to work on it in the safe container, get good at it, and then take it out to the real world with confidence!

There is a communication skill set that is used in Orgasmic Meditation that is priceless. It's simple and effective, clean and concise, easy to understand and interpret. I practice it in my daily OMs and use it in all ares of my life, with the greatest of ease! (well, I'm getting there!)

Now that I'm full I don't feel needy, graspy, or desperate. When I stopped feeling those ways a personal relationship dropped into my life that is wonderful. We have an OM practice and it has been a great foundation for connection and intimacy, sexual exploration and communication. It has opened so many conversations that may not have ever been discussed, but by digging into our desires, fears, resistance and willingness we have gone really deep in a short period of time. It's beautiful and I'm so grateful.

How Much and Why?

I need $10,000. I've already placed a large deposit. I'm committed! Most of the money will go towards the rest of my tuition. I will also need gas, food and lodging while I'm attending the program. I need to make up for some lost time from work. It is a ten month program in which I will be spending one long weekend in San Francisco per month at an intensive and I will participate in a couple tele courses per month from home. There will be people from all over the globe joining us in San Francisco in person and via satellite.

Anything will help!

I am only comfortable asking for money because this site allows me to give back in the way of perks. Please take a look at the donation values and associated perks to decide how you would like to help me embark on this journey. I'll thank you, in advance, for anything you may be able to do to help.

See pictures of the non OM related perks, such as the Buddha Sculpture, journals, jewelry and cookbooks on the gallery page.

The best way to help is for you to share this with your friends.

Help me take this to the outer edges of my circle of influence by passing along the link. The more people that know about this and donate, the more I'll get to ignite female orgasm and turn on within the community! I'm so grateful! Find the easy share options above.

(See a longer, more detailed video on the gallery page)

It has opened so many conversations that may not have ever been discussed, but by digging into our desires, fears, resistance and willingness we have gone really deep in a short period of time. It's beautiful and I'm so grateful.
How Much and Why?
I need $10,000. I've already placed a large deposit. I'm committed! Most of the money will go towards the rest of my tuition. I will also need gas, food and lodging while I'm attending the program. I need to make up for some lost time from work. It is a ten month program in which I will be spending one long weekend in San Francisco per month at an intensive and I will participate in a couple tele courses per month from home. There will be people from all over the globe joining us in San Francisco in person and via satellite.
Anything will help!
I am only comfortable asking for money because this site allows me to give back in the way of perks. Please take a look at the donation values and associated perks to decide how you would like to help me embark on this journey. I'll thank you, in advance, for anything you may be able to do to help.
See pictures of the non OM related perks, such as the Buddha Sculpture, journals, jewelry and cookbooks on the gallery page.
The best way to help is for you to share this with your friends.
Help me take this to the outer edges of my circle of influence by passing along the link. The more people that know about this and donate, the more I'll get to ignite female orgasm and turn on within the community! I'm so grateful! Find the easy share options above.
(See a longer, more detailed video on the gallery page)

story:
I'M GOING!!!

You can follow me here: http://TravelsOfAThinker.tumblr.com.

Short Summary

I was recently accepted into the Harvard Career Discovery program. There, I will be introduced design-based graduate school programs. For six-weeks I would study architecture, landscape architecture, urban planning, and urban design.

If I can make it there, I will be able to see if studies in these fields or other design fields is for me. Or, I'll see if it is just a hobby. Either way, my future studies will be based on this experience.

But before I can become enlightened by the minds at Harvard, I need to get there. That is what you can help me with. And really, any assistance is helpful, monetary or otherwise.

What I Need, The Breakdown, & What You Get

I need monetary assistance. As for my tuition, it might be covered by financial aid but I will not know until later. The rest though, has yet to be covered.

Where the money goes:
  • Campus Housing: $1,190
  • Travel, by plane, there + back: $490
If, on the off chance, I get more money than needed, the extra will go to:
  • Tuition, if I still owe after financial aid comes in
  • Pay for materials there
  • I will ship my bike to Boston
  • Pay off student loans
So what do you get in return?

You get a grateful student, friend, family member, or just plain human. Not the best return on investment, I know. But, it certainly makes a difference in my life. Also, you will get a perk depending on the level of your donation (you can see the levels on the side).

The Impact

This determines my future. No biggie.

A Little About Me

My name is Andrew R McHugh and I am an undergraduate student at Westminster College in Fulton, MO. I am double majoring in Philosophy and the Science of Information; and double minoring in Math and Physics. At school, I work on a conference I started (The "What If...?" Conference), the sustainable living-learning community there (EcoHouse), and a bike sharing initiative. After my time in the undergraduate world, I might go to graduate school or I might go off and do my own thing. If grad school, I could study anything from urban design, to philosophy, to designing systems (and that could be anything), to computer science, to neuroscience, to information systems, to I don't know what. That is why this summer program will help me.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute monetarily, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Tell me where some great places are in the Cambridge/Boston area.
  • Let me crash in your place if you live in the area.
  • Lend me an interesting and helpful book for the six weeks.
  • Tell others about this project. I'd appreciate it!

Word.

story:
WHAT AND WHY

I want to create the first platform of free social content. Nowadays more than ever we need a change; I want to help people to be aware of what is going on on society by offering them valuable and selected information for free. I believe in the books not only as form of knowledge but also as tool to shake, to arouse and to feed the reflection on specially delicate topics that occupy a relevant place today. I hope that Read to react turns into a place of reference to investigators, sociologists and professionals specialized in these areas, as well as for the general public with desire of knowing more and acting in consequence, is our responsability. In parallel I want to organize courses of creative writing that promots the reflection between the people. I think is a great idea, very useful and necessary! I need to collect money to design and create the web that is a bit complicated due to the big amount of manuals,books and articles I want to dowload and to prepare the promotion (create pins and Tshirts). in the beginning will be in Spanish, if goes well we will include material in English.

THE AREAS

· Art Brut · Woman · Corporative Social Responsability (CSR) · Political activity · Trade Fair · Environment · Culture and Cooperation to the development · Alzheimer · Disability · Homosexuality

THE IDEA

1. Providing access to a real  and critical knowledge of the current society by promoting reflection
2. Promote a social positive change through reading
3. Provide a platform for emerging writers and researchers
4. To allow that any interested person has information at minimal cost
5. Create the first social platform as point of meeting
6. Facilitate international and multicultural exchange of ideas and persectives
7. Give visibility to the most neglected social aspects

 WHO IS BEHIND

My name is Ana Vidal Egea. I am a  Summa Cum Laude PhD in Spanish Philology and Journalist. Currently I participate as speaker at conferences, symposia and encounters organized in US and Spain with essays that explore new narratives. I came to Miami to work as project coordinator at the Spanish Cultural Center, I have also worked as Creative Writing Professor at Miami Dade College. Now I want to focus in helping the people throught culture and knowledge. + info: http://anavidalegea.blogspot.com/

story:
About Me:

My name is Kevin James; I am a mathematics student at Portland State University.  I work as a math tutor part time while going to school full time.  My focus goal is to complete my bachelors in mathematics and to obtain my teaching license to teach high school math. 

As part of my goal to teach, I want to be come a better teacher by learning how to bridge gaps, to understand more about learning disabilities and learning barriers that student’s encounter while in their school career.   I also want to learn how to better understand how I can make a difference in those student’s lives.

As part of my studies at Portland State, I have applied and been accepted to this study abroad program and by going on this 2 and a half week trip with the university, I am going to be fully immersed in another culture.  I will be volunteering my time at a service site of either my choosing or of their need.  The options we have currently are working in an orphanage, a school, or on a farm.   However once we arrive, the needs of the community may be different. 

By being immersed in another culture, I will be attempting to speak their language and help with their English curriculum if I am at a school.  Either way, I will be working with people whom I will have to learn to communicate and overcome the barriers that will exist which will help me as a teacher learn and understand how to better work with students from around the world and within my own culture.

I will spend my time during the day working at the service sites and spending the evenings working and studying spanish and the Costa Rican culture and their government.

I will be in Costa Rica from August 27th through September 15th. 

 

*****Update 6/1/2012******

As of yesterday, I have been assigned to a school to work with students assisting in their English Curriculum.  I am very excited and looking forward to meeting all of the people I will be working so closely with.  I can't wait to get down there and learn from them.

What I need and what you get:

 

What I need is the funding to cover the cost of tuition, program fee, the flight, transportation to and from the service site, immunizations, airport exit fee, non-program meals, and some money to bring things with me for the students and for use in the area.

 

Tuition Fees:  Up to $514.00 (covers 6 credits)

Program Fees: $2033

(Covers housing in country, medical insurance, group meals, study abroad $200 fee)

Airfare: approx. $800-$1000 depending on time of purchase

Service Site transportation: $30-$50.00

Immunizations $200

Airport Exit fee $26.00

Non-program meals: $50.00

Spending money: $200.00

 

If I don’t reach my full goal, then the funding I do receive will go to the bare necessities that I will need during the trip, which would be for the flight, the tuition and program fees. 

What I hope you get from helping me take this journey is the enjoyment from knowwing  that you will be contributing to the creation of another well educated and better rounded teacher that will be teaching the children of the future.  I hope you also have the satisfaction from knowing that you helped someone who is trying to work towards embracing diversity and bridging gaps.  I also hope that you get the enjoyment and satisfaction that you are helping me help the community members and students of Costa Rica. 

 

The impact:

I cannot begin to possibly tell you the impact that I feel this trip will have on me.  I already know that it will be a huge life changing experience for me and a once in a lifetime experience as well.  I have spent my life struggling to find my place and I finally feel that I have arrived.  By being a teacher and helping kids, I will be making an impact in their lives.  I feel that being in another country and working with students will truly help me better understand how to reach students from many different avenues. 

I also don’t feel that it is all going to be a personal gain and experience.  I believe the lasting impact and impression that I will have on the students and the residents of Turrialba will be a lasting one.  The service that I will be able to do down there will greatly help the community and build lasting relationships with the students and my host family.  I feel that even more though that they will make a huge impact on me and I will learn a lot from them.

story:
WHY THIS CAMPAIGN

Our nation is facing a crisis in Art education. To satisfy budget cuts, art classes are being eliminated from our schools at an alarming rate. In Churchill County, our elementary schools now have NO art classes. To allow this to happen is to seriously inhibit the development of our children and our future. To remove Art from our communities is to stifle imagination and suppress quality of life. At Rising Sun we believe a community art center can play a vital role in stimulating our citizens, young and old, and in revitalizing our community.

MISSION

Rising Sun Gallery and Art Studios has been created to mitigate the impact of the growing void in Art education. Our primary goal is to keep Art and Art education alive by offering studio workshops where Art instruction is provided in an inclusive, creative and stimulating environment. 

WHAT WE DO

We offer instruction in a wide variety of Art disciplines to bring people together in shared expression, creativity and fellowship. By reaching out to seniors, our local military base, school children, and all others, we aspire to bridge the divide between generations and societal strata, and to re-establish a true sense of community. A gallery space adjoins the studio workshop to display the work of students and promote the work of many talented artists in Nevada and other western states.

WHO WE ARE

The inspiration for and the founder of this enterprise is Patricia Kupferer Sammons, who manages the gallery and workshop activities. Patricia is a working artist and a experienced gallery manager. Our studio instructors are five very talented artists that includes the head of the art department at our Jr. High School. These wonderful individuals are dedicated to providing quality, personalized instruction.

Rising Sun Gallery and Art Studios is a licensed Nevada company that opened on March 6th of this year. We are centrally located in downtown Fallon, Nevada, at 203 South Maine Street. During the past eight months we have received a positive reaction from the community that is demonstrated by increasing enrollment in our classes and gallery Art sales are steadily increasing.

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

Our opening was achieved with a lot of volunteerism, donations and borrowing of essential furnishings, supplies and equipment. Our campaign goal of $50,000 will enable us to replace all the borrowed items, expand the studio workshop area to accomodate community gatherings as well larger classroom space, and make a number of basic interior improvements. We also need to bolster our operating budget so we can engage in proper advertising and promotion campaigns; pay for legal, accounting and grant writing assistance, and be able to pay our key volunteers. If successful this campaign will allow us to expand our classes and strengthen our revenue streams. It will also enable us to continue to keep the cost of our classes at an affordable level for the majority of our community and increase our ability to offer some free classes.

Supporting Art Education here in Fallon will bring lasting benefits to society at large. Each person enriched by the creative experience will likely influence others they meet in a positive way.

Every dollar received will bring us closer to reaching our goals and allows us to maintain our momentum. You can also help by spreading the word. Tell your friends about us and ask them to tell their friends. You can keep in touch with us on Facebook and Gmail at risingsunartgallery@gmail.com

Thanks so much for taking your time to view our campaign.

Happy Holidays and God Bless.

story:
HELP International: Peru

Hello all! My name is Heather Raftery and I am currently pursuing a master’s degree in International Development at the University of Denver in Colorado. The reason I’m pursuing this degree is because I want to dedicate my career, and indeed my life, to the fight against world poverty. As part of my academic growth, I decided to apply for an internship in a developing country doing grassroots development work. Excitingly, I was recently given the opportunity to intern with HELP International (www.help-international.org) in Peru this summer to help local indigenous communities! Through this organization I will be able to help implement sustainable development projects and programs that will increase the level of living and well-being among the people I will serve. It is really a tremendous opportunity… but I need your help!!
 
HELP International is a non-profit organization that works across the globe, empowering local community members by implementing projects that meet basic health, education, and livelihood needs that are not currently being met, and by teaching important skills that can be passed on to others, thereby increasing the sustainability of these projects and programs. Currently HELP International is working with impoverished communities in eight locations around the world—Belize, El Salvador, Fiji, India, Thailand, Uganda, Tanzania, and Peru.
 
Projects vary tremendously and are based on each individual community's assessed need. The projects primarily focus around three major areas of development work: education, health and business development. Last year's projects included: dispersing microloans to local women to start or expand businesses; installing "natural light bulbs" made out of water, bleach and recycled bottles; working with a local orphanage and rehabilitation center; and starting a small-scale reforestation project with "neem" trees, which have a tremendous number of uses. This year we plan on continuing these projects as well as many others, including implementing a "soilet" project to address sanitation needs and improve water quality!

Why We Need Your Help!

The population of Peru is about 29.2 million and 34.8% of Peruvians live below the poverty line. Indigenous populations are especially susceptible to impoverishment due to deep-rooted discrimination and marginalization. Often they live at the bare minimum of subsistence levels... which isn't living at all, but rather merely surviving. The projects we implement will help them meet their basic needs and empower them to build better and more secure lives for themselves and their children. If you can imagine how difficult it would be to live on a couple hundred dollars a month... many of these families live on mere dollars a day!

How Can You Help??

The total cost for the trip will be close to $4,500. This will cover the cost of my transportation to and from Peru, the cost of my housing and food while I am there, transportation to and from project sites, as well as (and most importantly!) the cost of the projects I will help establish and implement. My Indiegogo goal is to raise at least $1,000 by the end of May. There is no minimum to the amount you can donate... any little bit helps! And if you just can't contribute, no problem... you can help simply by spreading the word and sending good vibes our direction! :)

story:
The mission of Oregon Outreach is to provide an accredited academic program and support system which assists the at-risk student in succeeding in the classroom, at home, and in the community.

Executive Director Rebecca Black founded Oregon Outreach (OOI) in 1988, as a response to gang violence in North/Northeast Portland; in conjunction with the Mayor’s Youth Gang Task Force, OOI offered job training and placement. This employment program was subsequently funded by the City of Portland, Multnomah County, the Northeast Police Precinct and the Urban League, and continues today as an accredited alternative school serving high-need youth who have dropped out of school, who are behind academically and/or who are not on track to graduation and post-secondary success. OOI helps to close the achievement gap by offering at-risk students the opportunity for individualized instruction and, by requiring a commitment to educational excellence and attendance requirements in return, instills discipline and self-motivation so students may aspire to on-time graduation and success in their communities.         

Approximately 90 students enroll at Oregon Outreach each year. Prospective students have been identified by high school counselors as being at risk for dropping out of school for reasons which include, but are not limited to, academic credit-deficiency, pregnancy, adjudication, substance abuse, being learning-disabled and/or behaviorally disordered.  Youth served by OOI are from families that are in frequent transition, are low-income, in foster care, and/or have been adjudicated, 95% live below federal poverty guidelines, and are two to five years behind their peers academically. OOI also serves homeless youth (defined as a youth without a family, from a family without a home, or from a family living with multiple families in one home).

Oregon Outreach operates schools in three locations (inner North/Northeast Portland, outerSoutheast Portland, and Mollala). Two of these sites are located in communities which have some of the highest crime rates and the largest scholastic achievement gaps in the state. The goal for OOI students is a high school diploma, whether earned at OOI or at their “home” schools, for students who have successfully re-entered them.

            The funds we are requesting is for an Arts program at our Rosi Hinton High School location in SE Portland.  The program was started in February of 2012 through a small grant provided by the Coen Gilbert Family Foundation.  The Students at Rosi Hinton have great difficulty with their academic work.  A majority of our students receive special education services for various disabilities. For most of our students, they have experienced little school success. Oregon Outreach at the Rosi Hinton School believes that the arts can be of immense benefit to our students. In our proposed visual arts program, students can work with a licensed, experienced artist and teacher with a great deal of experience helping students with depression, anxiety, anger and abuse issues, and oppositional defiance. Students can exorcise emotions therapeutically, collaborate on group art projects such as murals, learn about their culturally positive artistic role models, develop hands on skills, achieve successful outcomes, learn about various cultural art forms, develop creative and critical thinking skills, and learn history, economics, language arts, philosophy, science and how to be a better citizen and community member through the arts.

The overall goal of the Arts Program is to assist our at risk students in gaining success in projects, creating projects through critical thinking, addressing their deeply rooted psychological issues through visual arts, helping them develop self confidence in personal creative, academic and personal areas. The Arts Program has been implemented in a portion of a classroom. Periods during the school day are art periods for our middle and high school students. Through this program arts integration into academic subjects will be demonstrated by the art teacher to staff so that students can use what they learn in art class in their academic classes.
story_txt:
The mission of Oregon Outreach is to provide an accredited academic program and support system which assists the at-risk student in succeeding in the classroom, at home, and in the community.
Executive Director Rebecca Black founded Oregon Outreach (OOI) in 1988, as a response to gang violence in North/Northeast Portland; in conjunction with the Mayor’s Youth Gang Task Force, OOI offered job training and placement. This employment program was subsequently funded by the City of Portland, Multnomah County, the Northeast Police Precinct and the Urban League, and continues today as an accredited alternative school serving high-need youth who have dropped out of school, who are behind academically and/or who are not on track to graduation and post-secondary success. OOI helps to close the achievement gap by offering at-risk students the opportunity for individualized instruction and, by requiring a commitment to educational excellence and attendance requirements in return, instills discipline and self-motivation so students may aspire to on-time graduation and success in their communities.         
Approximately 90 students enroll at Oregon Outreach each year. Prospective students have been identified by high school counselors as being at risk for dropping out of school for reasons which include, but are not limited to, academic credit-deficiency, pregnancy, adjudication, substance abuse, being learning-disabled and/or behaviorally disordered.  Youth served by OOI are from families that are in frequent transition, are low-income, in foster care, and/or have been adjudicated, 95% live below federal poverty guidelines, and are two to five years behind their peers academically. OOI also serves homeless youth (defined as a youth without a family, from a family without a home, or from a family living with multiple families in one home).
Oregon Outreach operates schools in three locations (inner North/Northeast Portland, outerSoutheast Portland, and Mollala). Two of these sites are located in communities which have some of the highest crime rates and the largest scholastic achievement gaps in the state. The goal for OOI students is a high school diploma, whether earned at OOI or at their “home” schools, for students who have successfully re-entered them.
            The funds we are requesting is for an Arts program at our Rosi Hinton High School location in SE Portland.  The program was started in February of 2012 through a small grant provided by the Coen Gilbert Family Foundation.  The Students at Rosi Hinton have great difficulty with their academic work.  A majority of our students receive special education services for various disabilities. For most of our students, they have experienced little school success. Oregon Outreach at the Rosi Hinton School believes that the arts can be of immense benefit to our students. In our proposed visual arts program, students can work with a licensed, experienced artist and teacher with a great deal of experience helping students with depression, anxiety, anger and abuse issues, and oppositional defiance. Students can exorcise emotions therapeutically, collaborate on group art projects such as murals, learn about their culturally positive artistic role models, develop hands on skills, achieve successful outcomes, learn about various cultural art forms, develop creative and critical thinking skills, and learn history, economics, language arts, philosophy, science and how to be a better citizen and community member through the arts.
The overall goal of the Arts Program is to assist our at risk students in gaining success in projects, creating projects through critical thinking, addressing their deeply rooted psychological issues through visual arts, helping them develop self confidence in personal creative, academic and personal areas. The Arts Program has been implemented in a portion of a classroom. Periods during the school day are art periods for our middle and high school students. Through this program arts integration into academic subjects will be demonstrated by the art teacher to staff so that students can use what they learn in art class in their academic classes.

story:
The Reason

My name is Nathan Diekman. I am a teacher and founding member of the Oklahoma Education Project.  Our project focuses on using science as a backbone to all other forms of education; from math and literacy, to social studies and the arts.   Our approach to education uses a project based learning model that is mixed with high intensity science labs and as much technology as we can fit in.  The heart of the equation is the student.  Most of our projects, including this one, are student led, designed and carried out.  



To see the preliminary launch in pictures, click here.


This particular project will use weather balloons and huge amounts of helium to send data recorders into low orbit altitudes (80,000 - 100,000 ft) in a launch rig.  These recorders, usually referred to as loggers, will be equipped with different sensors designed to record specific sets of data.  For example, some of the sensors will be able to measure and record changes in UVA, UVB, barometric pressure, temperature, relative humidity, wind speed oxygen saturation, carbon dioxide concentration,  global position and altitude.  Obviously there will be weight restrictions on each launch, so students will need to decide how, when and where certain sensors will be launched.  Each launch rig will also be equipped with a photo/video recorder that will be synced with the logger.  This will allow the students to visually see the the atmosphere where a specific measurement was recorded.  For example, what is the relative humidity and temperature while inside a cloud versus above or below that same cloud?  Lastly each lunch rig will have to have a way for us to find it again.  The logger is not a transmitter.  We will have no way to recover any data until we lay our hands onto the rig.  To accomplish this we use SPOT locators that let us track the coordinates of the rig.  


Once back on the ground the data will be analyzed and the students will be tasked with finding creative ways to present it in modern and relevant forms.  Perhaps they will perform a one-act play describing the ascension rate of a helium balloon.  Maybe they will be able to predict weather patterns based on temperature and humidity levels and make a YouTube video about it.  Only the students can know exactly what will be produced.


The Payoff

This project, and future ones like it, will remind students that creativity and learning go hand in hand.  While that may sound warm and squishy, the true meaning goes much deeper.  In today's education system, students are encouraged to recreate and improve.  Rarely are they asked to create.  It is our mission to develop an excitement in students that will drive them to search for knowledge around them.  

However, competition for brains is very stiff.  Science like ours is competing against Xbox, YouTube, and iPhones.  If we can't excite kids, we will never win them over.  We need this.  You need this.  



The Hook

Unfortunately, in this country, high school science doesn't get funded.  Projects like this are expensive.  The staff of the Oklahoma Education Project did a preliminary launch of a similar rig and it was valued at over $500.00.  This basic rig only contained a camera, and the SPOT locator. Each balloon cost about $100.00 with another $100.00 of helium in it.The loggers, sensors, and cameras are not cheap either.  While they are not a consumable expense, like the balloon and helium, they must be purchased up front and possibly replaced if something goes terribly wrong.  Lastly, fuel is important.  Our last launch few approximately 90 miles away, as the crow flies.  In driving miles, round trip, it equaled well over 200 miles. Keeping in mind that we have absolutely no idea where this thing COULD land, we have to use our more rugged and less fuel efficient vehicles.  


The goal of this campaign is to have enough equipment to launch at least 2 separate balloon rigs with different equipment. This will allow 10-12 students to actively participate in the design and launch, in groups of 5-6. A smaller budget will obviously limit either how many launches we can do or what we can attach to each one.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Please don't feel that you only can donate the specified amounts.  Any donation of any size will be accepted.  If you cannot donate money, we need lots more.  Know anything about robotics or programming?  How about video editing or recording?  Got any spare cameras, GPS or time?  Do you live within a couple of states, in any direction, of Oklahoma (these things have been known to travel)?  Would you be willing to pick this thing up for me and mail it back?  Be creative.  I'm sure the kids can find something for you to do.

story:
The Story Behind KIP Education & Prevention Programs

Kay Alexander and I (Cendrine Marrouat) met last year, during her book launch in Winnipeg. I wrote an article on the event and we started emailing each other back and forth. At first, we discussed the topics in our books (I am also an author) and realized that we shared the same views on the world. 


I had always wanted to make a real difference in this world. So when Kay shared her vision -- an organization that would cater to both those in need and those who serve them through all-inclusive programs -- I felt instantly drawn to the idea. We met, and KIP started to take shape. 


Who We Are: The Founders

  • Kay Alexander:

Originally from Trinidad and Tobago, Kay Alexander migrated to Canada where she graduated with a degree in Psychology from the University of Manitoba. She spent most of her adult life working with children, including youth in crisis and has also counselled abused women. As a teenager she volunteered in orphanages, worked as a camp counsellor and an assistant camp director during her summers, and also worked with the elderly in a Senior citizens’ home. 


  • Cendrine Marrouat

I was born in Toulouse, southern France, and moved to Canada in 2003. I hold a bachelor’s degree in English-to-French translation. In my eight years in Winnipeg, I have worked as a translator, teacher, freelance journalist, reviewer and writer, and have had the opportunity to meet some extraordinary people who have opened my heart and mind to the beauties of this world.    

What is KIP Education & Prevention Programs?


KIP (Knowledge Is Power) Education & Prevention Programs will offer all-inclusive programs tailored to the specific needs of at-risk youth, newcomers and low-income people in Winnipeg. KIP will work with existing agencies and organizations to provide the necessary tools and equal opportunities allowing participants to become valuable individuals, employees and members of the community.


The Impact


Kay and I are experienced professionals in our fields. We know that our programs are unique and will address the specific needs of our participants. We will never follow a linear pattern. We will adjust to make sure that our participants receive individual attention, while providing a safe, stable and nurturing environment where they can thrive and grow as individuals. 


As a result, we believe that the impact on the community will be huge. 


Donation and Monies Distribution

Donations and monies will be used to cover the following:


1) Basic program costs, such as
--Day-to-day program expenses
--Administration costs
--Miscellaneous other costs: vehicles, computers, books, multimedia equipment...


2 ) Special event costs

KIP organizes two fundraisers a year: one in summer and one in winter. At the end of the program year, an award ceremony also celebrates the achievements and success of participants, while acknowledging KIP supporters.

Donations and monies will also be used to fund specific programs, such as the Certificate Program, the Freedom of Expression Program, the Recreational Program, and the Nutrition Program.


a) Certificate Program

KIP covers the expenses allowing participants to obtain various licenses and / or  certificates to become employable.


b) Freedom of Expression

Freedom of Expression is a unique program that gives participants an opportunity to heal and offers them a voice through creative expression.

KIP covers the costs of instruments, art supplies and rental space, and pays instructors for drama, dance, writing, music, and art and crafts classes.


c) Recreational Program

KIP covers the cost of all sports equipment, activities and passes. Our longer term goal is to have an on-site gym.


d) Nutrition Program

KIP creates cook books, covers the costs of nutritional education and food, and provides emergency food for participants.


What We Need Now

Here are ways you can help us get started.

1) Monetary support. 

2) Books: fiction, non-fiction, educational, used/new driver's handbooks.

3) New and used computers.

4) Sports equipment: basketballs, soccer balls, hockey equipment, ice skates...

5) Art supplies: paint brushes, canvases, easels...

6) Musical and multimedia donations: CD players, gently used instruments, projectors...

7) Cooking utensils

8) Food donations

9) Gently used clothing donations (business or work attire)


Contact us at info@kip-programs.org for more information.


Other Ways You Can Help

  1. Like our Fan Page and invite others to do the same.
  2. Tell all your friends, family, acquaintances, and followers about KIP and this campaign.
  3. Help spread the word about KIP. Share this campaign on social networking and bookmarking sites. 
  4. If you are a blogger or member of the media, feel free to contact me to schedule an interview with Kay and/or myself.

7) Cooking utensils
8) Food donations

Contact us at info@kip-programs.org for more information.


Other Ways You Can Help



Like our Fan Page and invite others to do the same.
Tell all your friends, family, acquaintances, and followers about KIP and this campaign.
Help spread the word about KIP. Share this campaign on social networking and bookmarking sites. 
If you are a blogger or member of the media, feel free to contact me to schedule an interview with Kay and/or myself.

story:
Short Summary

Jackie (my wife) and I sold everything we owned in 2011 to open a non profit 501c3  organization, Epic Missions, Inc. in Florida that encourages people from around the USA and Canada to donate a week of their life to community work and missions. No one at Epic Missions takes a salary and this is our life's work. We used all of our personal savings and proceeds from the sale of our home and cars to restore the missions base that houses and feeds the volunteers that travel here to do community work. Epic Missions then purchased the property in 2012.

We stepped out in faith to do this and in our first year alone we brought in over 300 people from around the USA and Canada to volunteer for a week at a time. This year we expect to house over 450 volunteers and contribute 18,000 hours to help save at risk children and teens, feed the hungry and help broken families.

We intend to duplicate this model in America with your financial help.

Every team member returns home with a desire to help make a positive change in their own community as a result of their missions trip with Epic Missions. Our volunteers may come from your own community so it helps you as they return home determined to make a positive difference in their own communities. We do all of our work in the USA - we think missions starts here at home.

But we need to reach more people to make a difference in the USA to stamp out hunger, homelessness, at risk kids and families that are in crisis. Our vounteers directly work with these need groups to help stop the cycle and start them on the road to recovery.

We are attempting to get 2,000 people to give $299 (the cost to feed and house each team member for a week) so that we can bring in more people to train, volunteer and send back to their communities in the USA and Canada. 

Your gift will offset our costs in training and bringing in these volunteers, we will be able to reach more people and will pay off the debt on the Epic Missions Property and base. Doing this will allow us to expand and make a greater impact across our country and Canada.Your gifts are tax deductible!

What We Need & What You Get

We need 2,000 people to donate $299 to offset the cost of a volunteer for one full week. The funding will then allow us to bring in more voluntters across America and return more of them home to your community to make a positive change.

The funds will be used to feed and house the volunteer while they spend a week doing community work with at risk teens (Gifford Youth Center and Hibiscus House) and working with the hungry and homeless at the Source as well as many other community organizations.

It will free up funds for us to pay down or eliminate the $475,000 of debt we have in a mortgage for Epic Missions which was used to purchase the missions base where Epic Missions is located.

Here are the perks!

$15

With a $15 contribution we will list you on our website page for supporting our Indie gogo Initiative - Search for Significance

$50

For a $50 contribution, we will list you on our website page as a contributor to our Search for Significance project, and we will send you a 5X7 signed picture of one of our teams that volunteer at Epic Missions

$100

For a $100 contribution, we will send you all of the above, plus an Epic Missions Tee shirt in your size (specify)

$299

For a $299 donation and above, you will receive all of the above plus a gift card for $25 to Carrabba’s, Bonefish Grill or Outback Steakhouse

$1,000 and above

For a donation of $1,000 or above, you will receive all of the above items plus a one week missions trip for one person through Epic Missions, Inc in Vero Beach Florida. You may either serve a week as part of another team that we will join you with, or you may have others that you know who would like to form a team with you to come to Epic Missions for a week and make a positive impact in our world.

The Impact

We are real people volunteering to deal with real problems in our communities across the USA. We use Vero Beach as a training ground for our teams of volunteers. They return home to your community  - changed - ready to make a positive difference in their hometown to end hunger, homelessness and protect kids at risk.

Over 27,000 hours of real volunteer time will have been poured into our communities by Epic Missions volunteers by the end of 2013. If we reach our goal - we will increase that number in subsequent years by over 700%.

Throwing money at the issues of hunger and homelessness without building relationships between the homeless, hungry, or at risk kids will not work. Volunteers make a difference. They can assist in finding out the CAUSE of what got the hurting person in their current situation. Knowing the STORY will help us find a solution to break the cycle. That is what we do. We get involved directly with the kids, teens, homeless persons or hungry family. We intervene and help find lasting solutions.

We need your help to duplicate this model across America and Canada.That is what we intend to do with your donations.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can go to our website at www.epicmissions.org or our facebook site Epicmissions and read about us. Help get the word out. Take our link here on Indiegogo and spread it to your friends - ask them to in turn - spread it to their friends. Help us go viral!

You may either serve a week as part of another team that we will join you with, or you may have others that you know who would like to form a team with you to come to Epic Missions for a week and make a positive impact in our world.


The Impact
We are real people volunteering to deal with real problems in our communities across the USA. We use Vero Beach as a training ground for our teams of volunteers. They return home to your community  - changed - ready to make a positive difference in their hometown to end hunger, homelessness and protect kids at risk.
Over 27,000 hours of real volunteer time will have been poured into our communities by Epic Missions volunteers by the end of 2013. If we reach our goal - we will increase that number in subsequent years by over 700%.
Throwing money at the issues of hunger and homelessness without building relationships between the homeless, hungry, or at risk kids will not work. Volunteers make a difference. They can assist in finding out the CAUSE of what got the hurting person in their current situation. Knowing the STORY will help us find a solution to break the cycle. That is what we do. We get involved directly with the kids, teens, homeless persons or hungry family. We intervene and help find lasting solutions.
We need your help to duplicate this model across America and Canada.That is what we intend to do with your donations.


Other Ways You Can Help
You can go to our website at www.epicmissions.org or our facebook site Epicmissions and read about us. Help get the word out. Take our link here on Indiegogo and spread it to your friends - ask them to in turn - spread it to their friends. Help us go viral!

story:
Short Summary

Isn’t it ironic that, despite the tremendous scientific and technological advancements and the massive increases in material production that have been achieved over the past two centuries, the world finds itself in the grips of an acute multidimensional crisis with one quarter of the world's population still living in poverty and squalor?

As the global mega-crisis deepens, major structural changes are urgently needed, especially in the realm of money, credit and finance. That's the realm in which I have unique knowledge and expertise and in which there are major leverage points for community empowerment.

As a leading "community economist" my mission in life is to help create a just and peaceful world that works for everyone. I've been at it for almost four decades--researching, speaking, writing, and assisting people on their own journeys toward our shared goals. Today I need your help to continue this work for the common good.

Community currencies and cashless exchange networks have been proliferating around the world, but as in the early days of aviation, their impact has so far been modest. With the application of advanced knowledge and expertise, and supported by adequate resources, these systems can be greatly improved to provide a real solution to the global crisis.

I'm headed off on a tour of Europe and the UK to meet with thought leaders, small business people, and local officials about bringing these ideas to life in their communities. The anchor event and first stop on this tour will be the 2nd International Conference on Complementary Currency Systems (CCS), 19 – 23 June 2013 in The Hague, Netherlands. I will both present individually and appear on two panels there. The organizers of that event will be providing a travel allowance, but it will not be enough to cover even the trans-Atlantic flight, much less living expenses and travel to other stops on my tour.

I have already made definite commitments to go to Sweden, England, and Greece, but my itinerary is still evolving and I expect to make several additional stops throughout the region to give talks, workshops and consultations. Quite often, the groups that need my help are unable to pay even my travel expenses, but with your help we can make meaningful change a reality for these communities. 

During a similar tour that I made last October, I gave a total of 15 presentations and workshops to various groups in three different countries. You can read a brief report of that tour at http://beyondmoney.net/2012/11/30/newsletter-november-2012/.

Civilization is going through an exciting and necessary metamorphic change from destructive competition, growth, and consumption, toward a regenerative, steady-state, more mature mode of living. The key to the successful completion of that metamorphosis is the transcendence of outmoded mechanisms of money, banking, and finance and the emergence of true economic democracy. The devolution of power to the people can only move forward by reclaiming the "credit commons" through the creation decentralized currencies and exchange mechanisms. That is where I can make a difference and that is what I am asking you to help me achieve.

As Swami Beyondananda says, “It’s time to shift our karma out of reverse and get our assets in gear.”

 ______________

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to contribute financially you can still help by:

Spreading the word about our work, the tour, and this campaign by using the share buttons on this page! 

Connect me with your EU/UK contacts who may be able to provide lodging or transportation along the way.

Thank you very much for helping in this important work.

story:
Who We Are

We are poet Roderick Borisade and cartoonist Aaron Hazouri, and we're here to ask you for help to spread the word of Buddy and Bird.

Roderick "Odd Rod" Borisade is a poet and public speaker based in the Jacksonville, Florida area. He has published several books; spoken to groups ranging in age from preschool to senior citizens, and in size from small gatherings to convention centers; and has recently released his second album of music and poetry. Raised in poverty by a drug addicted mother with no father present, the death of his older brother at a young age led Rod to discover poetry. Rod worked tirelessly to better himself and beat the odds stacked against him, attending the University of North Florida on a full scholarship. Currently, Rod tours on the college circuit, speaking to groups of students about his life experiences and sharing inspirational and motivational pieces of poetry.

Illustrator Aaron Hazouri, also from the Jacksonville area, is a cartoonist and puppeteer. He is responsible for designing the characters and settings, and for designing, building and performing the Buddy and Bird puppets. He spent ten years working in the corporate world; earlier this year, he left his day job to concentrate solely on his artistic career. Currently, in addition to his work with Buddy and Bird, Aaron is the writer and artist behind the young adult comic book The Strange Adventures of Toaster Guy.

Rod and Aaron each bring unique talents to this project that will help ensure its success. They're only missing one thing: you!

About Buddy and Bird

The team spent years developing the characters and story of Buddy and Bird, loosely based on their lives. The first story features Buddy and Bird's initial meeting and a look into their different worlds, showcasing both their differences and the things they have in common. Sobsequent stories will feature a wide range of diverse characters, facing different emotional issues common to young, lower middle class children.

Looking at the landscape of children's programming, there are a wealth of programs offering lessons in spelling, counting, and other educational areas of focus. However, there are few programs addressing the emotional needs of inner city kids - from bullying, to poverty, divorce, to death, to peer pressure. Buddy and Bird is designed to speak to those needs.

Rod and Aaron have taken Buddy and Bird to local schools, daycare centers, and Head Start programs. They've met with success locally, but are ready to take Buddy and Bird to the next level.

Buddy and Bird!

Buddy and Bird are the main characters - the stars of the show. 

Buddy is based on Rod, and Bird on Aaron. Their lives reflect the realities of Rod and Aaron's childhoods. Aaron designed the characters to appeal to young children, to be easily animated, and to be adaptable to different formats - book illustration, cartoon animation, web animation, and puppets.

The puppets are a big part of the Buddy and Bird "package." They're important for live-action interactions with kids. Children almost universally respond well to puppets, and the Buddy and Bird team has had great success working with groups of inner city kids using the puppets.

The supporting cast of characters features kids from different backgrounds, of different body types, different personalities and a wide range of abilities. 

What is "the next level?"

As mentioned earlier, there's been some measure of success locally, but to take Buddy and Bird further, we need your contributions. 

We think Buddy and Bird would be a great fit for educational television - ideally, PBS, but we're open to anyplace on television (or the internet). We'd like to put together a pilot film, with professional videography and animation; for that, we need money. 

Producing a pilot animated short film, seven to ten minutes of animation, will cost in the neighborhood of ten to twelve thousand dollars (Flash animation costs are right around $1,000 per minute). Hiring professional videographers, renting equipment, and filing permits to film the live-action segment of the pilot will also cost several thousand dollars. Finally, money is needed to produce a package, including high-quality copies of the pilot; character designs; and sample scripts. This will enable us to shop the project around to producers, agents, conventions, conferences, etc.

Do it for the kids - or, do it for the perks! Copies of the book, T-shirts, shout outs, and more!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to contribute - spread the word, whether it's Facebook, Twitter, Google Plus, standing on the corner and shouting - we think Buddy and Bird can make a huge difference in the lives of kids, and we need your help to get it there.

Thank you!

Thank you!

story:
About Sharon School

Sharon School (see footage of the school in video above from 0:30 - 0:55) is located in a large slum in Nairobi, Kenya, in a community where people struggle to attain even the most basic necessities. The slum is very large and yet there are no public schools in the area, which means most children can't go to school because their parents cannot afford any school fees. Infant mortality is high and for most parents and children there is little to no access to any sort of health care.

When we first encountered Sharon, we found 60 children and their teachers working and playing in a single, dirt-floored room. They had minimal school supplies and lacked access to basic sources of food and clean water.

But with the help of ICRI staff we were able to initiate important changes at Sharon School. Over the next few years, we were able to do the following:

  • Build and install a 3000 gallon water tank so that children would no longer have to share a bucket and single cup for drinking water.
  • Set up a food program to provide warm meals and snacks to the children.
  • Provide basic school and learning supplies for the children.

The Project

Sharon School provides crucial resources for its students, and while we have been able to take many steps to improve the care of children there, we still have a long way to go. Right now our priority is finding a new location for the school, which is currently located inside a church. In the community, church meetings and activities take precedent over school time, and the 50+ children who attend the school are often interrupted and displaced during their school day.

ICRI plans to purchase a building and a small plot of land for the school. With their own space, teachers will be able to develop a nurturing environment, safely store their toys and learning tools, and most importantly, provide a stable and consistent school space for the children.

 

After a long and careful search, we have found a potential new school site in Nairobi for a price of $10,000. Thanks to some very generous families, we've already raised $6,000, but we still need $4,000 more to reach our goal. Any money raised will go towards purchasing the new site for the school.

The Impact

Sharon School delivers a unique childcare and development program to vulnerable children, providing:

  • Food - The children, mostly coming from poor and struggling families, receive a balanced meal everyday at school.
  • Quality Education - Sharon and her teachers are equipped with the latest in early childhood development (ECD) practices through the elaborate ECD Capacity building programs offered by ICRI Africa.
  • Healthcare - ICRI provides a medical check up once a month and prescriptions for children at Sharon School. The nurse also often gives community talks to the parents of the children who come to school on the medical service day. 

With a new building Sharon School will be able to continue offering these services to children in need. Please help us keep Sharon School alive, and help support the education, health, and well-being of these children.

About ICRI

ICRI (International Child Resource Institute) is a non-profit that works around the world in the areas of early childhood care and education, children’s rights, empowerment of women and girls, maternal and child health, and grassroots community development. In 2005 ICRI began offering support to Sharon School, a school in a low-income community in Nairobi, Kenya, that provides education, food, and health checkups for poor children. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute monetarily, you can still help! Please share our project with your friends and family, and post a link to our page on facebook, twitter, or other social media sites. This kind of support is greatly appreciated!

story:
Who We Are

Team PyroTech is a third year FRC (FIRST Robotics Competition) community-based team from Cary, North Carolina. We belong to a non-profit (501-c3) organization called Wake Robotics.  

Our team of 20 students works with professional engineers, programmers and business people to design, build, and program robots. We have also acquired important life skills like public speaking, teamwork, and leadership.

We use these skills and our robots to get more people in our community excited about science, engineering and technology. We encourage and help other FRC teams, including several new teams in our area. Several students are also YAMs (young adult mentors) to younger FIRST teams (FTC, FLL, JrFLL).

Our outreach efforts were validated by winning the Engineering Inspiration Award sponsored by NASA at the NC FRC Regional.  We are now going to St. Louis, MO to compete with world class teams at the FIRST Robotics Competition World Championship.

Team PyroTech is committed to inspiring excitement and interest in science and Technology by showing and teaching people just how awesome and fun STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math) is. We have many students on the team, male and female, who were previously not interested in STEM and are now excited to use a cut off grinder or tell kids how our robot works. We also encourage women in STEM fields; our team is one third girls who are all very excited to transform our culture and challenge the norm and stereotypical views of STEM that have been accepted in our society.

 

Our Mission and Our Impact

Team PyroTech’s mission is to raise the level of understanding and experience of each student, and to change the world one person at a time by growing well-educated individuals who are ready to take leadership roles and to work together on and across teams.

Our team’s decisions reflect our core values: everybody grows and learns by doing, the world is best changed one person at a time, everybody is a leader, and life is FUN. We also  practice the FIRST principles of Coopertition® and Gracious Professionalism® .

We offer team members experience with shop tools, teamwork, collaboration, public speaking, business practices, deadlines, competition, travel, and leadership.  In turn, our team members spread our message by doing outreach, training rookie teams, collaborating with other teams, and bringing the principles of FIRST with us into our future careers.

Last summer we hosted over 35 outreaches and interacted with over 7500 people of all ages. Some of outreaches include:

  • Elementary schools (e.g. Cary Elementary)

  • High schools (e.g. Research Triangle High School)

  • Libraries and Museums (e.g. Marbles Museum)

  • Educational Conferences (e.g. NC Legislative Days)

  • Corporate Demos (e.g. Red Hat, Qualcomm)

  • Coach workshops (e.g. How to Coach a FIRST LEGO League Team)

Team PyroTech is using robots to change the culture around us and learn important life skills that are rarely learned within the classroom. We are changing the world one person at a time, giving students hands on experience and challenging them to think in the context of real world problems. This environment gives students new found confidence and helps prepare them for their future careers.

 

Where Your Donation Goes

Your Donation will help our team cover expenses (travel, food, tools, and emergency parts for our robot) to travel to the FIRST World Championships, in St. Louis, MO to meet other teams and learn from them as well as spread our impact throughout the FIRST community. In St. Louis, our team plans make an impact by spreading the Human Player Game (an exercise designed for teams to learn and collaborate with each other), spreading the concept of organic leadership (a method of leadership that allows all team members to be leaders which is often used in small start up companies), and spreading PyroTech’s program called “Change the World through CNC” (computer numerical control.)  We also hope to learn how other winners of the Engineering Inspiration Award make an impact in their communities to take back to NC.

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate all donations, as well as any help spreading word of our team. So even if you can't donate money, please, please, please share our campaign! Check around and see if there is a FIRST team or regional near you that you can volunteer with!

 

Images of perks can be found here.

story:
Short Summary

The Achieng HIV/AIDS International Project is the result of passion and hard work by Christine Himbury, a native of Bar Sauri Village, Kenya. Christine grew up in Bar Sauri, a village in Western Kenya with one of the highest rates of HIV/AIDS in the world. Poverty stricken children, many of them who cannot afford to eat or stay in school, are destined to repeat the cycle of poverty and disease if not given an education and mentorship support.

Christine's dream is to support girls in Bar Sauri, specifically in elementary school programs who would not otherwise have an opportunity to succeed through education.  

In May 2012, Christine went to Bar Sauri and identified 13 girls who need immediate help. Our goal at Achieng is to raise enough to sponsor these 13 girls for one year. The total required to do this is $3900 (or $300 per girl).

Please help us to achieve this goal by donating now! Every donation helps, regardless of size.

Everyone who volunteers at Achieng does so with a passion to support youth in Kenya through education. No one takes a salary, and every dollar raised goes to the girls in the program, with a small amount required to cover IndieGogo and PayPal fees.  

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Here are a few more details:

  • Each girl requires $300 to cover her costs for books, all other school materials, uniforms, and mentorship support. This cost represents one year of costs.
  • Additional costs include IndieGogo and PayPal fees.
  • If you sponsor a girl for a year, we will provide you with pictures, correspondence and updates on her progress.
  • ANY donation helps! Every dollar helps, so please feel free to donate whatever you feel comfortable donating.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can’t contribute, and that's okay - but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Tell your friends about it, send it out through your social media and do whatever you can! Any assistance in this way is greatly appreciated.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

If you have questions, please feel free to contact us, or check out the Achieng website at www.achieng.org
story_txt:
Short Summary
The Achieng HIV/AIDS International Project is the result of passion and hard work by Christine Himbury, a native of Bar Sauri Village, Kenya. Christine grew up in Bar Sauri, a village in Western Kenya with one of the highest rates of HIV/AIDS in the world. Poverty stricken children, many of them who cannot afford to eat or stay in school, are destined to repeat the cycle of poverty and disease if not given an education and mentorship support.
Christine's dream is to support girls in Bar Sauri, specifically in elementary school programs who would not otherwise have an opportunity to succeed through education.  

In May 2012, Christine went to Bar Sauri and identified 13 girls who need immediate help. Our goal at Achieng is to raise enough to sponsor these 13 girls for one year. The total required to do this is $3900 (or $300 per girl).
Please help us to achieve this goal by donating now! Every donation helps, regardless of size. 
Everyone who volunteers at Achieng does so with a passion to support youth in Kenya through education. No one takes a salary, and every dollar raised goes to the girls in the program, with a small amount required to cover IndieGogo and PayPal fees.  
 

 

What We Need & What You Get
Here are a few more details:

Each girl requires $300 to cover her costs for books, all other school materials, uniforms, and mentorship support. This cost represents one year of costs.
Additional costs include IndieGogo and PayPal fees.
If you sponsor a girl for a year, we will provide you with pictures, correspondence and updates on her progress.
ANY donation helps! Every dollar helps, so please feel free to donate whatever you feel comfortable donating.
 

Other Ways You Can Help


Some people can’t contribute, and that's okay - but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Tell your friends about it, send it out through your social media and do whatever you can! Any assistance in this way is greatly appreciated.
Use the Indiegogo share tools!


If you have questions, please feel free to contact us, or check out the Achieng website at www.achieng.org

story:
Hi, we are STUDIO Mada.

We are a group of architects and engineers that are currently engaged in a building project at Madangombe Primary School in Zimbabwe.

Our strategy is to develop Madangombe Primary School one block at a time. The first action is to invest in a manual brick press that can produce Compressed Stabilized Earth Blocks (CSEB) on site. These blocks will be the main construction material used for building new classrooms. For this we need your support.

Madangombe Primary School is an existing school in the Chivi-region and it has about 850 pupils. Due to its rapid growth they are short of several educational infrastructures. Their current priority is to build a kindergarten to house their 120 pupils in the Early Child Development program (ECD), from 3-5 years old. Today they have only one classroom for this purpose. According to the Zimbabwe Ministry of Education, the teacher/student ratio should be 1/20. At least six classrooms are in need in this case.  


The entire project of six ECD classrooms has an estimated budget of 35000 USD. We are already sponsored with 14000 USD from Chivi Foundation, another non-profit organization that has supported and developed Madangombe Primary School over the past several years. http://www.chivikids.no/ 

This campaign aims to raise 5000 USD to buy a manual brick press and the tools needed to set up a local CSEB production line for constructing the classrooms. A manual brick press and two moulds cost 4000 USD plus shipment to Madangombe. In addition we need to invest in a set of tools such as shovels, wheelbarrows and sieves that will be given to the school. 

If we exceed our goal of 5000 USD, the money will be spent on building materials and certified professionals (plumbers, electricians etc. ) to complete the ECD classrooms. 

Classrooms units will be built in stages to make sure that we are not dependent on raising the entire sum at once. 

After the project is completed the remaining funds will be transferred to Chivi Foundation and their volunteer work at Madangombe Primary School. 


Compressed Stabilized Earth Block

The Compressed Stabilized Earth Block is a cheap and sustainable building material because it uses local soil, and very little cement compared to the regular bricks. About 3-5 % cement is added to the soil, depending on the quality of soil, which increases its compressive strength and durability. 

Today the community builds structures with cement bricks that use 20 % cement. This is a major building cost, so being able to reduce the cement by 15-17 % will have a great impact on building economy.

Buying a brick press is an investment that will benefit the whole community. It is easy to handle and will provide the community with an extra way of income. 

By choosing a manual press rather than an electrical one we avoid more serious maintenance issues, in case of a breakdown. 

  • Less cement = less cost
  • Local soil = Local production
  • Low-tech solution = Less maintenance
  • Extra skills = more income 

Risks & Challenges

The currency values are constantly changing and in addition to that, corruption is, unfortunately, still a constant in several exchange situations.

As we are collaborating with another organization (Chivi Foundation) that has been working on the same location for several years, the network and trust built between several people is already solid and stable. Friends and friends of friends are normally present to support us and engaged in overcoming possible challenges.

We are working in a "small" community environment and everyone must feel included in the process. Without the support of the people, the development of the project can become more difficult and time consuming. We value the help of local friends, dean and teachers that know personally whom to and how to inform all the necessary people. 

Previous trips to the school have allowed us to evaluate how different the learning conditions are and how children and teachers in Zimbabwe engage in this task every day. Being able to share the knowledge that we have gathered in way less demanding conditions, is for us an honor and a duty. We are hopefully trying to empower and reach a more balanced world, one block at a time with your support!


Other Ways You Can Help

We truly appreciate all the support we can get, and if you wish to contribute in other terms than funding this campaign, please get in touch with us at studiomadamail@gmail.com

Please share this campaign with your friends to help us reach our goal.


All the best from STUDIO Mada

story:
The Computer Learning Center will give underprivileged Tanzanian youth the ability to learn critical computer skills and engage with interactive learning programs. Computer skills are greatly lacking in the Tanzanian workforce - this center will enable these children to master these skills, attain better jobs after school, and break the cycle of poverty that they were born into.

Your donations will provide:  

  • 15 computers for the lab 
  • Professional setup and ongoing computer training for the staff and children
  • Interactive learning software for typing, math, reading, and science
  • Wikipedia, Encarta, and Khan Academy

Any donations received beyond our goal will go towards additional computers and equipment.

Want to Help, but Short On Cash This Month?

Simply click here to pledge smaller monthly donations of $5, $10, or $25 for 12 months. And you'll still be eligible for the same rewards based on your total contribution!!

If you'd like to help beyond monetary means by volunteering your time to help the cause, please let us know by emailing us at bettervieworg@gmail.com

story:
Although my goal is listed at only 500 dollars, in reality my need is for nearly 100 time this amount, but as this website (and others like it) charge you more if you don't reach your goal, I figured it makes sense to just put the minimum they allow one to ask for.

As stated in the title, I'm currently seeking to finish my Master's degree here in Copenhagen. While the city is consistently rated one of the best for students in the world in terms of activities and amenities (http://www.topuniversities.com/city-rankings/2013) what is often left out of that description is the remarkable cost of living. Not only is housing here difficult to find at reasonable prices, but due to being an international student, my tuition costs are literally infinitely greater than those of the Danes.

Due to the conditions of my visa, my working opportunities here are quite limited, so at the recommendation of my brilliant mother, I've turned here in the hope that the people who have so fantastically populated and enriched my life, and maybe even some beautiful strangers feeling particularly generous, might lend me some assistance to allow me to stay and finish what has heretofore been one of the best and most fortunate experiences of my life.
