story:
“It seems that nerdom, geeky, or what ever you want to call it- is making it way into the main stream, either that or more of us are just banding together to bring forth these sort of events. It’s a really wonderful community, where everybody fits in and makes new friends,” said Blitz founder Laura Petrishen-Ha.

Blitz is Saskatchewan's longest running anime, gaming and comic convention owned and organized by Saskatchewan fans. We have mandated to not sell the convention to large, out of province corporations which enables us to create an experience that fans truly want!

The convention packs a variety of activities and events into just two days and aims to appeal to every aspect of ‘nerd-dom.’ The weekend features panel discussions, movie screenings, appearances from local, national and international special guests and – of course – a costume contest.

When hosting an independent convention in an environment with other brand conventions, it can be difficult to ensure a great con experience with no corporate backing. We want to keep Blitz Saskatchewan owned but we also want to make your experience at Blitz better than the last! This campaign with help us make the convention better than ever, and offer you the opportunity to personalize your con!


Blitz 2015 is going to be amazing, and it's because of you! Help us keep Blitz going as a locally owned convention by selecting one of the perks on the right and upgrading your experience! We will add updates explaining in more detail the perks as time goes on so keep returning to this page for updates! If you can't purchase a perk don't worry, it is easy to share with your friends and family! 


Thanks so much for your support and we will see you in June!

story:
Phra Daniel Nagasiri grew up in Belgium and France, but in 1998, at the age of 45, he left his previous life behind and was ordained a Buddhist monk in the Theravada tradition.  He has dedicated his life to caring for poor, sick and oppressed people, teaching the message of the Buddha.  He spent his first 2 years as a monk in an AIDS hospice in Thailand.

He moved to India in 2002 where he met a young boy, Ashoka, who was working in a Burmese temple.  Ashoka was denied an education and living under virtual slave-labor conditions.  Phra Daniel learned that Ashoka wanted to be a doctor, and he decided to help him realize his goal.  That was the beginning of the Koruna Dana Budhha  Mission.  Later, Buddhist monks from impoverished and oppressed Myanmar (Burma) asked him to receive more children. Soon, Phra Daniel had created a loving home for 8 to 15 children and registered them into Indian schools.  Ashoka went on to graduate high-school and entered medical school in 2012, where he is doing well.  

Phra Nagasiri discovered a passion for running a mission, eventually setting up shelters in various Indian cities and Nepal.  Most of these houses operated on a shoe-string budget, in the range of $400-500 per month (roughly $25/mth per child).  In this role, Phra Daniel has become an expert in cottage-industry, teaching the children how to sell their garden produce in the local market, as well as making aromatic candles, Belgian chocolates, and more.  Despite often primitive conditions, he was able to offer these children an education, good nutrition, a loving home and high quality of life. 



Since the Nepal earthquake of 2015, Phra Nagasiri lost almost everything and furthermore had to leave his very successful mission in Nepal due to visa troubles.  We are now looking to restore and expand the mission in Ghaziabat, just North of Delhi.  Historicaly, the mission has been a happy family, with laughter and compassion, hard work, and love. Everybody pitches in to help. The children come from many places but mostly from  Myanmar, and not in every case are they orphans, but in every case they have been rescued and adopted.  Almost all the children did well  in school despite having missed out on several years of school, and yet they have shown that desire is a great equalizer.




THE REQUEST

Currently about 8 children live in the Ghaziabat mission.  These are partially funded by Burmese monks in Bodhgaya.  The living conditions there are not optimal, the main advantage being that it is close to schools.

We are looking for relocate the mission to a more healthy and natural environment (such as when the Nepal mission was operating) and also to expand to 20 or more students. 

Our target funding of $3000 would accomplish the following:
  • Relocate the mission to a larger house, ideally in a healthier environment with garden, close to schools, etc; and to afford the lease on such a house (normally 6 months in advance @ 25,000 - 30,000 Rs per month, total of around $2400-$2600) 
  • Travel expenses for the current children, and to bring about 12 new students from Myanmar
The next batch of orphan is supposed to come end of February 2016.  Securing the initial funding will provide lead time to develop other income sources: either
other donors or else cottage-industry, such as supported the prior mission.

ABOUT PHRA DANIEL NAGASIRI
Prior to becoming a monk, Phra Daniel had many careers from translator, hotel owner and shop-keeper, tourist guide, and language teacher at the college level.  He speaks 8 languages: French, English, German, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, Cantonese and Inonesian.
 
In 2013 he wrote a book, in French: Sur La Route du Nirvana: Le Journal d'un Moine Buddhiste Theravada (later in English: On The Road to Nirvana: The Diary of a Theravada Buddhist Monk), available on Amazon here and here, recounting his experiences at the AIDS hospice in Thailand where he worked for 2 years.  It is a fast-paced, moving, and sometimes funny story. 

Some of the children he adopted have now graduated high-school.  They include a medical school student, an engineer, and a mountain guide.  Others are still in school and doing well.  Phra Daniel is also working on his second book in which he gives the incredible story of the Indian and Nepal missions.
 
On the 8 of January 2016 was Daniel Nagasiri birhthday here some comment from the boys from the mission :
Happy birthday Dad.... Yes i was small n nt may be innocent.... The most important person...of whome i was allyz in need left me when i was 8& half.its not the relation of blood... Dosent matter .. God send u to me to fulfil that need.. It was a short tym. My luck is like this the thing i love the most will nr be there with me longer.u helped me to grow up... I Saw the things had never dreamed about.... Life has to go on... I am doing well for my carrier soon i will be the next captain of F&B... Its all because of u.... Today i am Senior GSA form a GSA a post higher... Misd u for ur birthday.... Havent forget... Miss u... I pray for ur gud health n long life lots off happiness n less trouble.... Happy birthday dad love u Asmit...

Thank you baba and happy birthday <<David

Miss you baba , happy birthday , Alex

story:
Breve reseña


Carmina, Ramon, and Magaly, we are three Mexicans who despise having a not very good economic background are part of a very small group of mexicans who have gone to the university. We majored in Teaching Foreign Languages. The three of us speak English, French, and Spanish, and we believe that speaking another language in addition to our mother tongue has  changed our lives fulfilling most of our personal and professional goals.

Now as English teachers we have worked in different language institutions in England, The United States, and Mexico. We describe ourselves as passionate, we love and enjoy being surrounded by people sharing experiences, supporting, and encouraging them to look forward. As dreamers, we believe everything is possible and that no matter who you are you can always become the person you want to be. And as hard-working, we are convinced that in order to achieve any goal you must be persistantt when you don't get what you expect, updated to keep moving forward, and humble to accept and ask for help whenever you need it.

LEADS is a Foreign Language Center aimed to teach different languages, primarly English  through a communicative method. Our target audience are people since the age of  15. We totally believe that nowadays is extremly important to know English in order to be part of the globalization demand. It's our goal to help people grow in ther personal, laboral and professional life through the learning English process.

Its our dream to have a place where we can provide a service different from the other language centers in Colima. We dream in a place where we can share our experience, knowledge, and enthusiasm. We want to provide not only students a nice environment and well-equipped facilities where they can learn in a natural, fun, and interesting way, but also employees the best place to work, where they can be respected, valued, and appeciated for their performance, likewise they can perceive a fair salary to support their families.

If you help us we are going to be able to start as soon as possible with our language center and equip the facilities with the needed material.


In order to open our school we need:

(all the costs are in mexican pesos)

FACILITIES

* 8 classrooms, a teachers' room, a library, a kitchen for a small cafeteria, reception and waiting room, and 2 restrooms.


BUILDING SET UP

Building remodeling ( air condicioning, painting, gypsum board instalation, electricity instalation, etc. )   $50,000

Desks & chairs (15 per classroom = 120)  $240,000

Projector ( 1 per classroom + Teachers' room = 9)  $54,000

Whiteboard (1 per classroom + teachers' room = 9) $9,500

Lap tops ( 1 per classroom + 1 teachers' room + 1 reception = 10) $70,000

Receptionist chair  $800

 Waiting room furniture $20,000

1 Front Desk $3000

Air conditionair (1 per classroom + 1 teachers' room + receprion) $65,000

1 Teacehers' room table $1,500

10 Teachers' room chairs $3,800

2 Book shelves $2,500

5 square tables for the cafeteria with 4 chairs. $ 7,500

1 refrigerator $7,000

1 stove $4,000

1 Microwave $2,150

12 Markers $ 1,080

9 Eraser $84

Multifunctional printer$5,800

1 box of White sheets $650

10 stapler $460

TOTAL= $548,824

KEEPINF THE DOORS OPEN AND LIGHTS ON FOR THE FIRST 6 MONTHS.

Monthly...

Rent   $20,000 + Deposit $20,000

Electricity       $15,000

Water $ 1,000

Telephone & internet $800

Gas  $ 1,000

Teacehrs' salary ( $5,000 per teacher /8 teachers)  $80,000

Receptionist        $4,500

Staff (Cook & janitor)  $ 9,000

Marketing (flyers, brochure, and radio difusion) $55,000

TOTAL= $187,300  x 6 (months) =1,123,800 

Deposit (one time payment) 20, 000

total: $1,143, 800

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Total investment:

BUILDING SET UP ............................................................. $548,824

KEEPINF THE DOORS OPEN AND LIGHTS ON................$1,143, 800

                                                                                          TOTAL = $1, 692,624 pesos

 ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We relly appreciate any contribution we can receive from you. If for any reason we can't reach the ideal amount of money we need, we are going to do our best to assure LEADS Language Center will still  open with the reached amount.


El impacto

In LEADS Language Center, it is our objective to teach English to Mexican students and motivate them by making them aware of all the opportunities they may have when speaking this language. Opportunities like the ones we have been blessed to have such as working as language teacher assistants in The United States of America and The United Kingdom.

LEADS Language Center will open teaching English, but it is our purpose to include French, Italian, Chinese, German and sign language in a near future. The center will open with 5 classrooms. Every classroom will hold no more than 15 students so they have a cooperative and more personalized learning environment.
Students will attend their classes twice a week for two hours each. On Fridays, They will attend a more relaxed and communicative class where they can practice what they have learned through games and fun activities.
The school will also have a cafeteria where students will be able to interact with their classmates and the staff. At the same time they will practice their English because the menu will be written in the target language and the staff from the cafeteria will speak English as well.

In the last five years, we have worked in different language institutions in and outside Mexico, and we have taken the best strategies and methods to teach and learn a second language. Thanks to this, we feel confident we can assume the responsability of being in front of one and offer the best quality in the service we provide.

This project is very imporant and valuable  because with it you are contributing to open more and better opportunities to people who want to change and improve  their lives.

Explica tu campaña en mayor detalle y cuéntale a la gente la diferencia que hará su contribución:

explica por qué tu proyecto es valioso para el colaborador y para el mundo.

Describe tu historial de éxito en proyectos como este (si lo tienes).

Haz que la gente lo sienta real y genera confianza.

Riesgos y desafíos

We know and we are aware of the challenge that leaving our comfort zone and quitting our jobs to fulfill our biggest dream is, however we feel ready to go for it.  Opening a new school, requires patience and a lot of work. Some of the challenges we've faced when making our decision were the fear of the new and unknown. Nevertheless, due to the employment situation in Mexico, we decided it was time to change our picture and be able to change other people's as well. 

Another challenge is money. As middle class mexicans, we have always been conscious of the importance of it when thinking of a project. Since we were children, we have heard that you won't able to outstand if you don't have a lot of money, however, we have learned it is not always true. When there is passion and love for what you do, you can always find the way to get it and nowadays thanks to technology we can reach many people who believe in our dreams.

After Leads Language Center is opened, we'll have the objective to maintain our students interested in learning English and happy for their achievements, creating a fun, communicative and relaxing environment.

Due to the world crisis, Mexico is going through a very hard economic situation and that is affecting all sectors. Therefore, we know that openning a new school in the middle of this economic situation is our biggest risk; however, it is our challenge to turn obstacles into opportunities providing our students  with a very important tool to oustand and succed in today's world, which is knowing a foreing language.


Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

We appreciate that you took your time to read through our project. If you also believe that it can be possible, your contribution will be of a great help. If you cannot donate please help us spread the word by sharing our project with others you think may help. Thank you, Thank you, Thank you.
story_txt: Breve reseñaCarmina, Ramon, and Magaly, we are three Mexicans who despise having a not very good economic background are part of a very small group of mexicans who have gone to the university. We majored in Teaching Foreign Languages. The three of us speak English, French, and Spanish, and we believe that speaking another language in addition to our mother tongue has  changed our lives fulfilling most of our personal and professional goals.Now as English teachers we have worked in different language institutions in England, The United States, and Mexico. We describe ourselves as passionate, we love and enjoy being surrounded by people sharing experiences, supporting, and encouraging them to look forward. As dreamers, we believe everything is possible and that no matter who you are you can always become the person you want to be. And as hard-working, we are convinced that in order to achieve any goal you must be persistantt when you don't get what you expect, updated to keep moving forward, and humble to accept and ask for help whenever you need it.LEADS is a Foreign Language Center aimed to teach different languages, primarly English  through a communicative method. Our target audience are people since the age of  15. We totally believe that nowadays is extremly important to know English in order to be part of the globalization demand. It's our goal to help people grow in ther personal, laboral and professional life through the learning English process.Its our dream to have a place where we can provide a service different from the other language centers in Colima. We dream in a place where we can share our experience, knowledge, and enthusiasm. We want to provide not only students a nice environment and well-equipped facilities where they can learn in a natural, fun, and interesting way, but also employees the best place to work, where they can be respected, valued, and appeciated for their performance, likewise they can perceive a fair salary to support their families.If you help us we are going to be able to start as soon as possible with our language center and equip the facilities with the needed material.In order to open our school we need:(all the costs are in mexican pesos)FACILITIES* 8 classrooms, a teachers' room, a library, a kitchen for a small cafeteria, reception and waiting room, and 2 restrooms.BUILDING SET UPBuilding remodeling ( air condicioning, painting, gypsum board instalation, electricity story: I am trying to help out a fantastic student athlete that is unable to afford the fee to play on a summer football team. He has made all the right efforts to play (good marks, part time job, selling fund raising tickets), but is still short of the required amount to play. I know this young man as I teach as well as coach him at my high school. It pains me to see so many young students at my inner city high school not able to participate in athletics because they are unable to pay the fees. I am hoping that I can raise the amount needed so that this summer is a fantastic one for this student. Thanks for reading!

story:
To our family and friends,

Purpose

We would like to get your financial support to be able to participate in the Art of Living (AOL) Foundation Yes! Teacher Training Course (TTC).   

Credibility 

Dominique:

I am the mother of three children including a teenage son.  I am a qualified veteran teacher and work in an inner city elementary school.  I also taught in the South.

Wendy:

I am the mother of a 26 year old son.  I have a master's degree in school nursing with a teaching certificate.  My experience is with elementary school age children and internship experience with teenagers in a suburban school. 

The Issue

We have seen situations where children experience hardships such as: death of a parent or family member, divorce,  broken intimate relationships, child abuse, molestation and homelessness.  There are those who have to combat attention deficit disorders, autism spectrum disorders and certain other learning difficulties.  What about the day to day stressors of school life like detention and suspension.

The problem is this; children have to find ways to handle their emotional pain of hurt or loss and they do not have the right tools to help cope. 

Urgent Need

There is a desperate need for more teachers to be trained to deliver the work of transformation.  This is fundraising effort is urgent because the YES! TTC is only offered two times a year in the Summer.  One course is offered in California and the other in the Dominican Republic (DR).  The course in DR starts in 6 days. This fundraiser is to help us get the training so we can bring the techniques to more children.  The sooner we become trained the sooner we are able to bring this technique to the school and the better chance we have to save these children's lives.

Our commitment:

Wendy:

I’m committed to working with all children.  Also, I am especially driven to preventing teen suicide.  I have led workshops with teenagers who expressed despair and hopelessness. And, as we all know, too many of them kill themselves because they didn’t think they could cope. I believe the YES! Program will allow them to see their self- worth and give them a sense of belonging.

Dominique:

I’m committed to working with all kids.  In addition, being the parent of a teenage boy, I feel I have the experience and the knowledge to be able to connect with them.  I’ve witnessed too many of our teenage boys going to jail because they lack motivation to complete their education.  I believe the YES! Program will offer a gentler approach compared to the conventional use of psychotherapies and medications. Why wait for another tragedy?

Fundraiser Financial Goal

Our goal is to raise $4500.00 by July 15, 2015. 

Your investment in our training will put us at the forefront of the global mission to bring the art of meditation to all children-NOW!  Your contribution would make it possible for us to do the program immediately so we can bring the techniques to the schools as soon as possible.

Imagine for a moment, a world where all young people and teens are able to think clearly, are able to focus, are confident, responsible and feel good about themselves despite their hardships?  What would life be like, for them , for parents and for teachers? 

How your money will be spent:

  1. The airfare will cost between $550.00 -$600.00 each via Jet Blue airlines.
  2. The course discount is $1500.00 each for the entire ten day course food and board included  

We figured we can do it if, 90 people were to give at least $50.00, we’ll definitely meet this goal.

Background

We both have many years of training and experience in the work of transformation.   Recently, we completed the Happiness Program, Sahaj Samadhi Meditation and Dominique completed the advanced level, Silence Course.  We both assisted in the ART Excel course for youth and the YES!  for teens courses.  In addition, we completed the Landmark Education Curriculum for Living and we have assisted many times around the Landmark Forum for young people and teens.    It was during these courses that we got to see the world from children's point of view. 

Dominique: 

  • Created an after-school  technology program for adults in the the community 
  •  Acknowledged for significant improvement in State Standardized Math test  Richland One School district Columbia South Carolina 
  • Organized annual career day event for five consecutive years in Irvington, NJ
  • Developed and enrolled four hundred students in American Tutor After-School Tutoring Program

Wendy:

  • Organized a Career day event with many distinguished guest including the Honorable Cory Booker
  • Organized a Sports, Health/Fitness fair
  • Promoted and enrolled  guest speaker and 4-time Olympic track and field star Joetta Clark-Diggs to speak at the school
  • I wrote a grant for a dental program which was awarded $3000.00 from Deltal Dental it served about 100 third grade students

We are proud of our accomplishments and though we are very clear that our work inspired many over the years.  We do recognize however that there is something missing in the transformation of the school environment.  We finally discovered the missing piece and that is -meditation. 

We recognize that this concept of maintaining a peaceful mind is the training that is missing in the school environment. Further, having recently assisted during a YES! Course we are confident that if children have access to the techniques of the program such as; rhythmic breathing, meditation and yoga, it will improve their ability to focus, maintain concentration, control negative emotions and develop their leadership skills. 

On June 23, 2015, Dominique and I had the honor of meeting the world-renown philantropist and spiritual leader, Sri Sri Ravi Shankar (Guruji).  We were humbled by his presence and admire his compassionate and joyful nature.  We shared our interest and enthusiasm about participating in the upcoming YES! TTC, he smiled and gave us his blessings.  We then applied and we were accepted! 


Thank you so much for your support and patronage!

Sincerely,

Wendy & Dominique

story:
Short Summary

My wife, Holly, sadly passed away recently following a 19 month battle with breast cancer. Her school have chosen to rename the school library in her memory and I would like to raise some much needed funds to help make the library something truly incredible, just like Holly was!

What We Need & What You Get

I want the library to be the best any school has ever seen, containing a big, inspirational story telling chair, interior decoration with well loved story characters, LOTS of books and resources to aid the children and much more for the children to enjoy. Holly inspired children through literacy and this must continue!

The Impact

Your contributions will help to improve the lives of many children and positively assist them in their individual development.
Thank you so much in advance, it would mean a lot to a truly incredible woman whom we all miss dearly!
Matt

story:
What We Need & What You Get

What we need:

We're hoping to raise $1,000 to go towards the following needs for our Youth, Education, Empowerment & the Arts programs:

  • $360 for youth to be fed a meal and/or snacks at our programming *At one of our programs, students come during lunchtime to do personal, professional, and educational development as well as dance. We want to make sure they have a full meal to replace their usual lunch.
  • $560 for programmatic materials and supplies including paper for worksheets, art supplies, performance props and supplies, as well as instructional materials needed to implement our Youth, Education, Empowerment & the Arts programs in schools and communities.
  • $80 to cover operational and administrative costs associated with the program.

In return, you get the following perks:

  • $10 - Superstar Donation: You get a personal note from our Executive Director, Daphne Valcin, about your awesomeness!
  • $20 - Beacon of Light Donation: You get a personal note from our Executive Director, Daphne Valcin, about your awesomeness & a shout out on our Facebook and Twitter social media channels! Thank you for being a Beacon of Light!
  • $50 - Inspirational Funder Donation: Thank you for being an inspiration! For this donation, you'll get a personal note from our Executive Director, Daphne Valcin and a mention on our website as one of our 2014 Inspirational Funders!
  • $100 - Empowering Funder Donation: Thank you for being an inspiration! For this donation, you'll get a personal note from our Executive Director, Daphne Valcin and a mention on our website as one of our 2014 Empowering Funders!
  • $200 - Foundation Builder Donation: Thanks for playing an integral role in laying a foundation for our youth! Thank you for being an inspiration! For this donation, you'll get a personal note from our Executive Director, Daphne Valcin and a mention on our website as one of our 2014 Foundation Builders. If you represent an organization, we will also add your logo to our website as a list of one of our official 2014 Foundation Builders!

With your help, we KNOW we can reach our goal!

The Impact

About our Youth, Education, Empowerment, & the Arts program:

  • Through this program, young women from under-resourced high schools participate in a multi-step program in which career and college preparation, as well as self and community empowerment-oriented assignments, are completed and submitted to help lay the foundation for success!
  • In one of our major YEEA programs, the middle school our students attends is an "F" school, and a large number of our participants will be first generation college students, using the information and resources they gain from our program to develop personally, educationally, and professionally.

Through our youth empowerment program:

  • Each personalized workshop integrates the performing arts, empowerment, and components we feel will make specific participants successful: College and Career Preparation; Life Skills; Arts; and Self and Community Empowerment (CLAS). 
  • From 2003 until now, youth from our program partners in Philadelphia, Florida, Washington, D.C., and Maryland have benefited greatly from our empowerment programs in ways that have provided them with expanded knowledge and opportunities towards their dreams.

What is Project Inspire?

Are you ready to be part of a movement? We know our youth need inspiration in their lives, cultural empowerment to remember their place of power in the world, and preparation for the opportunities that await them. 

That's what we do at Project Inspire.

The mission of Project Inspire is to empower youth and young adults through powerful personal, educational and professional opportunities to using the arts as a gateway to achievement, and we've been doing so for 10 years as an initiative and the past 2 years as a 501 (c)(3) organization in schools and programs in Atlanta, Philadelphia, Florida, Washington, D.C., and Maryland through our scholarship and youth empowerment programs. 

You can find out more about us at http://www.inspirethemovement.org.

Help us to make our youth's dreams come true!


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Our youth deserve it!
  • You can share right on this page!

Go forth, and Inspire the Movement!

In one of our major YEEA programs, the middle school our students attends is an "F" school, and a large number of our participants will be first generation college students, using the information and resources they gain from our program to develop personally, educationally, and professionally.
Through our youth empowerment program:
Each personalized workshop integrates the performing arts, empowerment, and components we feel will make specific participants successful: College and Career Preparation; Life Skills; Arts; and Self and Community Empowerment (CLAS). 
From 2003 until now, youth from our program partners in Philadelphia, Florida, Washington, D.C., and Maryland have benefited greatly from our empowerment programs in ways that have provided them with expanded knowledge and opportunities towards their dreams.
What is Project Inspire?Are you ready to be part of a movement? We know our youth need inspiration in their lives, cultural empowerment to remember their place of power in the world, and preparation for the opportunities that await them. That's what we do at Project Inspire.The mission of Project Inspire is to empower youth and young adults through powerful personal, educational and professional opportunities to using the arts as a gateway to achievement, and we've been doing so for 10 years as an initiative and the past 2 years as a 501 (c)(3) organization in schools and programs in Atlanta, Philadelphia, Florida, Washington, D.C., and Maryland through our scholarship and youth empowerment programs. You can find out more about us at http://www.inspirethemovement.org.Help us to make our youth's dreams come true!Other Ways You Can HelpSome people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:
Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Our youth deserve it!
You can share right on this page!
Go forth, and Inspire the Movement!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • My name is Paul Raso and I am the Executive Director of a Non Profit organization in Toronto Ontario Called Education Involved Advocacy Group. Our mandate is to advocate for parents in Toronto's Jane and Finch community in respects to navigating the very scary and confusing world of education as well as to create engaging after school learning opportunities for youth aged 15-29.  
  • All with the aim of reducing the number of lives lost to gun violence in the community each year.
  • Prior to this I worked  as a teacher for 10 years and a vice principal for 2 in the Jane and Finch community.  I also worked as a vice principal for 1 year in Rexdale before resigning my job as VP to start Education Involved.
  • Throughout my tenure as a secondary school educator I taught, coached, facilitated international educational experiences for students (Kenya, Mexico, Japan), developed award winning experiential curriculum (program still running), and worked on a steering committee for the Ministry of Education's Urban Priority High School Grant program.
  • Throughout my tenure I also saw two communities plagued with violence (I have been to almost 2 funerals for every years I was teaching I do not use the word plague lightly) and marginalized in two very important areas of education; Parent engagement and experiential learning/differentiated instruction. 
  • Yes every board in the province has a mandated parent advisory committee that meets on a regular basis. (some more than others).  But the needs of the Jane and Finch community of parents require a presence, a voice, and an involvement that is simply not there.  The families I encounter, the stories I hear (and witnessed while working as a teacher/VP), the people we help are all representatives of how the 'one size fits all' or token programs are simply not enough for some of the communities.  It is even to the extent where you could make an argument public education has become inequitable. (I don't have enough room in this pitch to articulate this but if you would like to discuss feel free to contact me directly. paul@educationinvolved.org)
  • Every board also has designated 'alternative education' programs. However, the  learning environments that provide all types of learners and intelligences an opportunity to not only be smart, but relevant, and included, are often just that; 'ALTERNATIVE.  Kids who participate in some of these programs can be made to feel stupid, delinquent, or like they don't belong.  I mean how would you feel if your perfectly relevant skill set or learning style was labelled 'alternative' or as some face; only fostered in an after school capacity, like achievements in such warrant nothing more than congratulations for getting involved. 
  • What brought this about was a chance meeting between a WWE superstar and teachers college graduate Santino Marella (Anthony Carelli) and myself.  We discussed education and our connection to it as well as what we both felt it could and should be. Anthony already runs a pro wrestling course at Battle Arts Academy in Mississauga, but it is for members only.  So I told him what we were doing and he stepped up to the challenge of offering something for all kids to have an opportunity to participate in while maintaining the priority of providing opportunity to those who would otherwise not be able to participate. Mr. Carelli has been instrumental in helping us offset costs and raise money.  This includes having the poster designed, and made as well as dedicating time at each show for Education Involved to connect with parents.
  • Too often charitable efforts yield a mindset of substandard products or services, after all they are free right?  Well we disagree.  If our learning experiences are not good enough to pay for than they are not good enough for charity.  
  • It is our goal to be able to one day sponsor at least 20% of our spots in courses via our own revenue streams.  However we are only a year old as an organization so we are asking for some help in the meantime.  

What We Need And What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We need $1871.48  This will provide registration and transportation for 4 students.  Each student represents a fee of $467.87. ($299+hst =337.87 for course + $10/ week for 13 weeks of transportation.)  Total per student is $467.87.)
  • We have perks and givebacks at many levels of donation. 
  • If we do not reach the entire goal the funds will remain untouched until we can afford to send an additional student.  Education Involved Advocacy Group takes very seriously your ability to put your money towards any of our programs.  
  • If we surpass goals money will be directed towards future spots in the course for needy youth, work to support parents in the Jane and Finch community in their ability to navigate the world of their child's education, or be directed appropriately in conjunction with the donor. 

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • You will provide 4 youth the opportunity to participate to learn from a WWE superstar while supporting their education.  You also help reinforce a message for 4 young women or men that their passions, learning capacities, and intelligences are valued, important, and relevant.
  • You will also provide 4 young men or women the opportunity to represent their community (wherever that is) in a fun, exciting and charitable event.  A wrestling show where participants will sell tickets, bolster support, and show off the character and superstar they have created.  All in the context of not only fun and service to others but also through the scope of a very real and thriving industry that has been a part of Canadian culture since before the first Wrestlemania.
  • By providing an opportunity for students to train and learn at one of the province's top facilities we are sending a message to kids that they deserve the best.  Not a generic knock off, not a second rate venue just because it is coming from a non-profit organization but he very best. Not that this happens with every non-profit or charity but it does happen in the 'industry'. I have seen it from breakfast clubs to motivational speakers. I have also seen the amazing work that charities in and out of the Jane and Finch community do that literally save lives on a daily basis and give people the integrity and respect they deserve and need in their lives.  These are the organizations we aspire to be like.  To us this ability to provide the best quality has a profound impact on the way students view and internalize themselves and their own capability.
  • This is our first program as an organization so not only are you helping 4 kids specifically, but you are contributing to the effort to advocate for the equity of education in a community that needs after school programs that are rooted in the viability of education to play an integral role in saving lives.  It is sad to say but right now it is not.  
  • Most importantly everything we do at Education Involved Advocacy Group is geared towards helping parents get involved, and kids re-engage in education as a means of reducing the senseless number of lives lost to gun violence in the community.

Risks and Challenges

Right now our biggest obstacle is our ability to subsidize members of our community.  Education Involved Advocacy group is a brand new organization.  We are adopting the model of a 'social enterprise' in that we will use a business model to raise money for our social goal of equity in education.  One of our paid services will be experiential learning opportunities such as this one. (Others will be workshops series for parents on navigating the world that is their child's education) With the revenues generated from paid programs we hope to be able to one day cover operating costs so that grants and donations can go towards more program subsidies for members of the Jane and Finch community.   As we have yet to secure any public funding (we are at the mercy of granting schedules and donors giving seasons so to speak.  That is our next step) so in the interim we are trying to provide spots for 20% of the inaugural after school program. 

  • What qualifies us to over come this hurdle is 13 years experience educating in the Jane and Finch community.
  • A director with administrative experience in education as well as having sat on steering committee for a Ministry of Education Urban Priority High School Grant team.
  • Our plan for solving these issues is simple, work with and listen to a community so that we can offer advocacy where it is needed and support where it is asked.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have read this far you have already helped us by giving us a fighting chance. (see what we did there)  We appreciate your time and wish you all the best.  

Education Involved Advocacy Group

story:
My Story

Hello, and thank you for taking the time to read about my crowdfunding campaign!

I am Dr. Terrance E. Dillard, the founder of Digital Countermeasures, Inc.  Digital Countermeasures is an Information Technology, Information Security Company that specializes in Information Assurance and Privacy Awareness Education.

Our mission is to provide a comprehensive array of information security principles and best practices to our customers that are based on a globally recognized body of knowledge, which raises awareness surrounding information, and how to protect information assets from hacking incidents or unauthorized access.  Our company not only provides information security solutions and resources to our clients, but we also provide certification training in various high-demand, high-reward Information Technology areas, such as CISSP®, CompTIA Network+, CompTIA Security+, Cisco Certified Network Associate (CCNA), Project Management Professional (PMP), as well as several Microsoft specialties.

As a Computer Science Professor, with more than 35 years of experience in both technology and information systems, I have observed the low number of African American youth pursuing careers in information science.  As a mentor, engineer, native of Detroit, and proud alum of Detroit Public Education, I have observed numerous barriers that have contributed to the lack of African American participation in science, engineering, and mathematics disciplines.

As a graduate of Detroit Public Schools (DPS), and observer of the myriad challenges that have befallen the district over the past forty-plus years,  I can appreciate how difficult it must be for any student within DPS to break through these barriers.  I have made it my new mission to provide a unique set of opportunities to students within Detroit Public Schools, and to provide a pathway for learners to enter into the highly rewarding fields of Information Technology and Cyber Security.  I am convinced that this program will help young African American students and their families stem the tide of poverty, despair, under-education, and high unemployment.

Impact

The plight of African American youth is thoroughly documented and well known across the United States; and the problem is particularly acute within the City of Detroit.  In a May 2015 U.S. News & World Report article, it was reported that African American men were one of the few groups within the nation that had not made significant strides in the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.  This is surprising, considering the amount of focus that many schools have placed on science and technology programs in recent years.  However, the less funding a school district has at its disposal, the less commitment schools have demonstrated to underwriting such high opportunity curricula [2].

A report from the National Science Foundation discovered that the number of African American men, who earned doctoral degrees in science and technology disciplines, grew by more than 25% over ten years, which may sound impressive on the surface.  However, when delving more deeply into the data, we find that, despite an overall increase in a ten year period, the ACTUAL total percentage of the overall population of Ph.D. recipients was less than 6.5% [2].

Clearly, more must be done to provide quality educational opportunities for African American youth if they are to take their rightful place within the science and technology community.  Exposure, Guidance, and Mentoring have been proven as  critical success factors in the overall acquisition and educational attainment of African American students [3].  If public schools fail to gain the necessary funding to underwrite such crucial programs for learners within the African American community, someone must step up and lead the way.


The Solution

Schools and public education programs that have adopted Science, Technology, Engineering, & Math (STEM), as well as Project-Based Learning (PBL) into their curriculum have discovered that, in addition to enhancing a student’s potential for competitive economic advantage, it also helps to increase SAT and achievement test scores.  With a focus on critical thinking and higher-level thinking skills these programs expose students to patterns of logical deduction, recognizing logical fallacies in reasoning, and engaging in problem solving and critical analysis [4; 5].

To expand African American participation in a highly technical, global marketplace, students will be exposed to programs that promote critical thinking skills within Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math; as well as incorporate real-world experience through labs and simulations.  With my vast background as an Information Technology professional, and Professor, students will become highly skilled as I.T. professionals, and will be able to secure a position as interns and co-op students, beginning at the high school level.  This opportunity will also bring much needed income into their families and communities, and start making a difference for the city of Detroit!

The Need

Although Digital Countermeasures is an incredibly successful company, we need additional capital to expand our training programs to meet the needs of this underserved community. With your help, we can make this possible!

Through this campaign, I am seeking to raise $125,000 dollars to fund the I.T. Certification Training of 192 African American high school students (grades 10 through 12).  Each student will be provided approximately 62 hours of training in Computer Networking, and education in the fundamentals of Information Security.  Our curriculum will expose each learner to a broad array of hands-on activities and principles, which will culminate in each student being certified in an industry recognized and respected credential in Information Systems.  My team and I will guide each student along a path, which will be informed by real-world experience and background as Information Technologists.  Students will be mentored and nurtured into the community of information science.  I have provided a short list of curriculum topics that will be covered in this course:

  • Networking Basics
  • Cables & Connectors
  • Networking Devices
  • Ethernet
  • IP Configuration
  • Switch Management
  • Routing
  • Firewalls
  • Network Customization
  • Wireless Networking
  • Wide Area Networking
  • Network Policies and Procedures
  • Network Security
  • Network Hardening
  • Network Optimization
  • Certification Exam Preparation

There are numerous internships and co-operative job opportunities available with various Fortune 100, Fortune 500, Healthcare, Retail, Higher Ed., Public, and Private firms around our region.  Each of our students will be given access to available opportunities to hone in, and further develop their newly acquired skills in Information Technology.  Your generous donation will help us bridge a significant gap for African American students who may desire a career in Information Technology or Cyber Security.  By providing these students the opportunity to become highly skilled I.T. professionals, we are helping them pursue high-paying, high-growth careers in Information Science, and enabling them to chart a rewarding path for their future.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you are unable to make a donation at this time, there are still ways that you may be able to support this worthwhile endeavor!  Please take a few moments to share this campaign with your friends and family via social media, E-mail, and through word of mouth!  Please share the plight of African American youth with those closest to you, and help us gather the necessary funds to provide this crucial training, which will help Detroit students to be successful.

    Without your support, it will take longer for us to reach our goal, and will run the risk of delaying the delivery of the program until we become fully funded.  There is no amount of donation that is too small.  Let’s work together to ensure that Detroit high school graduates are successful, and competitive upon graduation!  Please Donate today!

    Me and my team at Digital Countermeasures thank you in advance for your generous contribution and support!

    Kind Regards,

    Dr. Terrance E. Dillard
    Founder & CEO
    Digital Countermeasures, Inc.


    Sources:
    [1] Rather, Dan. (2011). A National Disgrace: Detroit Public Schools [Motion picture excerpts]. HDNet.

    [2] http://www.usnews.com/news/stem-solutions/articles/2015/05/07/african-american-men-the-other-stem-minority

    [3] Mentoring minority graduate students: issues and strategies for institutions, faculty, and students. Equal Opportunities International, 26(3), 178-192.

    [4] Becker, W. (2015, January 12). Physics First: STEM and PBL Drives Higher SAT Scores and Grad Rates at Loyola High School. Retrieved from http://blog.iat.com/2015/01/12/physics-first-stem-pbl-drives-higher-sat-scores-and-grad-rates-loyola-high-school/

    [5] Sanford, N. (2013, April 1). Test scores rise to the top at STEM-centered high school. Retrieved from http://stemwire.org/2013/04/01/at-stem-centered-high-school-test-scores-rise-to-the-top/

    [6] DCM (2015, November 18). Exposure, Guidance, & Mentoring [Video file]. Retrieved from https://youtu.be/NDb5lfT_p_0

Me and my team at Digital Countermeasures thank you in advance for your generous contribution and support!Kind Regards,Dr. Terrance E. DillardFounder & CEODigital Countermeasures, Inc.Sources:

story:
Sometimes the things we take for granted are what another person desires, and one of these things is an education. School has become so part of our everyday routine that we don't stop to take a minute to truly appreciate it. However, in developing countries, education is harder to receive, especially for girls.This fundraiser is designed to help raise money for organizations who will ultimately provide education for girls in South Asia.

Short Summary

    • My family ties are from Pakistan and both of my parents’ entire families live there. I visit Pakistan annually but ten years ago when I visited, there was a girl of my age (at that time I was 6 years old) who used to come daily with her mother to clean our house. Often, she was not wearing any shoes and later I found out that she could not afford to buy any. I then asked my mother about why she doesn’t go to school and goes to clean people’s houses instead. That’s when my mother explained and tried to help me understand the poverty as well as affordability for impecunious families to send their children to receive an education. They had to send their children at a very young age to bring money for the family. This is the story of just one the girls in the third world countries of South Asia and there are many more.

    I grew up thinking that I will make a difference and do something to help the system, which ultimately led me to create this fundraiser. In this effort, I will raise the funds and distribute to known organizations who are genuinely working to have free schools and higher educations in the remote areas of such countries.

    By providing education to women in these countries will not only benefit them but will also ameliorate the economics and the demographics of the country. Educated women are more likely to seek medical care for themselves and their families and provide proper nutrition and sanitation at home. These practices can ensure healthier and well-nourished families and communities.


Donations

  • My goal currently is to raise $1500 and I will increase the amount as this progresses.

  • One of the organizations I’m going to be donating the money to is the Imran Khan Foundation (please refer to link below)

  • http://www.imrankhanfoundation.org.pk/about-ikf...

  • Every $10 donation will receive a thank you message as an appreciation for your kind gesture and every $100 donation will receive an E-card from our beneficiaries as a thank you.

  • Even if I don’t reach my desired goal, all donations will still go to these organizations.

The Impact

Educating women is not only beneficiary for themselves but also for their families, communities, and the country:

  • Girls play a huge role for global development. Educating them can help increase economic productivity, lower maternal and infant mortality, improve nutritional health, reduce poverty, and help wipe out diseases such as HIV and AIDS.

  • Educated women are also less likely to b vulnerable towards sexual abuse or exploitation which can ultimately protect them against sexually-transmitted infections such as HIV or AIDS.

  • Educated women are more likely to stay in school longer which will delay their marriage and when or how many children they may have. It’s estimated that one year of female schooling will reduce fertility by ten percent. Because educated women will have children later on in their lives, their babies will be healthier and they will know how to properly care for them.

  • Educated women can also reduce poverty. They will have a better grasp on their domestic role and can share the household duties more evenly with their spouse. They will have access to higher-paying jobs, which will help their families financially and contribute to their national economy.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t donate, you can still help by spreading the link to this fundraiser.

Thank you for your time and generosity.

story:
Who Are We?

Thank you for taking the time to look into this project. We are two final year BA (Hons) Media Production students at Bournemouth University and aspiring media producers. We both have a love for live performance and how new media forms can be used in live performance. We have worked in multiple projects together including our first projection mapped piece "Breaking Free". This project is highly ambitious and we need your help to succeed!


The Project

The project is an immersive, projection mapped narrative, held within a space and involving live performers interacting with projection.

In a world where self-expression is prohibited, the idea of the individual simply does not exist: art has been destroyed; song has been forgotten; dance has been forbidden. A world with no expression is a world of peace.

One young dancer is forced to perform in secret, trying to escape The Dictator's soul-destroying 'Shadow Army' from draining her personality  She cannot contain her expression and as she performs, her light is released - catching the attention of a fellow rebellion. Together they relish in their common ability and dance together, forgetting the austerity of the world - if only for a moment. 

In their fight for freedom, their differing personalities tear the two apart. The only way they can fight the shadows is to unite the rebels light and rid the world of the darkness. 


What We Need & What You Get

For this project to really make an impact we need help to bring the production to life with funding needed in several areas:

  • Xylobands - One major part of this project is to make the audience feel as if they are fully immersed in the story. For this we will be hiring Xylobands that we can control to light up in areas of the story. Some lucky funders will even be able to keep one!
  • Event Location - We may not have to spend a huge amount in this area thanks to free to book spaces for students. Any money left over in this area however will go towards providing food and drink for the event to ensure our audience has the best time possible!
  • Equipment - Although we are lucky enough to have access to a wide array of kit, this is an entirely new project for our course. Therefore we will be needing extra bits of kit such as midi controllers to make the live experience even more spectacular. 
  • Costumes and Props - To really create our dystopian narrative we will need to dress our performers and set to make it feel authentic.
By contributing to our funding, we will be offering a variety of perks. Take a look on the side-bar to see if there is anything you wanted to claim!

The Impact

As students working towards our final ever university project, we want to make this more spectacular than any other project we have worked on. Not only is this project the largest percentage of our final degree, but it is also the work that we will carry with us when searching for a job after university, so therefore we want to be incredibly proud of the final outcome. 

The Team

     Frankie Leonard: Director

     Grace Weston: Producer

     Laura Dodds: Technical Assistant and Lighting

     Tom Cotton: Camera and Photography

     Amy Hall: Assistant Editor and Event Photographer

     Iv Marks: Sound Recordist 

     Leanne Kent: Production Manager

     Michael Ellis: Event Lighting and Technical Support

 

  Anna Clayton: Set Up Crew and Event Sound Recordist

     Sophie Arnold: Set Up Crew and Event Sound 

     Alex Torrens: Set Up Crew and Event Camera

     Will Knight: Event Camera

     Christian Maltby: Production Assistant 

     Giselle Monkhouse: Choreographer

     Hannah Bowen: Music and Composition

Other Ways You Can Help

As students ourselves, we understand that many of you don't have the money to spare! If you can't spare even the smallest amount then please check out and share our social media pages and spread the word about this exciting project. If you can also share this campaign then you have already been a massive help!

story:
Hi, I am Victoria, 21. When I was 17 I left my home country - Kazakhstan - to study abroad. It was never my dream to study in Kazakhstan due to corrupt educational system and still-ussr-type of education itself. That's why I decided to go and study in Europe.

However, it did took me a while to realise that my single mother couldn't cover the tuition. Thus, after two years in university, right after finishing my sophomore year, I had to go back home in order to pay the loans which were taken to pay for the school. I had the hopes of saving some money for the college to go on studying.

It's been a year now and any of my attempts to try to leave were sentenced to failure. I can not leave the country as I have certain financial responsibilities (loans). The eaverage salary I receive im my city is $350 per month. I would never ask for help if the situation had ever been so complicated. What I do ask for is the amount of money to cover the loans I have as this is the only factor that backs me up. If you have ever been a college student, you probably know how much does it take to sustain yourself as the human being. Any help will be appreciated. Thank you in advance,

Victoria.

story:
Short Summary

Eleven students from a small school in rural Appalachia want to become lawyers. Last year, we created our school's first ever mock trial team in the hopes that our students would be one step closer to achieving their dreams. Through our high school's mock trial program, these 11 students had the chance to become lawyers and witnesses and argue a case in actual courtrooms. Thanks to your donation, last year, these hard working students walked away with an award as one of the top 10 mock trial teams in the state.

This year, our students are continuing to work week nights and weekends for months to prepare for the Kentucky High School Mock Trial State Tournament, and this year, they are shooting for a top 5 spot in the state.

It was because of you that our students experienced the thrill of the courtroom and the deep satisfaction that comes with fulfilling one's dreams. Help us get them where they want to go again. 

Our students come from an area where more than 80% of families are considered low income. Most of our students have never experienced the things that most high school students take for granted, such as being able to leave the county, having a multitude of organizations to join and having the ability to fund-raise quickly and easily in the community. Instead our students are worried about not having notebooks to take to class or finding $5 to go see a movie with friends on the weekend. Raising $1,500 to compete in a mock trial tournament is something our students would never experience without your help. 

What We Need

To cover the basic costs of the competition we will need: 

Transportation: $500

Hotel: $500

Food: $250

Case Materials: $250

TOTAL: $1,500

Impact

Many of our students have never left the counties they have grown up in. Many of them will not leave the area if they decide to go to college. Having the experience of leaving the county to participate in a mock trial tournament gives them the experience many other high school students take for granted and helps to open more opportunities for them to attend prestigious universities. 

Attending the mock trial competition will help our students gain the experience needed to get into a law school program of their choice, which gets them one step closer to their law degree. Achieving their goal allows them to come back to the impoverished community they grew up in, open local businesses, and use the law to create a stronger community for the local families that they love and care for.

Other Ways You Can Help

Our students appreciate your donation. Please help our students reach their goal by sharing our students' story with those who can also contribute to our cause.

story: I believe that when we want to make a big change in life, the right support is crucial for success. As a coach, I often have clients tell me things that they have never shared with anyone else. It's a privileged position to be in and I am honoured by the trust they give me. For this reason I also want to be able to give them even more when my current skills reach their limits. Training as a hypnotherapist in the Marisa Peer Method will allow me to give my clients more profoundly transformational experiences and allow them move forward and create the life they want and deserve. After all, don't we all deserve to feel happy and fulfilled? :)

story:
Who We Are...

"I started The GEMS Camp for the girls who are ridiculed for being smart. Girls who do everything they're supposed to do, but have to stay in their environments just because they don't have anywhere else to go. I wanted to give them what was given to me - a quality learning experience that made me curious about the world and compassionate about others in a safe environment." ~ Saki L. Milton, Founder 

The mission of The GEMS Camp - Girls interested in Engineering, Mathematics, and Science, is to build confidence in urban teen girls in five core areas called the Five Karat Gems - Academics, Career, Creativity, Leadership, and Service - so that they will be successful in STEM studies and careers. Since 2010, The GEMS Camp has engaged more than 150 girls in Dallas and Houston in STEM. 

Who We Serve...

Our holistic approach to STEM addresses several risk factors that are barriers for traditionally under-served populations, specifically:

  • 95% economically disadvantaged (Title 1 - free or reduced lunch)
  • 100% female
  • 50% Hispanic and African-American

Girls participate in an 8-week intensive Saturday program during the summer where they preview the upcoming school year's content from engaging certified math and science instructors, participate in hands-on project-based lessons, learn from successful women in STEM, complete six hours of community service, and apply practical leadership skills taught by trained, high school and college STEM mentors.

What's Your Imact...

THIS campaign is student-led! Each girl is  responsible for raising $100 by asking ten (10) people for $10 donations to reach our collective foal of $3,000. 90% of the proceeds raised will go back directly to the program. The other 10% will be donated to a 501c3 charity selected by our gems. Your gift will greatly help The GEMS Camp continue to serve girls in STEM by covering program expenses.

 - Fall field trip transportation

 - Instructional supplies: poster boards, markers, binders, notebooks, etc.

- Instructional technology:  tablets, WiFi hotspot, educational APPS

- Miscellaneous: Food, snacks, t-shirts, bags, facility rental, etc.

- Tutorial services throughout the school year


What You Get...

The GEMS Camp is a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt organization; therefore, your donation is 100% tax deductible. Great News!

If we do not reach our fundraising goal of $3,000, we will still donate 90% to The GEMS Camp and 10% to a charity in need.

For your $10 donation, we are offering your choice of five (5) different scents of organically-made lip balm packaged in a hand-made Origami box.  Each one is made by our GEMS as a continuation of their summer learning experience with Mary Kay engineers and scientists. These lip balms consist of basic ingredients: Vitamin E oil, coconut oil, and beeswax. The scents are Cherry-Berry, Lemon Cheesecake, Brown Sugar, White Chocolate, and Peppermint (regular, non-scented).




Ready to Help...

Choose a perk. Give your donation. Provide your contact information. Tell your friends, family, and coworkers! Share our campaign on social media.

story:
All I have ever wanted to do was teach, write and research.

I spend hours of my free time reading and writing for the betterment of myself, hoping to one day be in a position to spread what I read to others.  So, I am deciding to pursue graduate school at Florida International University for a combined MA in African & African Diaspora (AADS)\PhD in International Relations.

To be considered for this program, I must receive a score of 1120 in the Graduate Record Exam (GRE) and present a term paper that demonstrates that I have exceptional research abilities.

To ensure that I increase my candidacy for the program, I plan to enroll in a GRE prep course and an introductory African American History course at a nearby community college, which is why I have decided to crowd fund.

If you or anyone you know would like to contribute to my next academic venture, I would be more than appreciative as this has been a dream that I have been afraid to pursue for quite some time. 100% of your contributions will be used to enroll in both courses earlier stated.

All donators please e-mail me your current address at kandice1.hill@gmail.com. I would love to send you a thank you card as a physical, personable token of my gratitude.

kandice1.hill@gmail.com. I would love to send you a thank you card as a
physical, personable token of my gratitude.

story:
Do you love fun bags? We do too!  

This is a fun campaign that's so straight forward it does not even need a video. On October 1st we posted the "I ♥ Fun Bags"design on our Facebook page in honor of Breast Cancer Awareness Month.  We received many messages and e-mails in the past week requesting a t-shirt be made. 5% of the proceeds from this campaign will be donated to the National Breast Cancer Foundation.  About 1 in 8 U.S. women (about 12%) will develop breast cancer. We hope that you will join us in the fight, to bring support to breast cancer patients, survivors, and their loved ones.

                                   

Gili is a sustainable company founded just last year in July of 2014, making cool duffel bags for all sports, activities, and occasions. We started by making bags out extremely durable, multi-colored vinyl "TUFF"mesh. They are primarily for sports gear and equipment that needs to dry out, from scuba diving and whitewater rafting, to football, soccer, lacrosse, etc. Then we introduced an eco-friendly, all-season duffel bag made from upcycled waterproof billboard vinyl that would have been thrown away. Upcycling is the process of converting waste materials or useless products into new materials or products of better quality or for better environmental value. People loved the idea and thanks to a successful crowdfunding campaign last May, Gili bags are now in use all over the world helping people have FUN, enjoying what they love doing!                           

         

In further effort to support our goal of raising awareness towards a more sustainable future as well as breast cancer awareness, we decided to run another campaign that is a little different. Bypassing the headache of dealing with a complex design and production process, we outsourced 3 items instead. All the artwork has been submitted and just a click of the mouse away from placing orders. Each perk is made here in America and will have the "I ♥ Fun Bags" design on it.

Our eco-friendly Fun Bag for this campaign is the very awesome: 

• I ♥ Fun Bags Bagito - A full-sized reusable shopping bag that comes on a key chain and when unfolded can hold +20lbs. Each year, an estimated 500 billion to 1 trillion plastic bags are consumed worldwide. That's over one million plastic bags used per minute. I know, it hurts to think about. Stop being part of the problem and start being part of the solution! Use something, anything reusable.

Bagito was created to fund environmental literacy for the  K-12 students. Made in California from 100% recycled plastics and donating 100% of net revenues to teach the next generation to value and sustain their natural world. To learn more or get involved yourself, please visit: www.bagito.co and www.Power2Sustain.org. These are a great eco-friendly promotional item that any company can/should use.  

• I ♥ Fun Bags Sticker -this postcard sticker is made with heavyweight backing paper by Sticker Robot, known for the "highest quality sticker printing on the planet".  Whether using yourself or sending to a friend, postcards have always been an effective, simple way of getting a message out there. What better message to spread this month than that of breast cancer awareness.

                           

Last but not least, by popular demand:

•I ♥ Fun Bags T-shirt - Screen printed on a super comfy tri-blend (50% Polyester / 25% Cotton / 25% Rayon) fabric in our home state of Colorado. Enjoy everything you love about the fit, feel and durability of a vintage T-shirt, in a brand new version. Surely you know someone that would love to wear this!

                           


If you would like to make a donation directly to the National Breast Cancer Foundation or to start your own fundraiser, go to  https://fundraise.nbcf.org/.

For more reasons to use a reusable shopping bag check out the link below. WARNING: Content is disturbing if you care about our environment at all. http://www.inspirationgreen.com/plastic-bag-stats.html

Please email us if you have any questions at info@giligear.com

#iheartfunbags 

#ilovefunbags 

#gilibags

story:
I just left Moshi, Tanzania after an inspiring and long overdue reunion with the students and teachers at St. Timothy’s School! This time two years ago, I was given an overwhelming amount of love and support that was needed to partner with the community leaders to build an additional classroom and comprehensive computer lab!

In addition to the completed classroom and computer lab, school leaders have since purchased two additional school buses that provide reliable and safe transport, initiated sustainability projects and the school’s boarding home has been expanded to house 120 students, many of which who are orphaned or vulnerable. It's amazing to see the school fulfil its mission to become a cornerstone for quality education in the community and the entire Kilimanjaro region.

Now, the goal is to put the finishing touches on a much needed additional classroom. Due to St. Timothy’s growing reputation for academic excellence and top tier campus, the school has enrolled almost 100 new students the last year. Although this has allowed for the enrollment of 30 vulnerable students, who could otherwise afford access to education, many of the class sizes are too large. The nursery class has almost doubled from previous years with 52 students filling one classroom. The large class size has created noise distractions and the students don’t get the special attention they would receive in a smaller class.

Once the classroom is finished, the nursery classes will be divided into two to promote a healthier and more productive learning environment that upholds St. Timothy’s high standard of academic excellence.

HERE'S HOW YOU CAN HELP! I am committed to raising the final $2,000 needed to put the finishing touches on the much needed classroom! The students begin their term break on July 31st, so materials can be gathered and the construction can proceed if we raise the money in 7 days. The most exciting part- the classroom will be ready for learning when the students return to school on September 1st.

St. Timothy's needs approximately 4,765,000 Tanzanian shillings (about 2,000 USD) to insert the windows, plaster the walls and to finish the corridor. The funds also support locally employed masons and transport drivers. 

I am calling on all of my family and friends to help St. Timothy’s School and Mama Hope FINISH the classroom and give these young minds the space they need to grow and thrive!

Any support would mean so much to me, and even more to the most impressive primary students I know! I am asking for you to give whatever you can to help me reach this goal! This small goal will foster the growth of hundreds of children for generations to come. If you can’t donate at this time, please spread the word by sharing the campaign on your Facebook page.

Thank you and much love from Tanzania!

Katie

story:
Short Summary

The Hope Community Orphanage is a home for children who have previously lived on the streets of Agbobloshie, a slum in Accra. They are either orphans or children whose parents can no longer take care of them. There are 27 boys living at Hope full time. Their days are spent going to school, doing laundry, playing soccer, and reading in the library. Their fully stocked library is only missing one thing-- computers! The goal of this campaign is to raise sufficient funds to purchase three desktop computers, which the boys will use to practice English and develop critical computer skills allowing them to feel empowered for a successful life after Hope. Some of the older boys will use the computers to research and apply for university. 

Growing boys need to eat! Hope provides three hearty meals a day for every child that walks through its doors, including members of the larger community. Currently, the staff at Hope use a single stove to feed upwards of 40 children a day. Of the money raised from this campaign, $200 will go towards purchasing a new stove for Hope, which will allow them to better serve the children and community.

story:
Hi everybody.

I'm Ginevra, I'm italian. 

I thought to create an app to help students studying for their exams. 
Through gamification, in a continuos way, It is easier learn new topics.

We have a lot of "empty time" when we are on queue waiting for professors, in banks, post office or in secretary. Instead to reade useless stuff on web, we could use that time to start studying something without arrive at the beginning of exams session with a lot of books we could never read on time! 

This app will not exclude the traditional stady, but only integrate It with a dynamical interaction between professor and student (peer to peer). The student will be prepared in class and will know before what teacher is going to talk about. The student could prepare his questions on the topic and this avoid to lose time at the next lesson.

On this experience, I'm going to write my final thesis. I'm paying by myself this project, working in a bar in my birth city, but I need your help.

Once It will be ready, you can download the app for free and learn something about digital sociology :)

The app developer asked me for 3.000€ and 1.000€ is going to the graphic designer. I earned 2.000in the bar and now I have to come back to my study, so I need your help!

The app will be available in iOS and Android, too :)

story:
What you need to know:

We are a group of 5 students (Savannah, Emily, Sam, Mary and Rachel) and one adult advisor (Erin) from the Montessori High School at University Circle in Cleveland, Ohio. An X-Term is a 2-week intensive course at the end of May during which students study unique topics in small groups. The students are responsible for selecting the topic and planning the course of study, obtaining approval for the course from the school, recruiting a teacher to serve as our chaperone, and, most importantly, raising all of the funds needed to make the X-Term a success. Our X-Term group will complete an in depth literary analysis of J.K. Rowling’s Harry Potter series. The capstone of our X-Term will be a trip to Harry Potter World in Orlando, Florida. We have fundraised 80% of the money we need for this X-Term, by donating you will be helping us to fulfill our plan and get that extra 20% for our X-Term. We are trying to raise a total of $800 on Indiegogo. We've worked really hard all year on planning and fundraising and this is the final push that will make this X-Term a huge success! Please help us to make this a great X-Term!!
